Well, shall we just brainstorm a few ideas, to get started?</p></td></tr><tr style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">TRUDIE:</p></td><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">OK. We obviously need to look at the impact of new technology, particularly the&nbsp;internet. Now that lots of books have been digitalised, people can access them from their own computers at home.</p></td></tr><tr style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">STEWART:</p></td><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">And if everyone did that, libraries would be obsolete.</p></td></tr><tr style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">TRUDIE:</p></td><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">Yes.</p></td></tr><tr style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">STEWART:</p></td><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">But the digitalised books that are available online for free are mostly out of copyright. aren&rsquo;t they? And copyright in this country lasts for 70 years after the author dies. So you won&rsquo;t find the latest best-seller or up-to-date information.</span></p></td></tr><tr style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">TRUDIE:</p></td><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">That&rsquo;s an important point</span>. Anyway, I find it hard to concentrate when I&rsquo;m reading a long text on a screen. I&rsquo;d much rather read a physical book. And it takes longer to read on a screen.</p></td></tr><tr style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">STEWART:</p></td><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">Oh, I prefer it I suppose it&rsquo;s just a personal preference.</p></td></tr><tr style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">TRUDIE:</p></td><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">Mm. I expect that libraries will go on evolving in the next few years, Some have &nbsp;already become centres where community activities take place, like local clubs meeting there. I think that&rsquo;ll become even more common.</p></td></tr><tr style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">STEWART:</p></td><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">I&rsquo;d like to think so, and that they&rsquo;ll still be serving their traditional&nbsp;function, but I&rsquo;m not so sure. There are financial implications, after all.&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">What I&rsquo;m afraid will happen is that books and magazines will all disappear, and there&rsquo;ll just be rows and rows of computers</span>. They won&rsquo;t look anything like the libraries we&rsquo;re used to.</p></td></tr><tr style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">TRUDIE:</p></td><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">Well, we&rsquo;ll see.</p></td></tr><tr style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">TRUDIE:</p></td><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">I&rsquo;ve just had an idea. Why don&rsquo;t we make an in-depth study of our local public library as background to our paper?</p></td></tr><tr style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">STEWART:</p></td><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">Yes, that&rsquo;d be interesting, and raise all sorts of issues. Let&rsquo;s make a list of possible things we could ask about, then work out some sort of structure.&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">For instance, um,&nbsp;we could interview some of the staff, and find out whether the library has its own budget. or if that&rsquo;s controlled by the local council.</span></p></td></tr><tr style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">TRUDIE:</p></td><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">And what their policies are. I know they don&rsquo;t allow food, but I&rsquo;d love to find out what types of noise they ban - there always seems to be a lot of talking, but never music. I don&rsquo;t know if that&rsquo;s a policy or it just happens.</p></td></tr><tr style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">STEWART:</p></td><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px;\"><p style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">Ah. Like what measures does the library take to ensure their safety</span>? They&rsquo;d need floor coverings that aren&rsquo;t slippery, and emergency exits, for instance. File: app/src/main/assets/ielts_test/ielts_test_reading.json
----------------------------------------
[
  {
    "type": "Reading",
    "topic": "Recent Actual Tests",
    "questionType": "Matching Headings",
    "title": "The Motor Car",
    "paragraph": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: center; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">The Motor Car</h3></div><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">A</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">There are now over 700 million motor vehicles in the world - and the number is rising by more than 40 million each year. The average distance driven by car users is growing too - from 8 km a day per person in western Europe in 1965 to 25 km a day in 1995. This dependence on motor vehicles has given rise to major problems, including environmental pollution, depletion of oil resources, traffic congestion and safety.</p><p   style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">B&nbsp;</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">While emissions from new cars are far less harmful than they used to be, city streets and motorways are becoming more crowded than ever, often with older trucks, buses and taxis, which emit excessive levels of smoke and fumes. This concentration of vehicles makes air quality in urban areas unpleasant and sometimes dangerous to breathe. Even Moscow has joined the list of capitals afflicted by congestion and traffic fumes. In Mexico City, vehicle pollution is a major health hazard.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">C</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Until a hundred years ago, most journeys were in the 20 km range, the distance conveniently accessible by horse. Heavy freight could only be carried by water or rail. The invention of the motor vehicle brought personal mobility to the masses and made rapid freight delivery possible over a much wider area. Today about 90 per cent of inland freight in the United Kingdom is carried by road. Clearly the world cannot revert to the horse-drawn wagon. Can it avoid being locked into congested and polluting ways of transporting people and goods?</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">D</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">In Europe most cities are still designed for the old modes of transport. Adaptation to the motor car has involved adding ring roads, one-way systems and parking lots. In the United States, more land is assigned to car use than to housing. Urban sprawl means that life without a car is next to impossible. Mass use of motor vehicles has also killed or injured millions of people. Other social effects have been blamed on the car such as alienation and aggressive human behaviour.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">E</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">A 1993 study by the European Federation for Transport and Environment found that car transport is seven times as costly as rail travel in terms of the external social costs it entails such as congestion, accidents, pollution, loss of cropland and natural habitats, depletion of oil resources, and so on. Yet cars easily surpass trains or buses as a flexible and convenient mode of personal transport. It is unrealistic to expect people to give up private cars in favour of mass transit.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">F</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Technical solutions can reduce the pollution problem and increase the fuel efficiency of engines. But fuel consumption and exhaust emissions depend on which cars are preferred by customers and how they are driven. Many people buy larger cars than they need for daily purposes or waste fuel by driving aggressively. Besides, global car use is increasing at a faster rate than the improvement in emissions and fuel efficiency which technology is now making possible.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">G</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">One solution that has been put forward is the long-term solution of designing cities and neighbourhoods so that car journeys are not necessary - all essential services being located within walking distance or easily accessible by public transport. Not only would this save energy and cut carbon dioxide emissions, it would also enhance the quality of community life, putting the emphasis on people instead of cars. Good local government is already bringing this about in some places. But few democratic communities are blessed with the vision - and the capital - to make such profound changes in modern lifestyles.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">H</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">A more likely scenario seems to be a combination of mass transit systems for travel into and around cities, with small &#39;low emission&#39; cars for urban use and larger hybrid or lean burn cars for use elsewhere. Electronically tolled highways might be used to ensure that drivers pay charges geared to actual road use. Better integration of transport systems is also highly desirable - and made more feasible by modern computers. But these are solutions for countries which can afford them. In most developing countries, old cars and old technologies continue to predominate.</p>",
    "question": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px 5px; border-top: 3px solid rgb(255, 165, 0); color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">Questions 1-6</h3><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">Reading Passage 2 has eight paragraphs <strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">(A-H)</strong>. how driving habits contribute to road problems<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: F</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; the impact of the car on city development<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: D</span></p></div><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; Nowadays freight is not carried by water in the United Kingdom.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: NOT GIVEN</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; Most European cities were not designed for motor vehicles.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: YES</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">11&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"YES\">YES</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NO\">NO</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; Technology alone cannot solve the problem of vehicle pollution.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: YES</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">12&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"YES\">YES</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NO\">NO</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; People&#39;s choice of car and attitude to driving is a factor in the pollution problem.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: YES</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">13&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"YES\">YES</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NO\">NO</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; Redesigning cities would be a short-term solution.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: NO</span></p></div>",
    "answerLocation": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: center; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">The Motor Car</h3></div><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">A</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">There are now over 700 million motor vehicles in the world - and the number is rising by more than 40 million each year.</span> The average distance driven by car users is growing too - from 8 km a day per person in western Europe in 1965 to 25 km a day in 1995. This dependence on motor vehicles has given rise to major problems, including environmental pollution, depletion of oil resources, traffic congestion and safety.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">B&nbsp;</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">While emissions from new cars are far less harmful than they used to be, city streets and motorways are becoming more crowded than ever, often with older trucks, buses and taxis, which emit excessive levels of smoke and fumes. This concentration of vehicles makes air quality in urban areas unpleasant and sometimes dangerous to breathe. Even Moscow has joined the list of capitals afflicted by congestion and traffic fumes. In Mexico City,&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">vehicle pollution</span> is a major health hazard.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">C</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">Until a hundred years ago, most journeys were in the 20 km range, the distance conveniently accessible by horse. Heavy freight could only be carried by water or rail.</span> The invention of the motor vehicle brought personal mobility to the masses and made rapid&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">freight</span> delivery possible over a much wider area. Today about 90 per cent of inland freight in the United Kingdom is carried by road.&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">Clearly the world cannot revert to the horse-drawn wagon</span>. Can it avoid being locked into congested and polluting ways of transporting people and goods?</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">D</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">In Europe most cities are still designed for the old modes of transport</span>.&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">Adaptation to the motor car has involved adding ring roads, one-way systems and parking lots</span>. In the United States, more land is assigned to car use than to housing. Urban sprawl means that life without a car is next to impossible. Mass use of motor vehicles has also killed or injured millions of people. Other social effects have been blamed on the car such as alienation and aggressive human behaviour.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">E</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">A 1993 study by the European Federation for Transport and Environment found that car transport is seven times as costly as rail travel in terms of the external social costs it entails such as congestion, accidents, pollution, loss of cropland and natural habitats, depletion of oil resources, and so on. Yet&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">cars easily surpass trains or buses as a flexible and convenient mode of personal transport</span>. It is unrealistic to expect people to give up private cars in favour of mass transit.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">F</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Technical solutions can reduce the pollution problem and increase the fuel efficiency of engines. But fuel consumption and exhaust emissions depend on&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">which cars are preferred by customers and how they are driven.</span> <span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">Many people buy larger cars than they need for daily purposes or waste fuel by driving aggressively</span>. Besides, global car use is increasing at a faster rate than the improvement in emissions and fuel efficiency&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">which technology is now making possible.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">G</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">One solution that has been put forward is the&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">long-term solution of designing cities</span> and neighbourhoods so that car journeys are not necessary - all essential services being located within walking distance or easily accessible by public transport. Not only would this save energy and cut carbon dioxide emissions, it would also enhance the quality of community life, putting the emphasis on people instead of cars. Good local government is already bringing this about in some places. But few democratic communities are blessed with the vision - and the capital - to make such profound changes in modern lifestyles.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">H</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">A more likely scenario seems to be a combination of mass transit systems for travel into and around cities, with small &#39;low emission&#39; cars for urban use and larger hybrid or lean burn cars for use elsewhere. Electronically tolled highways might be used to ensure that drivers pay charges geared to actual road use.<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">&nbsp;Better integration of transport systems is also highly desirable - and made more feasible by modern computers</span>. But these are solutions for countries which can afford them. In most developing countries, old cars and old technologies continue to predominate.</p>",
    "extra": ""
  },
  {
    "type": "Reading",
    "topic": "Recent Actual Tests",
    "questionType": "Matching Information",
    "title": "Being Left-handed in a Right-handed World",
    "paragraph": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: center; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">Being Left-handed in a Right-handed World</h3></div><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial; text-align: center;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">The world is designed for right-handed people. Why does a tenth of the population prefer the left?</em></strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">A</strong> The probability that two right-handed people would have a left-handed child is only about 9.5 percent. The chance rises to 19.5 percent if one parent is a lefty and 26 percent if both parents are left-handed. The preference, however, could also stem from an infant&rsquo;s imitation of his parents. To test genetic influence, starting in the 1970s British biologist Marian Annett of the University of Leicester hypothesized that no single gene determines handedness. Rather, during fetal development, a certain molecular factor helps to strengthen the brain&rsquo;s left hemisphere, which increases the probability that the right hand will be dominant, because the left side of the brain controls the right side of the body, and vice versa. Among the minority of people who lack this factor, handedness develops entirely by chance. Research conducted on twins complicates the theory, however. One in fivesets of identical twins involves one right-handed and one left-handed person, despite the fact that their genetic material is the same. Genes, therefore, are not solely responsible for handedness.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">B</strong> Genetic theory is also undermined by results from Peter Hepper and his team at Queen&rsquo;s University in Belfast, Ireland. In 2004 the psychologists used ultrasound to show that by the 15th week of pregnancy, fetuses already have a preference as to which thumb they suck. In most cases, the preference continued after birth. At 15 weeks, though, the brain does not yet have control over the body&rsquo;s limbs. Hepper speculates that fetuses tend to prefer whichever side of the body is developing quicker and that their movements, in turn, influence the brain&rsquo;s development. Whether this early preference is temporary or holds up throughout development and infancy is unknown. Genetic predetermination is also contradicted by the widespread observation that children do not settle on either their right or left hand until they are two or three years old.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">C</strong> But even if these correlations were true, they did not explain what actually causes left-handedness. Furthermore, specialization on either side of the body is common among animals. Cats will favor one paw over another when fishing toys out from under the couch. Horses stomp more frequently with one hoof than the other. Certain crabs motion predominantly with the left or right claw. In evolutionary terms, focusing power and dexterity in one limb is more efficient than having to train two, four or even eight limbs equally. Yet for most animals, the preference for one side or the other is seemingly random. The overwhelming dominance of the right hand is associated only with humans. That fact directs attention toward the brain&rsquo;s two hemispheres and perhaps toward language.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">D</strong> Interest in hemispheres dates back to at least 1836. That year, at a medical conference, French physician Marc Dax reported on an unusual commonality among his patients. During his many years as a country doctor, Dax had encountered more than 40 men and women for whom speech was difficult, the result of some kind of brain damage. What was unique was that every individual suffered damage to the left side of the brain. At the conference, Dax elaborated on his theory, stating that each half of the brain was responsible for certain functions and that the left hemisphere controlled speech. Other experts showed little interest in the Frenchman&rsquo;s ideas. Over time, however, scientists found more and more evidence of peopleexperiencing speech difficulties following injury to the left brain. Patients with damage to the right hemisphere most often displayed disruptions in perception or concentration. Major advancements in understanding the brain&rsquo;s asymmetry were made in the 1960s as a result of so-called split-brain surgery, developed to help patients with epilepsy. During this operation, doctors severed the corpus callosum&mdash;the nerve bundle that connects the two hemispheres. The surgical cut also stopped almost all normal communication between the two hemispheres, which offered researchers the opportunity to investigate each side&rsquo;s activity.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">E</strong>&nbsp; In 1949 neurosurgeon Juhn Wada devised the first test to provide access to the brain&rsquo;s functional organization of language. By injecting an anesthetic into the right or left carotid artery, Wada temporarily paralyzed one side of a healthy brain, enabling him to more closely study the other side&rsquo;s capabilities. Based on this approach, Brenda Milner and the late Theodore Rasmussen of the Montreal Neurological Institute published a major study in 1975 that confirmed the theory that country doctor Dax had formulated nearly 140 years earlier: in 96 percent of right-handed people, language is processed much more intensely in the left hemisphere. The correlation is not as clear in lefties, however. For two thirds of them, the left hemisphere is still the most active language processor. But for the remaining third, either the right side is dominant or both sides work equally, controlling different language functions. That last statistic has slowed acceptance of the notion that the predominance of right-handedness is driven by left-hemisphere dominance in language processing. It is not at all clear why language control should somehow have dragged the control of body movement with it. Some experts think one reason the left hemisphere reigns over language is because the organs of speech processing&mdash;the larynx and tongue&mdash;are positioned on the body&rsquo;s symmetry axis. Because these structures were centered, it may have been unclear, in evolutionary terms, which side of the brain should control them, and it seems unlikely that shared operation would result in smooth motor activity. Language and handedness could have developed preferentially for very different &nbsp;reasons &nbsp;as &nbsp;well. &nbsp;For &nbsp;example, &nbsp;some &nbsp;researchers, &nbsp;including evolutionary psychologist Michael C. Corballis of the University of Auckland in New Zealand, think that the origin of human speech lies in gestures. Gestures predated words and helped language emerge. If the left hemisphere began to dominate speech, it would have dominated gestures, too, and because the left brain controls the right side of the body, the right hand developed more strongly.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">F&nbsp;</strong> Perhaps we will know more soon. In the meantime, we can revel in what, if any, differences handedness brings to our human talents. Popular wisdom says right-handed, left-brained people excel at logical, analytical thinking. Lefthanded, right-brained individuals are thought to possess more creative skills and may be better at combining the functional features emergent in both sides of the brain. Yet some neuroscientists see such claims as pure speculation. Fewer scientists are &nbsp;ready to claim that left-handedness means greater creative potential. Yet lefties are prevalent among artists, composers and the generally acknowledged great political thinkers. Possibly if these individuals are among the lefties whose language abilities are evenly distributed between hemispheres, the intense interplay required could lead to unusual mental capabilities.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">G</strong> Or perhaps some lefties become highly creative simply because they must be more clever to get by in our right-handed world. This battle, which begins during the very early stages of childhood, may lay the groundwork for exceptional achievements.</p>",
    "question": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: center; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; font-weight: 700;\">5&nbsp;</b><select style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none; border-radius: 3px;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"A\">A</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"B\">B</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"C\">C</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"D\">D</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"E\">E</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"F\">F</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"G\">G</option></select> A reference to an early discovery of each hemisphere&rsquo;s function.</p></div></div><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px 5px; border-top: 3px solid rgb(255, 165, 0); color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: right; margin-top: 10px;\"><br></div><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">Questions 6-9</h3><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">Look at the following researchers (Questions <strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">List of Findings</strong><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">&nbsp;A</strong> Early language evolution is correlated to body movement and thus affecting the preference of use of one hand.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">&nbsp;B</strong> No single biological component determines the handedness of a child.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">C</strong> Each hemisphere of the brain is in charge of different body functions.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">G</strong> Brain function already matures by the end of the fetal stage.</div><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">&nbsp;</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; Theodore Rasmussen<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">9&nbsp;</b><select style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; font-weight: 700;\">&nbsp;F</strong> The rate of development of one side of the body has influence on hemisphere preference in fetus.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">NO</strong>&nbsp; if the statement contradicts the information</em><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">NOT GIVEN</strong>&nbsp; if there is no information on this</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">10&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"YES\">YES</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NO\">NO</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select> The study of twins shows that genetic determinationis not the only factor for left-handedness.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: YES</span>&nbsp; &nbsp;<a style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(51, 122, 183); color: rgb(255, 255, 255); text-decoration: none; display: inline-block; padding: 1px 5px; margin-bottom: 0px; font-size: 11px; font-weight: 400; line-height: 1.5; text-align: center; white-space: nowrap; vertical-align: middle; touch-action: manipulation; cursor: pointer; user-select: none; background-image: none; border: 1px solid rgb(46, 109, 164); border-radius: 3px; overflow: hidden; position: relative; transition-duration: 0.3s;\">&nbsp;Locate</a><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">11&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"YES\">YES</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NO\">NO</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select> Marc Dax&rsquo;s report was widely accepted in his time.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: NO</span>&nbsp; &nbsp;<a style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(51, 122, 183); color: rgb(255, 255, 255); text-decoration: none; display: inline-block; padding: 1px 5px; margin-bottom: 0px; font-size: 11px; font-weight: 400; line-height: 1.5; text-align: center; white-space: nowrap; vertical-align: middle; touch-action: manipulation; cursor: pointer; user-select: none; background-image: none; border: 1px solid rgb(46, 109, 164); border-radius: 3px; overflow: hidden; position: relative; transition-duration: 0.3s;\">&nbsp;Locate</a><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">12&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"YES\">YES</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NO\">NO</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select> Juhn Wada based his findings on his research of people with language problems.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: NOT GIVEN</span><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">13&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"YES\">YES</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NO\">NO</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select> There tend to be more men with left-handedness than women.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: NOT GIVEN</span></p></div>",
    "answerLocation": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: center; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">Being Left-handed in a Right-handed World</h3></div><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial; text-align: center;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">The world is designed for right-handed people. Why does a tenth of the population prefer the left?</em></strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">A</strong> The probability<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">&nbsp;that two right-handed people would have a left-handed child is only about 9.5 percent</span>. The chance rises to 19.5 percent if one parent is a lefty and 26 percent if both parents are left-handed. The preference, however, could also stem from an infant&rsquo;s imitation of his parents. To test genetic influence, starting in the 1970s British biologist&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">Marian Annett of the University of Leicester hypothesized that no single gene determines handedness</span>. Rather,<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">&nbsp;during fetal development, a certain molecular factor helps to strengthen the brain&rsquo;s left hemisphere, which increases the probability that the right hand will be dominant, because the left side of the brain controls the right side of the body, and vice versa</span>. Among the minority of people who lack this factor, handedness develops entirely by chance. Research conducted on twins complicates the theory, however. One in fivesets of identical twins involves one right-handed and one left-handed person, despite the fact that their genetic material is the same.&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">Genes, therefore, are not solely responsible for handedness</span>.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">B</strong> Genetic theory is also undermined by results from Peter Hepper and his team at Queen&rsquo;s University in Belfast, Ireland. In 2004 the psychologists used ultrasound to show that&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">by the 15th week of pregnancy, fetuses already have a preference as to which thumb they suck</span>. In most cases, the preference continued after birth. At 15 weeks, though, the brain does not yet have control over the body&rsquo;s limbs. Hepper speculates that fetuses tend to prefer whichever side of the body is developing quicker and that their movements, in turn, influence the brain&rsquo;s development. Whether this early preference is temporary or holds up throughout development and infancy is unknown. Genetic predetermination is also contradicted by the widespread observation that&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">children do not settle on either their right or left hand until they are two or three years old.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">C</strong> But even if these correlations were true, they did not explain what actually causes left-handedness. Furthermore,&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">specialization on either side of the body is common among animals</span>. Cats will favor one paw over another when fishing toys out from under the couch. Horses stomp more frequently with one hoof than the other. Certain crabs motion predominantly with the left or right claw. In evolutionary terms, focusing power and dexterity in one limb is more efficient than having to train two, four or even eight limbs equally. Yet for most animals, the preference for one side or the other is seemingly random. The overwhelming dominance of the right hand is associated only with humans. That fact directs attention toward the brain&rsquo;s two hemispheres and perhaps toward language.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">D</strong> Interest in hemispheres dates back to at least 1836. That year, at a medical conference, French physician Marc Dax reported on an unusual commonality among his patients. During his many years as a country doctor, Dax had encountered more than 40 men and women for whom speech was difficult, the result of some kind of brain damage. What was unique was that every individual suffered damage to the left side of the brain. At the conference, Dax elaborated on his theory, stating that<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">&nbsp;each half of the brain was responsible for certain functions and that the left hemisphere controlled speech</span>.&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">Other experts showed little interest in the Frenchman&rsquo;s ideas.</span> Over time, however, scientists found more and more evidence of peopleexperiencing speech difficulties following injury to the left brain. Patients with damage to the right hemisphere most often displayed disruptions in perception or concentration. Major advancements in understanding the brain&rsquo;s asymmetry were made in the 1960s as a result of so-called split-brain surgery, developed to help patients with epilepsy. During this operation, doctors severed the corpus callosum&mdash;the nerve bundle that connects the two hemispheres. The surgical cut also stopped almost all normal communication between the two hemispheres, which offered researchers the opportunity to investigate each side&rsquo;s activity.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">E</strong>&nbsp; In 1949 neurosurgeon Juhn Wada devised the first test to provide access to the brain&rsquo;s functional organization of language. By injecting an anesthetic into the right or left carotid artery, Wada temporarily paralyzed one side of a healthy brain, enabling him to more closely study the other side&rsquo;s capabilities. Based on this approach, Brenda Milner and the late Theodore Rasmussen of the Montreal Neurological Institute published a major study in 1975 that confirmed the theory that country doctor Dax had formulated nearly 140 years earlier: in 96 percent of right-handed people,&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">language is processed much more intensely in the left hemisphere</span>. The correlation is not as clear in lefties, however. For two thirds of them, the left hemisphere is still the most active language processor. But for the remaining third, either the right side is dominant or both sides work equally, controlling different language functions. That last statistic has slowed acceptance of the notion that the predominance of right-handedness is driven by left-hemisphere dominance in language processing. It is not at all clear why language control should somehow have dragged the control of body movement with it. Some experts think one reason the left hemisphere reigns over language is because the organs of speech processing&mdash;the larynx and tongue&mdash;are positioned on the body&rsquo;s symmetry axis. Because these structures were centered, it may have been unclear, in evolutionary terms, which side of the brain should control them, and it seems unlikely that shared operation would result in smooth motor activity. Language and handedness could have developed preferentially for very different &nbsp;reasons &nbsp;as &nbsp;well. &nbsp;For &nbsp;example, &nbsp;some &nbsp;researchers, &nbsp;including evolutionary psychologist Michael C. Corballis of the University of Auckland in New Zealand, think that the origin of human speech lies in gestures. Gestures predated words and helped language emerge.&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">If the left hemisphere began to dominate speech, it would have dominated gestures, too, and because the left brain controls the right side of the body, the right hand developed more strongly</span>.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">F&nbsp;</strong> Perhaps we will know more soon. In the meantime, we can revel in what, if any, differences handedness brings to our human talents. Popular wisdom says right-handed, left-brained people excel at logical, analytical thinking. Lefthanded, right-brained individuals are thought to possess more creative skills and may be better at combining the functional features emergent in both sides of the brain. Yet some neuroscientists see such claims as pure speculation. Fewer scientists are &nbsp;ready to claim that left-handedness means greater creative potential. Yet&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">lefties are prevalent among artists, composers and the generally acknowledged great political thinkers.</span> Possibly if these individuals are among the lefties whose language abilities are evenly distributed between hemispheres, the intense interplay required could lead to unusual mental capabilities.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">G</strong> Or perhaps some lefties become highly creative simply because they must be more clever to get by in our right-handed world. This battle, which begins during the very early stages of childhood, may lay the groundwork for exceptional achievements.</p>",
    "extra": ""
  },
