    "answerLocation": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: center; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">In Praise of Amateurs</h3></div><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">Despite the specialization of scientific research, amateurs still have an important role to play.</em></strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">During the scientific revolution of the 17th century,&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">scientists</span> were largely men of private means who pursued their interest in natural philosophy for their own edification. Only in the past century or two has it become possible to make a living from investigating the workings of nature . Modern science was, in other words, built on the work of amateurs. Today,&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">science</span> is an increasingly specialized and compartmentalized subject, the domain of experts &nbsp;who know more and more about less and less. Perhaps surprisingly, however, amateurs &ndash; even those without private means &ndash; are still important.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">A recent poll carried out at a meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science by astronomer Dr Richard Fienberg found that, in addition to his field of astronomy, amateurs are actively involved in such&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">field</span> as acoustics , horticulture, ornithology, meteorology, hydrology and palaeontology. Far from being crackpots, amateur scientists are often in close touch with professionals, some of whom rely heavily on their&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">co-operation</span>.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Admittedly, some fields are more open to amateurs than others. Anything that requires expensive equipment is clearly a no-go area. And some kinds of research can be dangerous; most amateur chemists,&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">jokes Dr Fienberg, are either locked up or have blown themselves to bits</span>. But amateurs can make valuable contributions in fields from rocketry to palaeontology and the rise of the Internet has made it easier than before to collect data and distribute results.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Exactly which field of study has benefited most from the contributions of amateurs is a matter of some dispute. Dr Fienberg makes a strong case for astronomy. There is, he points out, a long tradition of collaboration between amateur and professional sky watchers . Numerous comets, asteroids and even the planet Uranus were discovered by amateurs. Today, in addition to comet and asteroid spotting, amateurs continue to do valuable work observing the brightness of variable stars and detecting novae- &lsquo;new&rsquo; stars in the Milky Way and supernovae in other galaxies. Amateur observers are helpful, says Dr Fienberg, because there are so many of them (they far outnumber professionals) and because they are distributed all over the world. This makes special kinds of&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">observations</span> possible:&rsquo; if several observers around the world accurately record the time when a star is eclipsed by an asteroid, for example, it is possible to derive useful information about the asteroid&rsquo;s shape.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Another field in which amateurs have traditionally played an important role is palaeontology. Adrian&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">Hunt</span>, a palaeontologist at Mesa Technical College in New Mexico, insists that his is the field in which amateurs have made the biggest contribution. Despite the development of high-tech equipment,&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">he says, the best sensors for finding fossils are human eyes &ndash; lots of them</span>.&nbsp;</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Finding volunteers to look for fossils is not difficult, he says, because of the near universal interest in anything to do with&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">dinosaurs</span>. As well as helping with this research, volunteers learn about science, a process&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">he calls &lsquo;recreational education&rsquo;</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Rick Bonney of the Cornell Laboratory of Ornithology in Ithaca, New York, contends that amateurs have contributed the most in his field. There are, he notes, thought to be as many as 60 million birdwatchers in America alone. Given their huge numbers and the wide geographical coverage they provide, Mr Bonney has enlisted thousands of amateurs in a number of research projects. Over the past few years their observations have uncovered previously unknown trends and cycles in bird migrations and revealed declines in the breeding populations of several species of migratory birds, prompting a habitat&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">conservation programme</span>.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Despite the successes and whatever the field of study, collaboration between amateurs and professionals is not without its difficulties. Not everyone, for example is happy with the<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">&nbsp;term &lsquo;amateur&rsquo;</span>.&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">Mr Bonney has coined the term &lsquo;citizen scientist&rsquo;</span> because he felt that other words, such as&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">&lsquo;volunteer&rsquo;</span> sounded disparaging. A more serious problem is the question of how professionals can best&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">acknowledge</span> the contributions made by amateurs . Dr Fienberg says that some amateur astronomers are happy to provide their observations but grumble about not being reimbursed for out-of-pocket expenses. Others feel let down when their observations are used in scientific papers, but they are not listed as co-authors. Dr Hunt says some amateur palaeontologists are disappointed when told that they cannot take finds home with them.&nbsp;</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">These are legitimate concerns but none seems insurmountable. Provided amateurs and professionals agree the terms on which they will work together beforehand, there is no reason why co-operation between the two groups should not flourish. Last year&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">Dr S. Carlson</span>, founder of the Society for Amateur Scientists won an award worth $290,000 for his work in promoting such co-operation. He says that one of the main benefits of the prize is the endorsement it has given to the contributions of amateur scientists, which has done much to silence critics among those professionals who&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">believe science should remain their exclusive preserve</span>.&nbsp;</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">At the moment, says Dr Carlson, the society is involved in several schemes including an innovative rocket-design project and the setting up of a network of observers who will search for evidence of a link between low- frequency radiation and earthquakes. The amateurs, he says, provide enthusiasm and talent, while the professionals provide guidance &lsquo;so that anything they do discover will be taken seriously&rsquo;. Having laid the foundations of science, amateurs will have much to contribute to its ever &ndash; expanding edifice.&nbsp;</p>",
    "extra": ""
  },
  {
    "type": "Reading",
    "topic": "Nature & Environment",
    "questionType": "Matching Headings",
    "title": "RISING SEA",
    "paragraph": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: center; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">RISING SEA</h3></div><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">Paragraph 1. INCREASED TEMPERATURES</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">The average air temperature at the surface of the earth has risen this century, as has the temperature of ocean surface waters. Because water expands as it heats, a warmer ocean means higher sea levels.&nbsp;We cannot say definitely that the temperature rises are due to the greenhouse effect; the heating may&nbsp;be part of a &ldquo;natural&rdquo; variability over a long time-scale that we have not yet recognized I our short&nbsp;100 years of recording. However, assuming the build up of greenhouse gases is responsible, and that the&nbsp;warming will continue. Scientists and inhabitants of low-lying coastal areas would like to know the&nbsp;extent of future sea level rises.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">Paragraph 2.</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Calculating this is not easy. Models used for the purpose have treated the oceans as passive, stationary and one-dimensional. Scientists have assumed that heat simply diffused into the sea from the&nbsp;atmosphere. Using basic physical laws, they then predict how much a known volume of water would&nbsp;expand for a given increase in temperature. But the oceans are not one-dimensional, and recent work&nbsp;by oceanographers, using a new model which takes into account a number of subtle facets of the sea-including vast and complex ocean currents-suggests that the rise in sea level may be less than some earlier estimates had predicted.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">Paragraph 3</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">An international forum on climate change, in 1986, produced figures for likely sea-level rises of 20 cm and 1.4 m, corresponding to atmospheric temperature increases of 1.5 and 4.5C respectively. Some&nbsp;scientists estimate that the ocean warming resulting from those temperature increases by the year&nbsp;2050 would raise the sea level&nbsp;by between 10 cm and 40 cm. This model only takes into account the&nbsp;temperature effect on the oceans; it does not consider changes in sea level brought about by the&nbsp;melting of ice sheets and glaciers, and changes in groundwater storage. When we add on estimates of&nbsp;these, we arrive at figures for total sea-level rises of 15 cm and 70 cm respectively.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">Paragraph 4</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">It&rsquo;s not easy trying to model accurately the enormous complexities of the ever-changing oceans, with their great volume, massive currents and sensitively to the influence of land masses and the&nbsp;atmosphere. For example, consider how heat enters the ocean. Does it just &ldquo;diffuse&rdquo; from the warmer&nbsp;air vertically into the water, and heat only the surface layer of the sea? (Warm water is less dense than&nbsp;cold, so it would not spread downwards). Conventional models of sea-level rise have considered that&nbsp;this the only method, but measurements have shown that the rate of heat transfer into the ocean by&nbsp;vertical diffusion is far lower in practice than the figures that many models have adopted.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">Paragraph 5</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Much of the early work, for simplicity, ignored the fact that water in the oceans moves in three dimensions. By movement, of course, scientists don&rsquo;t mean waves, which are too small individually to&nbsp;consider, but rather movement of vast volumes of water in huge currents. To understand the&nbsp;importance of this, we now need to consider another process-advection. Imagine smoke rising from a&nbsp;chimney. On a still day it will slowly spread out in all directions by means of diffusion. With a strong&nbsp;directional wind, however, it will all shift downwind, this process is advection-the transport of properties&nbsp;(notably heat and salinity in ocean) by the movement of bodies of air or water, rather than by&nbsp;conduction or diffusion.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">Paragraph 6</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Massive oceans current called gyres do the moving. These currents have far more capacity to store heat than does the atmosphere. Indeed, just the top 3 m of the ocean contains more heat than the whole of&nbsp;the atmosphere. The origin of the gyres lies in the fact that more heat from the Sun reaches the&nbsp;Equator than the Poles, and naturally heat trends to move from the former to the latter. Warm air&nbsp;rises at the Equator, and draws more air beneath it in the form of winds (the &ldquo;Trade Winds&quot;) that,&nbsp;together with other air movements, provide the main force driving the ocean currents.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">Paragraph 7</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Water itself is heated at the Equator and moves poleward, twisted by the Earth&rsquo;s rotation and affected by the positions of the continents. The resultant broadly circular movements between about 10 and 40 &#39;&nbsp;North and South are clockwise in the Southern Hemisphere. They flow towards the east at mind&nbsp;latitudes in the equatorial region. They then flow towards the Poles, along the eastern sides of&nbsp;continents, as warm currents. When two different masses of water meet, once will move beneath the&nbsp;other, depending on their relative densities in the subduction process. The densities are determined by&nbsp;temperature and salinity. The convergence of water of different densities from the Equator and the&nbsp;Poles deep in the oceans causes continuous subduction. This means that water moves vertically as well&nbsp;as horizontally. Cold water from the Poles travels as depth-it is denser than warm water-until it&nbsp;emerges at the surface in another part of the world in the form of a cold current.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">Paragraph 8. HOW THE GREENHOUSE EFFECTS WILL CHANGE OCEAN TEMPERATURES</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Ocean currents, in three dimensions, from a giant &ldquo;conveyor belt&rdquo;, distributing heat from the thin surface layer into the interior of the oceans and around the globe. Water may take decades to circulate in these 3-D gyres in the lop kilometer of the ocean, and centuries in the deep water. With the increased atmospheric temperatures due to the greenhouse effect, the oceans conveyor belt will carry more heat into the interior. This subduction moves heat around far more effectively than simple diffusion. Because warm water expands more than cold when it is heated, scientists had presumed that the sea level would rise unevenly around the globe. It is now believed that these inequalities cannot persist, as winds will act to continuously spread out the water expansion. Of course, of global warming changes the strength and distribution of the winds, then this &ldquo;evening-out&rdquo; process may not occur, and the sea level could rise more in some areas than others.</p>",

cursor: not-allowed;\">&nbsp;thermal expansion</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">B</b></span>&nbsp;<input type=\"checkbox\" name=\"q9\" value=\"B\" disabled=\"\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; cursor: not-allowed;\">&nbsp;melting ice</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">C</b></span>&nbsp;<input type=\"checkbox\" name=\"q9\" value=\"C\" disabled=\"\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; cursor: not-allowed;\">&nbsp;increased air temperature</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">D</b></span>&nbsp;<input type=\"checkbox\" name=\"q9\" value=\"D\" disabled=\"\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; cursor: not-allowed;\">&nbsp;changes in the water table&nbsp;</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; Answer: B C E</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">&nbsp;</p></div><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px 5px; border-top: 3px solid rgb(255, 165, 0); color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">Questions 10-14</h3><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">Do the following statements agree with the information given in Reading Passage 2? Write</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; padding-left: 30px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">TRUE &nbsp; &nbsp;</strong>if the statement agrees with the information</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; padding-left: 30px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">NOT GIVEN</strong> &nbsp; &nbsp;if there is no information on this</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">10&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">11&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"TRUE\">TRUE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"FALSE\">FALSE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; Advection of water changes heat and salt levels.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: TRUE</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">12&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"TRUE\">TRUE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"FALSE\">FALSE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; A gyre holds less heat than there is in the atmosphere.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: FALSE</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">13&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"TRUE\">TRUE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"FALSE\">FALSE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; The process of subduction depends on the water density.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: TRUE</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">14&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"TRUE\">TRUE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"FALSE\">FALSE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; The sea level is expected to rise evenly over the Earth&rsquo;s surface.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: FALSE</span></p></div>",
    "answerLocation": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: center; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">RISING SEA</h3></div><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">Paragraph 1. INCREASED TEMPERATURES</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">The average air temperature at the surface of the earth has risen this century, as has the temperature of ocean surface waters. Because water expands as it heats, a warmer ocean means higher sea levels.&nbsp;We cannot say definitely that the temperature rises are due to the greenhouse effect; the heating may&nbsp;be part of a &ldquo;natural&rdquo; variability over a long time-scale that we have not yet recognized I our short&nbsp;100 years of recording. However, assuming the build up of greenhouse gases is responsible, and that the&nbsp;warming will continue. Scientists and inhabitants of low-lying coastal areas would like to know the&nbsp;extent of future sea level rises.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">Paragraph 2.</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Calculating this is not easy. Models used for the purpose have treated the oceans as passive, stationary and one-dimensional. Scientists have assumed that heat simply diffused into the sea from the&nbsp;atmosphere. Using basic physical laws, they then predict how much a known volume of water would&nbsp;expand for a given increase in temperature. But the oceans are not one-dimensional, and recent work&nbsp;by oceanographers, using a new model which takes into account a number of subtle facets of the sea-including vast and complex ocean currents-suggests that the rise in sea level may be less than some earlier estimates had predicted.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">Paragraph 3</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">An international forum on climate change, in 1986, produced figures for likely sea-level rises of 20 cm and 1.4 m, corresponding to atmospheric temperature increases of 1.5 and 4.5C respectively. Some&nbsp;scientists estimate that the ocean warming resulting from those temperature increases by the year&nbsp;2050 would raise the sea level&nbsp;by between 10 cm and 40 cm. This model only takes into account the&nbsp;temperature effect on the oceans; it does not consider changes in sea level brought about by the&nbsp;melting of ice sheets and glaciers, and changes in groundwater storage. When we add on estimates of&nbsp;these, we arrive at figures for total sea-level rises of 15 cm and 70 cm respectively.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">Paragraph 4</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">It&rsquo;s not easy trying to model accurately the enormous complexities of the ever-changing oceans, with their great volume, massive currents and sensitively to the influence of land masses and the&nbsp;atmosphere. For example, consider how heat enters the ocean. Does it just &ldquo;diffuse&rdquo; from the warmer&nbsp;air vertically into the water, and heat only the surface layer of the sea? (Warm water is less dense than&nbsp;cold, so it would not spread downwards). Conventional models of sea-level rise have considered that&nbsp;this the only method, but measurements have shown that the rate of heat transfer into the ocean by&nbsp;vertical diffusion is far lower in practice than the figures that many models have adopted.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">Paragraph 5</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Much of the early work, for simplicity, ignored the fact that water in the oceans moves in three dimensions. By movement, of course, scientists don&rsquo;t mean waves, which are too small individually to&nbsp;consider, but rather movement of vast volumes of water in huge currents. To understand the&nbsp;importance of this, we now need to consider another process-advection. Imagine smoke rising from a&nbsp;chimney. On a still day it will slowly spread out in all directions by means of diffusion. With a strong&nbsp;directional wind, however, it will all shift downwind, this process is advection-the transport of properties&nbsp;(notably heat and salinity in ocean) by the movement of bodies of air or water, rather than by&nbsp;conduction or diffusion.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">Paragraph 6</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Massive oceans current called gyres do the moving. These currents have far more capacity to store heat than does the atmosphere. Indeed, just the top 3 m of the ocean contains more heat than the whole of&nbsp;the atmosphere. The origin of the gyres lies in the fact that more heat from the Sun reaches the&nbsp;Equator than the Poles, and naturally heat trends to move from the former to the latter. Warm air&nbsp;rises at the Equator, and draws more air beneath it in the form of winds (the &ldquo;Trade Winds&quot;) that,&nbsp;together with other air movements, provide the main force driving the ocean currents.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">Paragraph 7</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Water itself is heated at the Equator and moves poleward, twisted by the Earth&rsquo;s rotation and affected by the positions of the continents. The resultant broadly circular movements between about 10 and 40 &#39;&nbsp;North and South are clockwise in the Southern Hemisphere. They flow towards the east at mind&nbsp;latitudes in the equatorial region. They then flow towards the Poles, along the eastern sides of&nbsp;continents, as warm currents. When two different masses of water meet, once will move beneath the&nbsp;other, depending on their relative densities in the subduction process. The densities are determined by&nbsp;temperature and salinity. The convergence of water of different densities from the Equator and the&nbsp;Poles deep in the oceans causes continuous subduction. This means that water moves vertically as well&nbsp;as horizontally. Cold water from the Poles travels as depth-it is denser than warm water-until it&nbsp;emerges at the surface in another part of the world in the form of a cold current.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">Paragraph 8. HOW THE GREENHOUSE EFFECTS WILL CHANGE OCEAN TEMPERATURES</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Ocean currents, in three dimensions, from a giant &ldquo;conveyor belt&rdquo;, distributing heat from the thin surface layer into the interior of the oceans and around the globe. Water may take decades to circulate in these 3-D gyres in the lop kilometer of the ocean, and centuries in the deep water. With the increased atmospheric temperatures due to the greenhouse effect, the oceans conveyor belt will carry more heat into the interior. This subduction moves heat around far more effectively than simple diffusion. Because warm water expands more than cold when it is heated, scientists had presumed that the sea level would rise unevenly around the globe. It is now believed that these inequalities cannot persist, as winds will act to continuously spread out the water expansion. Of course, of global warming changes the strength and distribution of the winds, then this &ldquo;evening-out&rdquo; process may not occur, and the sea level could rise more in some areas than others.</p>",
    "extra": ""
  },

    "type": "Reading",
    "topic": "Education",
    "questionType": "Matching Headings",
    "title": "Do literate women make better",
    "paragraph": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: center; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">Do literate women make better mothers?</h3></div><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Children in developing countries are healthier and more likely to survive past the age of five when their mothers can read and write. Experts In public health accepted this idea decades&nbsp;ago, but until now no one has been able to show that a woman&#39;s ability to read in Itself&nbsp;Improves her children&rsquo;s chances of survival.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Most literate women learnt to read In primary school, and the fact that a woman has had an education may simply indicate her family&rsquo;s wealth or that It values Its children more highly.&nbsp;Now a long-term study carried out In Nicaragua has eliminated these factors by showing that&nbsp;teaching reading to poor adult women, who would otherwise have remained Illiterate, has a&nbsp;direct effect on their children&rsquo;s health and survival.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">In 1979, the government of Nicaragua established a number of social programmes, including a National Literacy Crusade. By 1985, about 300,000 Illiterate adults from all over the&nbsp;country, many of whom had never attended primary school, had learnt how to read, write and&nbsp;use numbers.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">During this period, researchers from the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine, the Central American Institute of Health In Nicaragua, the National Autonomous University of Nicaragua&nbsp;and the Costa Rican Institute of Health Interviewed nearly 3,000 women, some of whom had&nbsp;learnt to read as children, some during the literacy crusade and some who had never learnt&nbsp;at all. The women were asked how many children they had given birth to and how many of&nbsp;them had died In Infancy. The research teams also examined the surviving children to find out&nbsp;how well-nourished they were.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">The Investigators&#39; findings were striking. In the late 1970s, the infant mortality rate for the children of Illiterate mothers was around 110 deaths per thousand live births. At this point In&nbsp;their lives, those mothers who later went on to learn to read had a similar level Of child&nbsp;mortality (105/1000). For women educated in primary school, however, the Infant mortality&nbsp;rate was significantly lower, at 80 per thousand.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">In 1985, after the National Literacy Crusade had ended, the infant mortality figures for those who remained illiterate and for those educated In primary school remained more or less&nbsp;unchanged. For those women who learnt to read through the campaign, the infant mortality&nbsp;rate was 84 per thousand, an impressive 21 points lower than for those women who were&nbsp;still Illiterate. The children of the newly-literate mothers were also better nourished than those&nbsp;of women who could not read.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Why are the children of literate mothers better off? According to Peter Sandiford of the Liverpool School of Tropical Medicine, no one Knows for certain. Child health was not on the&nbsp;curriculum during the women&rsquo;s lessons, so fie and his colleagues are looking at other&nbsp;factors. They are working with the same group of 3,000 women, to try to find out whether&nbsp;reading mothers make better use of hospitals and clinics, opt for smaller families, exert more&nbsp;control at home, learn modern childcare techniques more quickly, or whether they merely&nbsp;have more respect for themselves and their children.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">The Nicaraguan study may have important implications for governments and aid agencies that need to know where to direct their resources. Sandiford says that there is increasing&nbsp;evidence that female education, at any age, is &quot;an important health intervention in its own&nbsp;right&rsquo;. The results of the study lend support to the World Bank&#39;s recommendation that&nbsp;education budgets in developing countries should be increased, not just to help their&nbsp;economies, but also to improve child health.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">&#39;We&rsquo;ve known for a long time that maternal education is important,&rsquo; says John Cleland of the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine. &lsquo;But we thought that even if we started&nbsp;educating girls today, we&#39;d have to wait a generation for the pay off. The Nicaraguan study&nbsp;suggests we may be able to bypass that.&#39;</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Cleland warns that the Nicaraguan crusade was special in many ways, and similar campaigns elsewhere might not work as well. It is notoriously difficult to teach adults skills that do not have an immediate impact on their everyday lives, and many literacy campaigns in other countries have been much less successful. &#39;The crusade was part of a larger effort to bring a better life to the people,&rsquo; says Cleland. Replicating these conditions in other countries will be a major challenge for development workers.</p>",
    "question": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px 5px; border-top: 3px solid rgb(255, 165, 0); color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">Public health experts have known for many years that there is a connection between child health and <b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">2&nbsp;</b><select style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">However, it has not&nbsp;previously been known whether these two factors were directly linked or not.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">This question has been investigated by <b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">3&nbsp;</b><select style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none; border-radius: 3px;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"A\">A</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"B\">B</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"C\">C</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"D\">D</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"E\">E</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"F\">F</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"G\">G</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"H\">H</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"I\">I</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"J\">J</option></select> in Nicaragua.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">As a result, factors such as <b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">4&nbsp;</b><select style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none; border-radius: 3px;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"A\">A</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"B\">B</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"C\">C</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"D\">D</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"E\">E</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"F\">F</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"G\">G</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"H\">H</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"I\">I</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"J\">J</option></select> and attitudes to children have been eliminated, and it has been shown that <b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">5&nbsp;</b><select style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none; border-radius: 3px;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"A\">A</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"B\">B</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"C\">C</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"D\">D</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"E\">E</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"F\">F</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"G\">G</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"H\">H</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"I\">I</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"J\">J</option></select> can in itself improve infant health and survival.</p><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: right; margin-top: 10px;\"><br></div><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">Questions 6-11</h3><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">Do the following statements agree with the claims of the writer in Reading Passage 2?</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">In boxes <strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">6-11</strong> on your answer sheet, write &nbsp; &nbsp;.</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; padding-left: 30px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">YES &nbsp; &nbsp;</strong>if the statement agrees with the claims of the writer</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; padding-left: 30px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">NO &nbsp; &nbsp;</strong>if the statement contradicts the claims of the writer</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; padding-left: 30px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">NOT GIVEN</strong> if it is impossible to say what the writer thinks about this</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; padding-left: 30px;\">&nbsp;</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">6&nbsp;</b><select style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none; border-radius: 3px;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"YES\">YES</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NO\">NO</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; &nbsp; About a thousand of the women interviewed by the researchers had learnt to read when they were children.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">7&nbsp;</b><select style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none; border-radius: 3px;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"YES\">YES</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NO\">NO</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; &nbsp; Before the National Literacy Crusade, illiterate women had approximately the same levels of infant mortality as those who had learnt to read in primary school.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">8&nbsp;</b><select style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none; border-radius: 3px;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"YES\">YES</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NO\">NO</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; &nbsp; Before and after the National Literacy Crusade, the child mortality rate for the illiterate women stayed at about 110 deaths for each thousand live births.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">9&nbsp;</b><select style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none; border-radius: 3px;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"YES\">YES</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NO\">NO</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; &nbsp; The women who had learnt to read through the National Literacy Crusade showed the greatest change in infant mortality levels.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">10&nbsp;</b><select style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none; border-radius: 3px;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"YES\">YES</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NO\">NO</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; color: rgb(255, 0, 0);\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">TWO</strong></span> letters,&nbsp;<strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">A-E</strong>.</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">13</strong> on your answer sheet.</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">Which&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(255, 0, 0);\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">TWO</strong></span> important implications drawn from the Nicaraguan study are mentioned by the writer of the passage?</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">&nbsp;</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">A</b></span>&nbsp;<input type=\"checkbox\" name=\"q12\" value=\"A\" disabled=\"\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box;
