    "answerLocation": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: center; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">Measures to combat infectious disease in tsarist Russia</h3></div><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">A</span> -&nbsp;Systematic intelligence-gathering about external cases of plague.</strong></span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">In the second half of the seventeenth century, Russian authorities began implementing controls at the borders of their empire to prevent the importation of plague, a highly infectious and dangerous disease. Information on disease outbreak occurring abroad was regularly reported to the tsar&rsquo;s court through various means, including commercial channels (travelling merchants), military personnel deployed abroad,&nbsp;</span><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">undercover agents</span><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">, the network of Imperial Foreign Office embassies and representations abroad, and the customs offices. For instance, the heads of customs offices were instructed to question foreigners entering Russia about possible epidemics of dangerous diseases in their respective countries.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px; font-weight: 400;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">B - Partly successful bans against foreign states affected by plague.</strong></span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">If news of an outbreak came from abroad, relations with the affected country were suspended. For instance,&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">foreign vessels were not allowed to dock in Russian ports</span> if there was credible information about the existence of epidemics in countries from whence they had departed. In addition, all foreigners entering Russia from those countries had to undergo quarantine. In 1665, after receiving news about a plague epidemic in England, Tsar Alexei wrote a letter to King Charles II in which he announced the cessation of Russian trade relations with England and other foreign states. These protective measures appeared to have been effective, as the country did not record any cases of plague during that year and in the next three decades. It was not until 1692 that another plague outbreak was recorded in the Russian province of Astrakhan. This epidemic continued for five months and killed 10,383 people, or about 65 percent of the city&rsquo;s population. By the end of the seventeenth century, preventative measures had been widely introduced in Russia, including the isolation of persons ill with plague, the imposition of quarantines, and the distribution of explanatory public health notices about plague outbreaks.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px; font-weight: 400;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">C -&nbsp;Outbreaks of plague as a result of military campaigns.</strong></span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">During the eighteenth century, although&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">none of the occurrences was of the same scale as in the past</span>, plague appeared in Russia several times. For instance, from 1703 to 1705, a plague outbreak that had ravaged Istanbul spread to the Podolsk and Kiev provinces in Russia, and then to Poland and Hungary. After defeating the Swedes in the battle of Poltava in 1709, Tsar Peter I (Peter the Great) dispatched part of his army to Poland, where plague had been raging for two years. Despite preventive measures, the disease spread among the Russian troops. In 1710, the plague reached Riga (then part of Sweden, now the capital of Latvia), where it was active until 1711 and claimed 60,000 lives. During this period, the Russians besieged Riga and, after the Swedes had surrendered the city in 1710, the Russian army lost 9.800 soldiers to the plague. Russian military chronicles of the time note that more soldiers died of the disease after the capture of Riga than from enemy fire during the siege of that city.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px; font-weight: 400;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">D -&nbsp;Various measures to limit outbreaks of plague associated with war</strong></span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">Tsar Peter I imposed strict measures to prevent the spread of plague during these conflicts. Soldiers suspected of being infected were isolated and taken to areas far from military camps. In addition, camps were designed to separate divisions, detachments, and smaller units of soldiers. When plague reached Narva (located in present-day Estonia) and threatened to spread to St. Petersburg, the newly built capital of Russia, Tsar Peter I ordered the army to cordon off the entire boundary along the Luga River, including temporarily halting all activity on the river.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">In order to prevent the movement of people and goods from Narva to St Petersburg and Novgorod, roadblocks and checkpoints were set up on all roads. The tsar&rsquo;s orders were rigorously enforced, and those who disobeyed were hung.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px; font-weight: 400;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">E -&nbsp;The general limitations of early Russian anti-plague measures</strong></span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">However, although the Russian authorities applied such methods to contain the spread of the disease and limit the number of victims,&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">all of the measures had a provisional character: they were intended to respond to a specific outbreak, and were not designed as a coherent set of measures to be implemented systematically at the first sign of plague</span>. The advent of such a standard response system came a few years later.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px; font-weight: 400;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">F -&nbsp;The formulation and publication of preventive strategies</strong></span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">The first attempts to organise procedures and carry out proactive steps to control plague date to the aftermath of the 1727- 1728 epidemic in&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">Astrakhan</span>. In response to this, the Russian imperial authorities issued several decrees aimed at controlling the future spread of plague. Among these decrees, the &lsquo;Instructions for Governors and Heads of Townships&rsquo; required that all governors immediately inform the Senate - a government body created by Tsar Peter I in 1711 to advise the monarch - if plague cases were detected in their respective provinces.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">Furthermore, the decree required that governors ensure the physical examination of all persons suspected of carrying the disease and their subsequent isolation. In addition, it was ordered that sites where plague victims were found had to be encircled by checkpoints and isolated for the duration of the outbreak. These checkpoints were to remain operational for at least six weeks.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">The&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">houses</span> of infected persons were to be burned along with all of the personal property they contained, including farm animals and cattle. The governors were instructed to inform the neighbouring provinces and cities about every plague case occurring on their territories. Finally, letters brought by couriers were heated above a&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">fire</span> before being copied.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">G</strong></span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">The implementation by the authorities of these combined measures demonstrates their intuitive understanding of the importance of the timely isolation of infected people to limit the spread of plague.</span></p>",
    "extra": ""
  },
  {
    "type": "Reading",
    "topic": "Science",
    "questionType": "Matching Information",
    "title": "The harm that picture books can cause",
    "paragraph": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: center; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">The harm that picture books can cause</h3></div><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">A</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">There is a great concern in Europe and North America about declining standards of literacy in schools. In&nbsp;Britain, the fact that 30 per cent of 16 year olds&nbsp;have a reading age of 14 or less has helped to prompt massive educational changes. The development of literacy has far-reaching effects on general intellectual development and thus anything which impedes the development of literacy is a serious matter for us all. So the hunt is on for the cause of the decline in literacy. The search so far has focused on socioeconomic factors, or the effectiveness of &#39;traditional&#39; versus &#39;modern&#39; teaching techniques.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">B</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">The fruitless search for the cause of the increase in illiteracy is a tragic example of the saying &#39;They can&#39;t see the wood for the trees&#39;. When teachers use picture books, they are simply continuing a long-established tradition that is accepted without question. And for the past two decades, illustrations in reading primers have become increasingly detailed and obtrusive, while language has become impoverished &mdash; sometimes to the point of extinction.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">C</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Amazingly, there is virtually no empirical evidence to support the use of illustrations in teaching reading. On the contrary, a great deal of empirical evidence shows that pictures interfere in a damaging way with all aspects of learning to read. Despite this, from North America to the Antipodes, the first books that many school children receive are totally without text.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">D</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">A teacher&#39;s main concern is to help young beginner readers to develop not only the ability to recognise words, but the skills necessary to understand what these words mean. Even if a child is able to read aloud fluently, he or she may not be able to understand much of it: this is called &#39;barking at text&#39;. The teacher&#39;s task of improving comprehension is made harder by influences outside the classroom. But the adverse effects of such things as television, video games, or limited language experiences at home, can be offset by experiencing &#39;rich&#39; language at school.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">E</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Instead, it is not unusual for a book of 30 or more pages to have only one sentence full of repetitive phrases. The artwork is often marvellous, but the pictures make the language redundant, and the children have no need to imagine anything when they read such books. Looking at a picture actively prevents children younger than nine from creating a mental image, and can make it difficult for older children. In order to learn how to comprehend, they need to practise making their own meaning in response to text. They need to have their innate powers of imagination trained.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">F</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">As they grow older, many children turn aside from books without pictures, and it is a situation made more serious as our culture becomes more visual. It is hard to wean children off picture books when pictures have played a major part throughout their formative reading experiences, and when there is competition for their attention from so many other sources of entertainment. The least intelligent are most vulnerable, but tests show that even intelligent children are being affected. The response of educators has been to extend the use of pictures in books and to simplify the language, even at senior levels. The Universities of Oxford and Cambridge recently held joint conferences to discuss the noticeably rapid decline in literacy among their undergraduates.&nbsp;</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">G</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Pictures are also used to help motivate children to read because they are beautiful and eye-catching. But motivation to read should be provided by listening to stories well read, where children imagine in response to the story. Then, as they start to read, they have this experience to help them understand the language. If we present pictures to save children the trouble of developing these creative skills, then I think we are making a great mistake.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">H</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Academic journals ranging from educational research, psychology, language learning, psycholinguistics, and so on cite experiments which demonstrate how detrimental pictures are for beginner readers. Here is a brief selection:</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">I</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">The research results of the Canadian educationalist Dale Willows were clear and consistent: pictures affected speed and accuracy and the closer the pictures were to the words, the slower and more inaccurate the child&#39;s reading became. She claims that when children come to a word they already know, then the pictures are unnecessary and distracting. If they do not know a word and look to the picture for a clue to its meaning, they may well be misled by aspects of the pictures which are not closely related to the meaning of the word they are trying to understand.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">J</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Jay Samuels, an American psychologist, found that poor readers given no pictures learnt significantly more words than those learning to read with books with pictures. He examined the work of other researchers who had reported problems with the use of pictures and who found that a word without a picture was superior to a word plus a picture. When children were given words and pictures, those who seemed to ignore the pictures and pointed at the words learnt more words than the children who pointed at the pictures, but they still learnt fewer words than the children who had no illustrated stimuli at all.</p>",
    "question": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px 5px; border-top: 3px solid rgb(255, 165, 0); color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">Questions 9-12</h3><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">Reading Passage has ten paragraphs, <strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">Reading Passage has ten paragraphs, <strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">A-J.</strong></em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">Which paragraphs state the following information?</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">Write the appropriate letters <strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">A-J</strong> in boxes <strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">9-12</strong> on your answer sheet.</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">NB</strong> There are more paragraphs than summaries, so you will not use them all.</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">&nbsp;</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">9&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"A\">A</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"B\">B</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"C\">C</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"D\">D</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"E\">E</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"F\">F</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"G\">G</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"H\">H</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"I\">I</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"J\">J</option></select> The decline of literacy is seen in groups of differing ages and abilities.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: F</span> &nbsp;</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">10&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"A\">A</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"B\">B</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"C\">C</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"D\">D</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"E\">E</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"F\">F</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"G\">G</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"H\">H</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"I\">I</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"J\">J</option></select> Reading methods currently in use go against research findings.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: C</span>&nbsp; &nbsp;</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">11&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"A\">A</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"B\">B</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"C\">C</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"D\">D</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"E\">E</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"F\">F</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"G\">G</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"H\">H</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"I\">I</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"J\">J</option></select> Readers able to ignore pictures are claimed to make greater progress.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: J</span>&nbsp; &nbsp;</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">12&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"A\">A</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"B\">B</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"C\">C</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"D\">D</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"E\">E</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"F\">F</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"G\">G</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"H\">H</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"I\">I</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"J\">J</option></select> Illustrations in books can give misleading information about word meaning.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: I</span>&nbsp; &nbsp;</p></div><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px 5px; border-top: 3px solid rgb(255, 165, 0); color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">Questions 13</h3><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">From the list below choose the most suitable title for the whole of Reading Passage.</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">Write the appropriate letter<strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">&nbsp;A-E</strong> in box 13 on your answer sheet.&nbsp;</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; padding-left: 30px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">A</b> <input type=\"radio\" name=\"q13\" value=\"A\" disabled=\"\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 4px 0px 0px; font-style: inherit; font-variant: inherit; font-weight: inherit; font-stretch: inherit; font-size: inherit; line-height: normal; font-family: inherit; color: inherit; padding: 0px; cursor: not-allowed;\">&nbsp;The global decline in reading levels</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; padding-left: 30px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">B</b> <input type=\"radio\" name=\"q13\" value=\"B\" disabled=\"\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 4px 0px 0px; font-style: inherit; font-variant: inherit; font-weight: inherit; font-stretch: inherit; font-size: inherit; line-height: normal; font-family: inherit; color: inherit; padding: 0px; cursor: not-allowed;\">&nbsp;Concern about recent educational developments</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; padding-left: 30px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">C</b> <input type=\"radio\" name=\"q13\" value=\"C\" disabled=\"\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 4px 0px 0px; font-style: inherit; font-variant: inherit; font-weight: inherit; font-stretch: inherit; font-size: inherit; line-height: normal; font-family: inherit; color: inherit; padding: 0px; cursor: not-allowed;\">&nbsp;The harm that picture books can cause</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; padding-left: 30px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">D</b> <input type=\"radio\" name=\"q13\" value=\"D\" disabled=\"\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 4px 0px 0px; font-style: inherit; font-variant: inherit; font-weight: inherit; font-stretch: inherit; font-size: inherit; line-height: normal; font-family: inherit; color: inherit; padding: 0px; cursor: not-allowed;\">&nbsp;Research carried out on children&#39;s literature</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; padding-left: 30px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">E</b> <input type=\"radio\" name=\"q13\" value=\"E\" disabled=\"\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 4px 0px 0px; font-style: inherit; font-variant: inherit; font-weight: inherit; font-stretch: inherit; font-size: inherit; line-height: normal; font-family: inherit; color: inherit; padding: 0px; cursor: not-allowed;\"> An examination of modern reading styles<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: C</span></p></div>",
    "answerLocation": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: center; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">The harm that picture books can cause</h3></div><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">A</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">There is a great concern in Europe and North America about declining standards of literacy in schools. In&nbsp;Britain, the fact that 30 per cent of 16 year olds&nbsp;have a reading age of 14 or less has helped to prompt massive educational changes. The development of literacy has far-reaching effects on general intellectual development and thus anything which impedes the development of literacy is a serious matter for us all. So the hunt is on for the cause of the decline in literacy. The search so far has focused on socioeconomic factors, or the effectiveness of &#39;traditional&#39; versus &#39;modem&#39; teaching techniques.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">B</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">The fruitless search for the cause of the increase in illiteracy is a tragic example of the saying &#39;They can&#39;t see the wood for the trees&#39;.&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">When teachers use picture books, they are simply continuing a long-established tradition that is accepted without question</span>. And for the past two decades, illustrations in reading primers have become increasingly detailed and obtrusive, while language has become impoverished &mdash; sometimes to the point of extinction.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">C</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Amazingly, there is virtually no empirical evidence to support the use of illustrations in teaching reading. On the contrary,&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">a great deal of empirical evidence</span> shows that&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">pictures interfere in a damaging way with all aspects of learning to read</span>. Despite this, from North America to the Antipodes, the first books that many school children receive are totally without text.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">D</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">A teacher&#39;s main concern is to help young beginner readers to develop not only the ability to recognise words, but the skills necessary to understand what these words mean</span>. Even if a child is able to read aloud fluently, he or she may&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">not be able to understand much of it</span>: this is called &#39;<strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">barking at text</strong>&#39;. The teacher&#39;s task of improving comprehension is made harder by influences outside the classroom. But the adverse effects of such things as television, video games, or limited language experiences at home, can be offset by experiencing &#39;rich&#39; language at school.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">E</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Instead, it is not unusual for a book of 30 or more pages to have only one sentence full of repetitive phrases.&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">The artwork is often marvellous, but the pictures make the language redundant, and the children have no need to imagine anything when they read such books.</span> <span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">Looking at a picture actively prevents children younger than nine from creating a mental image, and can make it difficult for older children</span>. In order to learn how to comprehend, they need to practise making their own meaning in response to text. They need to have their innate powers of imagination trained.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">F</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">As they grow older, many children turn aside from books without pictures, and it is a situation made more serious as our culture becomes more visual. It is hard to wean children off picture books when pictures have played a major part throughout their formative reading experiences, and when there is competition for their attention from so many other sources of entertainment.&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">The least intelligent are most vulnerable, but tests show that even intelligent children are being affected</span>. The response of educators has been to extend the use of pictures in books and to simplify the language, even at senior levels.&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">The Universities of Oxford and Cambridge recently held joint conferences to discuss the noticeably rapid decline in literacy among their undergraduates.&nbsp;</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">G</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Pictures are also used to help motivate children to read because they are beautiful and eye-catching. But motivation to read should be provided by listening to stories well read, where children imagine in response to the story. Then, as they start to read, they have this experience to help them understand the language. If we present pictures to save children the trouble of developing these creative skills, then I think we are making a great mistake.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">H</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Academic journals ranging from educational research, psychology, language learning, psycholinguistics, and so on cite experiments which demonstrate how detrimental pictures are for beginner readers. Here is a brief selection:</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">I</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">The research results of the Canadian educationalist Dale Willows were clear and consistent: pictures affected speed and accuracy and the closer the pictures were to the words, the slower and more inaccurate the child&#39;s reading became. She claims that when children come to a word they already know, then the pictures are unnecessary and distracting. If they do not know a word and look to the picture for a clue to its meaning,&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">they may well be misled by aspects of the pictures which are not closely related to the meaning of the word they are trying to understand.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">J</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Jay Samuels, an American psychologist, found that&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">poor readers given no pictures learnt significantly more words than those learning to read with books with pictures</span>. He examined the work of other researchers who had reported problems with the use of pictures and who found that a word without a picture was superior to a word plus a picture. When children were given words and pictures, those who seemed to ignore the pictures and pointed at the words learnt more words than the children who pointed at the pictures, but they still learnt fewer words than the children who had no illustrated stimuli at all.</p>",
    "extra": ""

    "type": "Reading",
    "topic": "Economics & Business",
    "questionType": "TRUE-FALSE-NOT GIVEN",
    "title": "BAKELITE - The birth of modem plastics",
    "paragraph": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: center; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">BAKELITE - The birth of modem plastics</h3></div><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">In 1907, Leo Hendrick Baekeland, a Belgian scientist working in New York, discovered and patented a revolutionary new synthetic material. His invention, which he named &#39;Bakelite&#39;, was of enormous technological importance, and effectively launched the modern plastics industry.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">The term &#39;plastic&#39; comes from the Greek plassein, meaning &#39;to mould&#39; Some plastics are derived from natural sources, some are semi-synthetic (the result of chemical action on a natural substance), and some are entirely synthetic, that is, chemically engineered from the constituents of coal or oil. Some are &#39;thermoplastic&#39;, which means that, like candlewax, they melt when heated and can then be reshaped. Others are &#39;thermosetting&#39;: like eggs, they cannot revert to their original viscous state, and their shape is thus fixed for ever Bakelite had the distinction of being the first totally synthetic thermosetting plastic.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">The history of today&#39;s plastics begins with the discovery of a series of semi-synthetic thermoplastic materials in the mid-nineteenth century. The impetus behind the development of these early plastics was generated by a number of factors - immense technological progress in the domain of chemistry, coupled with wider cultural changes, and the pragmatic need to find acceptable substitutes for dwindling supplies of &#39;luxury&#39; materials such as tortoiseshell and ivory.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Baekeland&#39;s interest in plastics began in 1885 when, as a young chemistry student in Belgium, he embarked on research into phenolic resins, the group of sticky substances produced when phenol (carbolic acid) combines with an aldehyde (a volatile fluid similar to alcohol). He soon abandoned the subject, however, only returning to it some years later. 8y 1905 he was a wealthy New Yorker, having recently made his fortune with the invention of a new photographic paper. While Baekeland had been busily amassing dollars, some advances had been made in the development of plastics. The years 1899 and 1900 had seen the patenting of the first semi-synthetic thermosetting material that could be manufactured on an industrial scale. In purely scientific terms, Baekeland&#39;s major contribution to the field is not so much the actual discovery of the material to which he gave his name, but rather the method by which a reaction between phenol and formaldehyde could be controlled, thus making possible its preparation on a commercial basis. On 13 July 1907, Baekeland took out his famous patent describing this preparation, the essential features of which are still in use today.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">The original patent outlined a three-stage process, in which phenol and formaldehyde (from wood or coal) were initially combined under vacuum inside a large egg-shaped kettle. The result was a resin known as Novalak, which became soluble and malleable when heated. The resin was allowed to cool in shallow trays until it hardened, and then broken up and ground into powder. Other substances were then introduced: including fillers, such as woodflour, asbestos or cotton, which increase strength and moisture resistance, catalysts (substances to speed up the reaction between two chemicals without joining to either) and hexa, a compound of ammonia and formaldehyde which supplied the additional formaldehyde necessary to form a thermosetting resin. This resin was then left to cool and harden, and ground up a second time. The resulting granular powder was raw Bakelite, ready to be made into a vast range of manufactured objects. In the last stage, the heated Bakelite was poured into a hollow mould of the required shape and subjected to extreme heat and pressure, thereby &#39;setting&#39; its form for life.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">The design of Bakelite objects, everything from earrings to television sets, was governed to a large extent by the technical requirements of the moulding process. The object could not be designed so that it was locked into the mould and therefore difficult to extract. A common general rule was that objects should taper towards the deepest part of the mould, and if necessary the product was moulded in separate pieces. Moulds had to be carefully designed so that the molten Bakelite would flow evenly and completely into the mould. Sharp corners proved impractical and were thus avoided, giving rise to the smooth, &#39;streamlined&#39; style popular in the 1930s. The thickness of the walls of the mould was also crucial&rsquo; thick walls took longer to cool and harden, a factor which had to be considered by the designer in order to make the most efficient use of machines.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Baekeland&#39;s invention, although treated with disdain in its early years, went on to enjoy an unparalleled popularity which lasted throughout the first half of the twentieth century. It became the wonder product of the new world of industrial expansion - &#39;the material of a thousand uses&#39;. Being both non-porous and heat-resistant, Bakelite kitchen goods were promoted as being germ-free and sterilisable. Electrical manufacturers seized on its insulating properties, and consumers everywhere relished its dazzling array of shades, delighted that they were now, at last, no longer restricted to the wood tones and drab browns of the preplastic era. It then fell from favour again during the 1950s, and was despised and destroyed in vast quantities. Recently, however, it has been experiencing something of a renaissance, with renewed demand for original Bakelite objects in the collectors&#39; marketplace, and museums, societies and dedicated individuals once again appreciating the style and originality of this innovative material.</p>",
    "question": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px 5px; border-top: 3px solid rgb(255, 165, 0); color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">Questions 1-3</h3><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">Complete the summary.</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">Choose <span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(255, 0, 0);\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">ONE WORD ONLY</strong></span> from the passage for each answer. Write your answers in boxes<strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">&nbsp;1-3</strong> on your answer sheet.</em></p><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 10px; border: 1px solid black;\">&nbsp;<p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">Some plastics behave in a similar way to <b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">1&nbsp;</b><input type=\"text\" required=\"\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; border: 1px solid rgb(204, 204, 204); border-radius: 4px; width: 130px; background-color: rgb(255, 228, 225);\">. In that they melt under heat and can be moulded into new forms. Bakelite was unique because it was the first material to be both entirely <b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">2&nbsp;</b><input type=\"text\" required=\"\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; border: 1px solid rgb(204, 204, 204); border-radius: 4px; width: 130px; background-color: rgb(255, 228, 225);\">&nbsp;in origin, and thermosetting.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">There were several reasons for the research into plastics in the nineteenth century, among them the great advances that had been made in the field of <b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">3&nbsp;</b><input type=\"text\" required=\"\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; border: 1px solid rgb(204, 204, 204); border-radius: 4px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: right; margin-top: 10px;\"><br></div><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; padding-left: 30px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">TRUE</strong> if the statement agrees with the information</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; padding-left: 30px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">FALSE</strong> if the statement contradicts the information</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; padding-left: 30px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">NOT GIVEN</strong> if there is no information on this</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; padding-left: 30px;\">&nbsp;</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">11&nbsp;</b><select style=\"box-sizing: border-box;     "answerList": "1. candlewax\t8. pressure\n2. synthetic\t9. B, C IN EITHER ORDER\n3. chemistry\t10. B, C IN EITHER ORDER\n4. Novalak\t11. TRUE\n5. fillers\t12. FALSE\n6. hexa\t13. FALSE\n7. raw",
    "answerDetail": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px 5px; color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">Questions 1-3</h3><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">Complete the summary.</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">Choose <span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(255, 0, 0);\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">ONE WORD ONLY</strong></span> from the passage for each answer. Write your answers in boxes<strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">&nbsp;1-3</strong> on your answer sheet.</em></p><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 10px; border: 1px solid black;\">&nbsp;<p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">Some plastics behave in a similar way to <b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">1&nbsp;</b><input type=\"text\" required=\"\" readonly=\"\" value=\"\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit;\"><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: candlewax</span>. In that they melt under heat and can be moulded into new forms. Bakelite was unique because it was the first material to be both entirely <b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">2&nbsp;</b><input type=\"text\" required=\"\" readonly=\"\" value=\"\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit;\"> in origin, and thermosetting.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: synthetic</span>&nbsp; &nbsp;</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">There were several reasons for the research into plastics in the nineteenth century, among them the great advances that had been made in the field of <b style=\"box-sizing: border-box;
