    "answerLocation": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: center; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">BAKELITE - The birth of modem plastics</h3></div><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">In 1907, Leo Hendrick Baekeland, a Belgian scientist working in New York, discovered and patented a revolutionary new synthetic material. His invention, which he named &#39;Bakelite&#39;, was of enormous technological importance, and effectively launched the modern plastics industry.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">The term &#39;plastic&#39; comes from the Greek plassein, meaning &#39;to mould&#39; Some plastics are derived from natural sources, some are semi-synthetic (the result of chemical action on a natural substance), and some are entirely synthetic, that is, chemically engineered from the constituents of coal or oil. Some are &#39;thermoplastic&#39;, which means that, like candlewax, they melt when heated and can then be reshaped. Others are &#39;thermosetting&#39;: like eggs, they cannot revert to their original viscous state, and their shape is thus fixed for ever Bakelite had the distinction of being the first totally&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">synthetic</span> thermosetting plastic.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">The history of today&#39;s plastics begins with the discovery of a series of semi-synthetic thermoplastic materials in the mid-nineteenth century. The impetus behind the development of these early plastics was generated by a number of factors - immense technological progress in the domain of&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">chemistry</span>, coupled with wider cultural changes, and the pragmatic need to find acceptable substitutes for dwindling supplies of &#39;luxury&#39; materials such as tortoiseshell and ivory.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Baekeland&#39;s interest in plastics began in 1885 when, as a young chemistry student in Belgium, he embarked on research into phenolic resins, the group of sticky substances produced when phenol (carbolic acid) combines with an aldehyde (a volatile fluid similar to alcohol). He soon abandoned the subject, however, only returning to it some years later. 8y 1905 he was a wealthy New Yorker, having recently made his fortune with the invention of a new photographic paper. While Baekeland had been busily amassing dollars, some advances had been made in the development of plastics. The years 1899 and 1900 had seen the patenting of the first semi-synthetic thermosetting material that could be manufactured on an industrial scale. In purely scientific terms, Baekeland&#39;s major contribution to the field is not so much the actual discovery of the material to which he gave his name, but rather the method by which a reaction between phenol and formaldehyde could be controlled, thus making possible its preparation on a commercial basis.&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">On 13 July 1907, Baekeland took out his famous patent describing this preparation, the essential features of which are still in use today.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">The original patent outlined a three-stage process, in which phenol and formaldehyde (from wood or coal) were initially combined under vacuum inside a large egg-shaped kettle. The result was a resin known as Novalak, which became soluble and malleable when heated. The resin was allowed to cool in shallow trays until it hardened, and then broken up and ground into powder. Other substances were then introduced: including&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">fillers</span>, such as woodflour, asbestos or cotton, which increase strength and moisture resistance, catalysts (substances to speed up the reaction between two chemicals without joining to either) and hexa, a compound of ammonia and formaldehyde which supplied the additional formaldehyde necessary to form a thermosetting resin. This resin was then left to cool and harden, and ground up a second time. The resulting granular powder was&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">raw</span> Bakelite, ready to be made into a vast range of manufactured objects. In the last stage, the heated Bakelite was poured into a hollow mould of the required shape and subjected to extreme heat and&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">pressure</span>, thereby &#39;setting&#39; its form for life.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">The design of Bakelite objects, everything from earrings to television sets, was governed to a large extent by the technical<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">requirements of the moulding process.</span> The object could not be designed so that it was locked into the mould and therefore difficult to extract. A common general rule was that objects should taper towards the deepest part of the mould, and&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">if necessary the product was moulded in separate pieces</span>. Moulds had to be carefully designed so that the molten Bakelite would flow evenly and completely into the mould. Sharp corners proved impractical and were thus avoided, giving rise to the smooth, &#39;streamlined&#39; style popular in the 1930s. The thickness of the walls of the mould was also crucial&rsquo; thick walls took longer to cool and harden, a factor which had to be considered by the designer in order to make the most efficient use of machines.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">Baekeland&#39;s invention, although treated with disdain in its early years</span>, went on to enjoy an unparalleled popularity which lasted throughout the first half of the twentieth century. It became the wonder product of the new world of industrial expansion - &#39;the material of a thousand uses&#39;. Being both non-porous and heat-resistant, Bakelite kitchen goods were promoted as being germ-free and sterilisable. Electrical manufacturers seized on its insulating properties, and consumers everywhere relished its&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">dazzling array of shades</span>, delighted that they were now, at last, no longer restricted to the wood tones and drab browns of the preplastic era. It then fell from favour again during the 1950s, and was despised and destroyed in vast quantities. Recently, however, it has been experiencing something of a renaissance, with renewed demand for original Bakelite objects in the collectors&#39; marketplace, and museums, societies and dedicated individuals once again appreciating the style and originality of this innovative material.</p>",
    "extra": ""
  },
  {
    "type": "Reading",
    "topic": "Nature & Environment",
    "questionType": "TRUE-FALSE-NOT GIVEN",
    "title": "Glaciers",
    "paragraph": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: center; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">Glaciers</h3></div><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">A</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Besides the earth&rsquo;s oceans, glacier ice is the largest source of water on earth. A glacier is a massive stream or sheet of ice that moves underneath itself under the influence of gravity. Some glaciers travel down mountains or valleys, while others spread across a large expanse of land. Heavily glaciated regions such as Greenland and Antarctica are called continental glaciers. These two ice sheets encompass more than 95 percent of the earth&rsquo;s glacial ice. The Greenland ice sheet is almost 10,000 feet thick in some areas, and the weight of this glacier is so heavy that much of the region has been depressed below sea level. Smaller glaciers that occur at higher elevations are called alpine or valley glaciers. Another way of classifying glaciers is in terms of their internal temperature. In temperate glaciers, the ice within the glacier is near its melting point. Polar glaciers, in contrast, always maintain temperatures far below melting.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">B</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">The majority of the earth&rsquo;s glaciers are located near the poles, though glaciers exist on all continents, including Africa and Oceania. The reason glaciers are generally formed in high alpine regions is that they require cold temperatures throughout the year. In these areas where there is little opportunity for&nbsp;summer ablation (loss of mass), snow changes to compacted fim and then crystallized ice. During periods in which melting and evaporation exceed the amount of snowfall, glaciers will retreat rather than progress. While glaciers rely heavily on snowfall, other climactic conditions including freezing rain, avalanches, and wind, contribute to their growth. One year of below average precipitation can stunt the growth of a glacier tremendously. With the rare exception of surging glaciers, a common glacier flows about 10 inches per day in the summer and 5 inches per day in the winter. The fastest glacial surge on record occurred in 1953, when the Kutiah Glacier in Pakistan grew more than 12 kilometers in three months.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">C</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">The weight and pressure of ice accumulation causes glacier movement. Glaciers move out from under themselves, via plastic deformation and basal slippage. First, the internal flow of ice crystals begins to spread outward and downward from the thickened snow pack also known as the zone of accumulation. Next, the ice along the ground surface begins to slip in the same direction. Seasonal thawing at the base of the glacier helps to facilitate this slippage. The middle of a glacier moves faster than the sides and bottom because there is no rock to cause friction. The upper part of a glacier rides on the ice below. As a glacier moves it carves out a U-shaped valley similar to a riverbed, but with much steeper walls and a flatter bottom.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">D</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Besides the extraordinary rivers of ice, glacial erosion creates other unique physical features in the landscape such as horns, fjords, hanging valleys, and cirques. Most of these landforms do not become visible until after a glacier has receded. Many are created by moraines, which occur at the sides and front of a glacier. Moraines are formed when material is picked up along the way and deposited in a new location. When many alpine glaciers occur on the same mountain, these moraines can create a horn. The Matterhorn, in the Swiss Alps is one of the most famous horns. Fjords, which are very common in Norway, are coastal valleys that fill with ocean water during a glacial retreat. Hanging valleys occur when two or more glacial valleys intersect at varying elevations. It is common for waterfalls to connect the higher and lower hanging valleys, such as in Vosemite National Park. A cirque is a large bowlshaped valley that forms at the front of a glacier. Cirques often have a lip on their down slope that is deep enough to hold small lakes when the ice melts away.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">E</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Glacier movement and shape shifting typically occur over hundreds of years. While presently about 10 percent of the earth&rsquo;s land is covered with glaciers, it is believed that during the last Ice Age glaciers covered approximately 32 percent of the earth&rsquo;s surface. In the past century, most glaciers have been retreating rather than flowing forward. It is unknown whether this glacial activity is due to human impact or natural causes, but by studying glacier movement, and comparing climate and agricultural profiles over hundreds of years, glaciologists can begin to understand environmental issues such as global warming.</p>",
    "question": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px 5px; border-top: 3px solid rgb(255, 165, 0); color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; padding: 0px 5px; border-top: 3px solid rgb(255, 165, 0); color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: right; margin-top: 10px;\"><br></div><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">Questions 6-10</h3><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">Do the following statements agree with the information in Passage 1 ? in boxes <strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">6-10</strong> on your Answer Sheet, write</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; padding-left: 30px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">TRUE</strong> if the statement is true according to the passage.</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; padding-left: 30px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">FALSE</strong> if the statement contradicts the passage.</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; padding-left: 30px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">NOT GIVEN</strong> if there is no information about this in the passage.</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">6&nbsp;</b><select style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none; border-radius: 3px;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"TRUE\">TRUE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"FALSE\">FALSE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; &nbsp; Glaciers exist only near the north and south poles.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">7&nbsp;</b><select style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none; border-radius: 3px;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"TRUE\">TRUE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"FALSE\">FALSE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; &nbsp; Glaciers are formed by a combination of snow and other weather conditions.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">8&nbsp;</b><select style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none; border-radius: 3px;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"TRUE\">TRUE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"FALSE\">FALSE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; &nbsp; Glaciers normally move at a rate of about 5 to 10 inches a day.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">9&nbsp;</b><select style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none; border-radius: 3px;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"TRUE\">TRUE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"FALSE\">FALSE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; &nbsp; All parts of the glacier move at the same speed.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">10&nbsp;</b><select style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none; border-radius: 3px;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"TRUE\">TRUE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"FALSE\">FALSE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; &nbsp; During the last Ice Age, average temperatures were much lower than they are now.</p></div></div><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px 5px; border-top: 3px solid rgb(255, 165, 0); color: rgb(51, 51, 51); text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; padding-left: 30px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">FALSE</strong> if the statement contradicts the passage.</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; padding-left: 30px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">NOT GIVEN</strong> if there is no information about this in the passage.</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">6&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"TRUE\">TRUE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"FALSE\">FALSE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; Glaciers exist only near the north and south poles.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: FALSE</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">7&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"TRUE\">TRUE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"FALSE\">FALSE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; Glaciers are formed by a combination of snow and other weather conditions.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: TRUE</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">8&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"TRUE\">TRUE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"FALSE\">FALSE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; Glaciers normally move at a rate of about 5 to 10 inches a day.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: TRUE</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">9&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"TRUE\">TRUE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"FALSE\">FALSE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; All parts of the glacier move at the same speed.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: FALSE</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">10&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"TRUE\">TRUE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"FALSE\">FALSE</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"NOT GIVEN\">NOT GIVEN</option></select>&nbsp; During the last Ice Age, average temperatures were much lower than they are now.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: NOT GIVEN</span></p></div><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px 5px; border-top: 3px solid rgb(255, 165, 0); color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">Questions 11-15</h3><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">Match each definition below with the term it defines.</em></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><em style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\">Write the letter of the term,&nbsp;<strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"A\">A</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"B\">B</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"C\">C</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"D\">D</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"E\">E</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"F\">F</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"G\">G</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"H\">H</option></select><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: B</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">12 &nbsp; &nbsp;</strong>a glacier with temperatures well below freezing&nbsp;<select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"A\">A</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"B\">B</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"C\">C</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"D\">D</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"E\">E</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"F\">F</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"G\">G</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"H\">H</option></select><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"A\">A</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"B\">B</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"C\">C</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"D\">D</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"E\">E</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"F\">F</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"G\">G</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"H\">H</option></select><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: H</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">14 &nbsp; &nbsp;</strong>a glacial valley formed near the ocean&nbsp;<select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"A\">A</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"B\">B</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"C\">C</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"D\">D</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"E\">E</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"F\">F</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"G\">G</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"H\">H</option></select><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: vii</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">15 &nbsp;</strong> a glacial valley that looks like a bowl&nbsp;<select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit; text-transform: none;\"><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"\">&nbsp;</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"A\">A</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"B\">B</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"C\">C</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"D\">D</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"E\">E</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"F\">F</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"G\">G</option><option style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\" value=\"H\">H</option></select><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: G</span></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div>",
    "answerLocation": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: center; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">Glaciers</h3></div><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">A</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Besides the earth&rsquo;s oceans, glacier ice is the largest source of water on earth. A glacier is a massive stream or sheet of ice that moves underneath itself under the influence of gravity. Some glaciers travel down mountains or valleys, while others spread across a large expanse of land. Heavily glaciated regions such as Greenland and Antarctica are called continental glaciers. These two ice sheets encompass more than 95 percent of the earth&rsquo;s glacial ice. The Greenland ice sheet is almost 10,000 feet thick in some areas, and the weight of this glacier is so heavy that much of the region has been depressed below sea level. Smaller glaciers that occur at higher elevations are called alpine or valley glaciers. Another way of classifying glaciers is in terms of their internal temperature. In temperate glaciers, the ice within the glacier is near its melting point. Polar glaciers, in contrast, always maintain temperatures far below melting.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">B</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">The majority of the earth&rsquo;s glaciers are located near the poles, though glaciers exist on all continents, including Africa and Oceania. The reason glaciers are generally formed in high alpine regions is that they require cold temperatures throughout the year. In these areas where there is little opportunity for&nbsp;summer ablation (loss of mass), snow changes to compacted fim and then crystallized ice. During periods in which melting and evaporation exceed the amount of snowfall, glaciers will retreat rather than progress. While glaciers rely heavily on snowfall, other climactic conditions including freezing rain, avalanches, and wind, contribute to their growth. One year of below average precipitation can stunt the growth of a glacier tremendously. With the rare exception of surging glaciers, a common glacier flows about 10 inches per day in the summer and 5 inches per day in the winter. The fastest glacial surge on record occurred in 1953, when the Kutiah Glacier in Pakistan grew more than 12 kilometers in three months.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">C</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">The weight and pressure of ice accumulation causes glacier movement. Glaciers move out from under themselves, via plastic deformation and basal slippage. First, the internal flow of ice crystals begins to spread outward and downward from the thickened snow pack also known as the zone of accumulation. Next, the ice along the ground surface begins to slip in the same direction. Seasonal thawing at the base of the glacier helps to facilitate this slippage. The middle of a glacier moves faster than the sides and bottom because there is no rock to cause friction. The upper part of a glacier rides on the ice below. As a glacier moves it carves out a U-shaped valley similar to a riverbed, but with much steeper walls and a flatter bottom.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">D</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Besides the extraordinary rivers of ice, glacial erosion creates other unique physical features in the landscape such as horns, fjords, hanging valleys, and cirques. Most of these landforms do not become visible until after a glacier has receded. Many are created by moraines, which occur at the sides and front of a glacier. Moraines are formed when material is picked up along the way and deposited in a new location. When many alpine glaciers occur on the same mountain, these moraines can create a horn. The Matterhorn, in the Swiss Alps is one of the most famous horns. Fjords, which are very common in Norway, are coastal valleys that fill with ocean water during a glacial retreat. Hanging valleys occur when two or more glacial valleys intersect at varying elevations. It is common for waterfalls to connect the higher and lower hanging valleys, such as in Vosemite National Park. A cirque is a large bowlshaped valley that forms at the front of a glacier. Cirques often have a lip on their down slope that is deep enough to hold small lakes when the ice melts away.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><strong style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">E</strong></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Glacier movement and shape shifting typically occur over hundreds of years. While presently about 10 percent of the earth&rsquo;s land is covered with glaciers, it is believed that during the last Ice Age glaciers covered approximately 32 percent of the earth&rsquo;s surface. In the past century, most glaciers have been retreating rather than flowing forward. It is unknown whether this glacial activity is due to human impact or natural causes, but by studying glacier movement, and comparing climate and agricultural profiles over hundreds of years, glaciologists can begin to understand environmental issues such as global warming.</p>",
    "extra": ""
  },

    "type": "Reading",
    "topic": "Recent Actual Tests",
    "questionType": "TRUE-FALSE-NOT GIVEN",
    "title": "The way the brain buys",
    "paragraph": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: center; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">The way the brain buys</h3></div><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">Supermarkets take great care over the way the goods they sell are arranged. This is because they know a lot about how to persuade people to buy things.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">When yon enter a supermarket, it takes some time for the mind to get into a shopping mode. This is why the area immediately inside the entrance of a supermarket is known as the &lsquo;decompression zone&rsquo;. People need to slow down and take stock of the surroundings, even if they are regulars. Supermarkets do not expect to sell much here, so it tends to be used more for promotion. So the large items piled up here are designed to suggest that there are bargains further inside the store, and shoppers are not necessarily expected to buy them. Walmart, the world&rsquo;s biggest retailer, famously employs &lsquo;greeters&rsquo; at the entrance to its stores. A friendly welcome is said to cut shoplifting. It is harder to steal from nice people.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">Immediately to the left in many supermarkets is a &lsquo;chill zone&rsquo;, where customers can enjoy browsing magazines, books and DVDs. This is intended to tempt unplanned purchases and slow customers down. But people who just want to do their shopping quickly will keep walking ahead, and the first thing they come to is the fresh fruit and vegetables section. However, for shoppers, this makes no sense. Fruit and vegetables can be easily damaged, so they should be bought at the end, not the beginning, of a shopping trip. But psychology is at work here: selecting these items makes people feel good, so they feel less guilty about reaching for less healthy food later on.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">Shoppers already know that everyday items, like milk, arc invariably placed towards the back of a store to provide more opportunity to tempt customers to buy things which are not on their shopping list. This is why pharmacies are also generally at the back. But supermarkets know shoppers know this, so they use other tricks, like placing popular items halfway along a section so that people have to walk all along the aisle looking for them. The idea is to boost &lsquo;dwell time&rsquo;: the length of time people spend in a store.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">Having walked to the end of the fruit-and-vegetable aisle, shoppers arrive at counters of prepared food, the fishmonger, the butcher and the deli. Then there is the in-store bakery, which can be smelt before it is seen. Even small supermarkets now use in store bakeries. Mostly these bake pre-prepared items and frozen ingredients which have been delivered to the supermarket previously, and their numbers have increased, even though central bakeries that deliver to a number of stores are much more efficient. They do it for the smell of freshly baked bread, which arouses people&rsquo;s appetites and thus encourages them to purchase not just bread but also other food, including ready meals.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Retailers and producers talk a lot about the &lsquo;moment of truth&rsquo;. This is not a philosophical idea, but the point when people standing in the aisle decide to buy something and reach to get it. At the instant coffee section, for example, branded products from the big producers are arranged at eye level while cheaper ones are lower down, along with the supermarket&rsquo;s own label products.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">But shelf positioning is fiercely fought over, not just by those trying to sell goods, but also by those arguing over how best to manipulate shoppers. While many stores reckon eye level is the top spot, some think a little higher is better. Others think goods displayed at the end of aisles sell the most because they have the greatest visibility. To be on the right-hand side of an eye-level selection is often considered the very best place, because most people are right-handed and most people&rsquo;s eyes drift rightwards. Some supermarkets reserve that for their most expensive own-label goods.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">Scott Bearse, a retail expert with Deloitte Consulting in Boston, Massachusetts, has led projects observing and questioning tens of thousands of customers about how they feel about shopping. People say they leave shops empty- handed more often because they are &lsquo;unable to decide&rsquo; than because prices are too high, says Mr Bearse. Getting customers to try something is one of the best ways of getting them to buy, adds Mr Bearse. Deloitte found that customers who use fitting rooms in order to try on clothes buy the product they are considering at a rate of&nbsp;</span><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">8</span><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">j% compared with&nbsp;</span><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">58</span><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">% for those that do not do so.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">Often a customer struggling to decide which of two items is best ends up not buying either. In order to avoid a situation where a customer decides not to buy either product, a third &lsquo;decoy&rsquo; item, which is not quite as good as the other two, is placed beside them to make the choice easier and more pleasurable. Happier customers are more likely to buy.</span></p>",
    "question": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px 5px; border-top: 3px solid rgb(255, 165, 0); color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-weight: 400;\">The most frequent reason for leaving shops without buying something is price.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">&lsquo;Decoy&rsquo; items are products which the store expects customers to choose.</span></p></div></div><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px 5px; border-top: 3px solid rgb(255, 165, 0); color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; font-weight: 400;\">The most frequent reason for leaving shops without buying something is price.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: FALSE</span>&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\"><b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">10&nbsp;</b><select disabled=\"disabled\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">&lsquo;Decoy&rsquo; items are products which the store expects customers to choose.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: FALSE</span>&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></p></div><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px 5px; border-top: 3px solid rgb(255, 165, 0); color: rgb(51, 51, 51); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; border-spacing: 0px; border-collapse: collapse; background-color: transparent;\"><tbody style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><tr style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: frozen ingredients</span> &nbsp;</div></td></tr><tr style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px; text-align: center;\"><img data-fr-image-pasted=\"true\" src=\"http://content.ieltsonlinetests.com/fileman/Uploads/Images/ielts/IP1/arrow-down.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"5\" height=\"19\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; border: 0px;\" class=\"fr-fic fr-dii\"></td></tr><tr style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px; text-align: center;\"><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 10px; border: 1px solid black;\">Baking bread in-store produces an aroma.</div></td></tr><tr style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px; text-align: center;\"><img data-fr-image-pasted=\"true\" src=\"http://content.ieltsonlinetests.com/fileman/Uploads/Images/ielts/IP1/arrow-down.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"5\" height=\"19\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; border: 0px;\" class=\"fr-fic fr-dii\"></td></tr><tr style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px; text-align: center;\"><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 10px; border: 1px solid black;\">Shoppers&rsquo; <b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">12&nbsp;</b><input type=\"text\" required=\"\" readonly=\"\" value=\"\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit;\"> are stimulated.<br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: appetites</span>&nbsp; &nbsp;</div></td></tr><tr style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px; text-align: center;\"><img data-fr-image-pasted=\"true\" src=\"http://content.ieltsonlinetests.com/fileman/Uploads/Images/ielts/IP1/arrow-down.png\" alt=\"\" width=\"5\" height=\"19\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; border: 0px;\" class=\"fr-fic fr-dii\"></td></tr><tr style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><td style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 0px; text-align: center;\"><div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; padding: 10px; border: 1px solid black;\">They are then keener to buy food, including bread and <b style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 700;\">13&nbsp;</b><input type=\"text\" required=\"\" readonly=\"\" value=\"\" style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font: inherit; color: inherit;\"><br style=\"box-sizing: border-box;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: bold; color: red;\">Answer: ready meals</span>&nbsp; &nbsp;</div></td></tr></tbody></table><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px;\">&nbsp;</p></div>",
    "answerLocation": "<div style=\"box-sizing: border-box; text-align: center; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><h3 style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-family: inherit; font-weight: 500; line-height: 1.1; color: inherit; margin-top: 20px; margin-bottom: 10px;   font-size: 20px;\">The way the brain buys</h3></div><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">Supermarkets take great care over the way the goods they sell are arranged. This is because they know a lot about how to persuade people to buy things.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">When yon enter a supermarket, it takes some time for the mind to get into a shopping mode. This is why the area immediately inside the entrance of a supermarket is known as the &lsquo;decompression zone&rsquo;. People need to slow down and take stock of the surroundings, even if they are regulars. Supermarkets do not expect to sell much here, so it tends to be used more for&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">promotion</span>. So the large items piled up here are designed to suggest that there are bargains further inside the store, and shoppers are not necessarily expected to buy them. Walmart, the world&rsquo;s biggest retailer, famously employs &lsquo;greeters&rsquo; at the entrance to its stores. A friendly welcome is said to cut shoplifting. It is harder to steal from nice people.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">Immediately to the left in many supermarkets is a &lsquo;chill zone&rsquo;, where customers can enjoy browsing magazines, books and DVDs. This is intended to tempt&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">unplanned purchases</span> and slow customers down. But people who just want to do their shopping quickly will keep walking ahead, and the first thing they come to is the fresh&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">fruit and vegetables</span> section. However, for shoppers, this makes no sense.&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">Fruit and vegetables can be easily damaged, so they should be bought at the end</span>, not the beginning, of a shopping trip. But psychology is at work here:<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">&nbsp;selecting these items makes people feel good, so they feel less guilty about reaching for less healthy food later on</span>.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">Shoppers already know that everyday items, like milk, arc invariably placed towards the back of a store to provide more opportunity to tempt customers to buy things which are not on their shopping list. This is why pharmacies are also generally at the back. But supermarkets know shoppers know this, so they use other tricks, like placing&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">popular items</span> halfway along a section so that people have to walk all along the aisle looking for them. The idea is to boost &lsquo;dwell time&rsquo;: the length of time people spend in a store.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">Having walked to the end of the fruit-and-vegetable aisle, shoppers arrive at counters of prepared food, the fishmonger, the butcher and the deli. Then there is the in-store bakery, which can be smelt before it is seen. Even small supermarkets now use in store bakeries. Mostly these bake pre-prepared items and&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">frozen ingredients</span> which have been delivered to the supermarket previously, and their numbers have increased, even though central bakeries that deliver to a number of stores are much more efficient. They do it for the smell of freshly baked bread, which arouses people&rsquo;s&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">appetites</span> and thus encourages them to purchase not just bread but also other food, including&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">ready meals</span>.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\">Retailers and producers talk a lot about the &lsquo;moment of truth&rsquo;. This is not a philosophical idea, but the point when people standing in the aisle decide to buy something and reach to get it. At the instant coffee section, for example, branded products from the big producers are arranged at eye level while cheaper ones are lower down, along with the supermarket&rsquo;s own label products.</p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">But shelf positioning is fiercely fought over, not just by those trying to sell goods, but also by those arguing over how best to manipulate shoppers. While many stores reckon eye level is the top spot, some think a little higher is better. Others think goods displayed at the end of aisles sell the most because they have the greatest visibility. To be on the right-hand side of an eye-level selection is often considered the very best place, because most people are right-handed and most people&rsquo;s eyes drift rightwards. Some supermarkets reserve that for their most expensive own-label goods.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">Scott Bearse, a retail expert with Deloitte Consulting in Boston, Massachusetts, has led projects observing and questioning tens of thousands of customers about how they feel about shopping.&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">People say they leave shops empty- handed more often because they are &lsquo;unable to decide&rsquo; than because prices are too high</span>, says Mr Bearse. Getting customers to try something is one of the best ways of getting them to buy, adds Mr Bearse. Deloitte found that customers who use fitting rooms in order to try on clothes buy the product they are considering at a rate of&nbsp;</span><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">8</span><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">j% compared with&nbsp;</span><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">58</span><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">% for those that do not do so.</span></p><p  style=\"box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px 0px 10px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-style: normal; font-variant-ligatures: normal; font-variant-caps: normal; font-weight: 400; letter-spacing: normal; orphans: 2; text-align: start; text-indent: 0px; text-transform: none; white-space: normal; widows: 2; word-spacing: 0px; -webkit-text-stroke-width: 0px; text-decoration-style: initial; text-decoration-color: initial;\"><span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; font-weight: 400;\">Often a customer struggling to decide which of two items is best ends up not buying either.&nbsp;<span style=\"box-sizing: border-box; background-color: rgb(255, 227, 21); color: rgb(34, 34, 34); border-bottom: 3px solid rgb(226, 181, 15); padding-right: 5px;\">In order to avoid a situation where a customer decides not to buy either product, a third &lsquo;decoy&rsquo; item, which is not quite as good as the other two, is placed beside them to make the choice easier and more pleasurable</span>. Happier customers are more likely to buy.</span></p>",
    "extra": ""
  }
]

Overall, there are seven stages in the process, beginning with the digging up of clay and culminating in delivery.<br><br>\n\nTo begin, the clay used to make the bricks is dug up from the ground by a large digger. This clay is then placed onto a metal grid, which is used to break up the clay into smaller pieces. A roller assists in this process.<br><br>\n\nFollowing this, sand and water are added to the clay, and this mixture is turned into bricks by either placing it into a mould or using a wire cutter. Next, these bricks are placed in an oven to dry for 24  48 hours.<br><br>\n\nIn the subsequent stage, the bricks go through a heating and cooling process. They are heated in a kiln at a moderate and then a high temperature (ranging from 200c to 1300c), followed by a cooling process in a chamber for 2  3 days. Finally, the bricks are packed and delivered to their destinations.<br><br>\n\n(<b>Words 173</b>)",
