    {
        "graph_cate": 6,
        "vocab": "<b>These charts show how there was a significant change</b><br><br>\n\nThis is a good start as it immediately identifies the key point  there was change. The These charts show how is a helpful model to borrow as if you use it you will be more able to change the wording of the title. You can keep some of the same words, you just need to use them differently.<br><br>\n\n<b>It is clear that there was a major shift from fathers being the sole breadwinner to more dual income families and single mothers.</b><br><br>\n\nThis is my summary statement. I prefer normally to put it right at the start. Note how I dont use any numbers here  thats a detail that comes later. Note also the word shift which is a useful variation of the word change I have already used.<br><br>\n\n<b>In 1976 a huge majority of families were financially supported either by the father or by both parents: 51% and 33% respectively</b><br><br>\n\nI do what I think is the simple thing and make my first topic paragraph about the the first chart in 1976. I can then use my next paragraph to show what has changed. I start off with the big point and the big numbers. Again this is logical.<br><br>\n\n<b>None of the other categories of couples with no income, single fathers, single mothers and couples where the mother was the only earner accounted for more than 8%.</b><br><br>\n\nThis is a summary. I dont include all the detail but I do name all the categories. I also group information together. This is a really useful skill to learn as it helps you avoid repetition. If you go through each category one by one. you will almost certainly repeat yourself too much.<br><br>\n\n<b>This situation was quite different in 2014.</b><br><br>\n\nDont be afraid of the really short sentence from time to time. Here it works as it clearly shows the main point of the paragraph. Its also a useful tip to start off paragraphs with slightly shorter sentences.<br><br>\n\nBy that time, dual income families had become easily the largest category at 55%. It is also striking how the father being the sole earner had fallen dramatically to only 17%. Equally notable is how the proportion of lone mothers had doubled to 16%. The figures for couples with no income, single fathers and the the mother as the major breadwinner all rose but still only accounted for only 8% of the total.<br><br>\n\nNote how this is logical and organised. I start with the major changes and bigger numbers and work down to the smaller numbers.",
        "graph_id": 16,
        "answer": "These charts show how there was a significant change in the working status of parents in Canada between 1976 and 2014. It is clear that there was a major shift from fathers being the sole breadwinner to more dual income families and single mothers.<br><br>\n\nIn 1976 a huge majority of families were financially supported either by the father or by both parents: 51% and 33% respectively. None of the other categories of couples with no income, single fathers, single mothers and couples where the mother was the only earner accounted for more than 8%..<br><br>\n\nThis situation was quite different in 2014. By that time, dual income families had become easily the largest category at 55%. It is also striking how the father being the sole earner had fallen dramatically to only 17%. Equally notable is  how the proportion of lone mothers had doubled to 16%. The figures for couples with no income, single fathers and the mother as the major breadwinner all rose but still only accounted for only 8% of the total.",

        "es_category": 3,
        "vocab": "The writer in this IELTS sample essay introduces the topic in the introductory paragraph <b>(Alternative medicine...)</b> and puts forward a clear view on the issue <b>(I am unconvinced...and feel...).</b><br><br>\n\nThe essay has a well-balanced argument looking at both sides of the issue. The first body paragraph expresses some doubt about alternative therapies <b>(...little scientific research.. .only useful for long term...)</b>, but in the second body paragraph the writer takes a different view <b>(On the other hand...)</b> and examines the benefits <b>(...few side effects)</b>.<br><br>\n\nThe writer's concluding paragraph offers a strong opinion <b>(I strongly believe...)</b> and sums up the fact that both types of treatment are valid today.<br><br>\n\nThere is also a good range of grammatical structures <b>(If they were totally unhelpful, it would be...)</b>, and connectors <b>(despite the fact, in addition, finally)</b>.",
        "es_id": 1,
        "answer": "Alternative medicine is not new. It is accepted that it pre-dates conventional medicine and it is still used by many people all over the world. I am unconvinced that it is dangerous, and feel that both alternative and conventional medicine can be useful.<br><br>\n\nThere are several reasons why the conventional medical community is often dismissive of alternatives.  Firstly, there has been little scientific research into such medicine, so there is a scarcity of evidence to support the claims of their supporters. Furthermore, people often try such treatment because of recommendations from friends, and therefore come to the therapist with a very positive attitude, which may be part of the reason for the cure. Moreover, these therapies are usually only useful for long-term, chronic conditions. Acute medical problems, such as accidental injury, often require more conventional methods.<br><br>\n\nOn the other hand, there remain strong arguments for the use of alternatives.  Despite the lack of scientific proof, there is a lot of anecdotal evidence to suggest that these therapies work. In addition, far from being dangerous, they often have few or no side effects, so the worst outcome would be no change. One of the strongest arguments for the effectiveness of alternative therapies in the West is that, whilst conventional medicine is available without charge, many people are prepared to pay considerable sums for alternatives. If they were totally unhelpful, it would be surprising if this continued.<br><br>\n\nI strongly believe that conventional medicine and alternative therapies can and should coexist. They have different strengths, and can both be used effectively to target particular medical problems. The best situation would be for alternative therapies to be used to support and complement conventional medicine.<br><br>\n\n<b>(280 words)</b>",

This essay will discuss the reasons for this phenomenon and examine some of the possible effects it will have on society.<br><br>\n\nOne of the principal reasons for smaller family units is birth control. As a country develops and becomes richer, birth control becomes more readily available. This may be due to a rise in the number of medical clinics or the distribution of free contraception. The result of this is that people can choose family size. Another important factor is the rise in the levels of education that occur as a country develops, which means that women are more educated and more likely to be working. Consequently, many will want to delay having children and so will likely have fewer in the long-term. <br><br>\n\nThis can impact on society in a number of ways. While this can create problems, there are steps that can be taken to reduce the impacts.<br><br>\n\nThe main problem is that older people may find it more difficult to secure work, which arises because younger people are more likely to have up-to-date qualifications and experience. For example, information technology is integral to a variety of jobs these days and the skills needed for this are rapidly changing. Young people may well have recent knowledge through university or through using technology in their leisure time. If older people cannot secure work, this leads to other problems. As they are likely to have a family to support, they may not have an adequate income to provide for their childrens education or other such necessities.<br><br>\n\nIt is the government that needs to take measures to ameliorate such problems. This needs to begin with ensuring that older people have all the skills needed to compete in the job market, which could be achieved by providing free training on the most important job requirements at local community colleges, for example. In addition to this, the government needs to encourage employers to change their employment practices by promoting the value of experience that older workers can bring to a job.<br><br>\n\nTo conclude, the main issue with competition for work between these groups is that older people may start to find it more difficult to find work. The high divorce rates have meant many children have been brought up in one-parent families with no father to act as a role model which is detrimental to their development.  This is particularly important for boys, who without this guidance are easily led astray by bad influences such as drugs and crime.  Another factor is the <b>lack of things to do</b> for the young. For example, in the UK, many television programs about this issue have shown that teenagers hang around in the evenings with little to do. Airline companies, nowadays, have their own websites so that it can entice new customers to use their services. They also lowered the ticket prices by developing promotional fares which is beneficial for the customers. Another reason is convenience. People today can use the internet to search their preferred tourist destination. They can also view the best route to maximize the cost of travel and time. Electronic maps are also available in the internet.<br><br>\n\nThere are several benefits that a traveller can get through travelling. Initially, the traveller can eat some exotic foods and see new sights. The individual can also experience new culture and traditions. These new experiences can give the traveller new insights on life and the environment.<br><br>\n\nIn my own experience, visiting Thailand with my mother was such a wonderful experience. I was hesitant at first because I knew beforehand that ticket prices for that destination are pricey. I changed my mind when I saw the promotional fare of Cebu Pacific in their website. After we booked the flight, I then searched the internet for our hotel accomodations. We really enjoyed the trip when we visited some Buddhist temple.<br><br>\n\nTo sum it up, more people would like to travel because of its advantages. Furthermore, the trend will keep on increasing in the future.",

        "es_id": 22,
        "answer": "It is certainly true that the more people nowadays do not have a close relationship with their neighbours and that this has weakened communities in our cities. This is probably due to a combination of our more mobile society and the nature of new building developments and is a problem that will require better  planning policies.<br><br>\n\nOne main cause of this change is the trend for people to move home to find work. This mobility means that there is less chance for people to put down roots in a community and establish relationships with their neighbours. If, for example, a person moves city once every five years then it is most unlikely that they will form lasting relationships where they live.<br><br>\n\nAnother important factor is that when people move into a new area they often live in apartment blocks and not houses. This matters because these blocks do not have common social areas where people can meet each other in the same way as is possible in more traditional housing estates. It is possible for people who live in these new high rise buildings never to see each other, still less get to know each other well enough to form a bond.<br><br>\n\nAny solution to this problem will probably involve local government adopting planning policies that are focused on the community. While it is unlikely that anything can be done about social mobility, it is possible for local authorities to encourage a greater sense of community by ensuring new building developments have social spaces where people can meet each other regularly. These could include green spaces where children can play together, local markets and community halls.\n\nMy conclusion is that there may be nothing to be done about social mobility but it is possible for local government to foster a greater sense of community by ensuring new developments are more community friendly.",

        "answer": "Digital technology <b>has without question</b> changed the way we read and access books and this threatens the role of the public library. <b>My view is that while there is a good argument for saying  libraries are much less relevant nowadays, they still perform a vital function and should be be maintained.</b><br><br>\n\n<b>The advance of online reading technologies and services is one compelling argument in favour of limiting any funding public libraries </b>. It is now possible to not just buy almost any book you want online through stores such as Amazon, you are also able to borrow books for a small subscription fee from various sites. Indeed, these online services are generally much more comprehensive and reliable than any provided by a local library where you can often have to wait weeks for the book you want. <b>In these circumstances,</b> it is quite possible to argue that public libraries are out of date and have been largely overtaken by technology.<br><br>\n\n<b>Despite this, public libraries do still have some role to play and it would be a mistake to abolish them entirely. </b>One such role is lending books to children and encouraging children to acquire the reading habit books by having schemes that reward them for borrowing books on a regular basis. Many parents who are anxious about the amount of screen time their children have would much prefer to visit a library where they can more closely monitor the books their children are taking out. Another important role public libraries perform is stocking a wide range of reference books and more specialised books  that are typically not available via online services. While these services may be limited, they still matter and show that libraries still perform an important function.<br><br>\n\n<b>My conclusion is a mixed one.</b> On the one hand, I believe it is true that nearly all the function of libraries have been replaced by digital technology, but in some areas, namely childrens books and reference books, public libraries do have a role to play.",

        "vocab": "<b>Notes on essay structure and task response</b><br><br>\n\nLength<br><br>\n\nThis essay is perhaps a little long at 310 words  the third topic paragraph is included to give you more ideas. The essay would be complete without that paragraph<br><br>\n\nFocus on question<br><br>\n\nNote how each paragraph refers to young adults and computer games. Its important to do this to get task response right. An easy mistake to make is to talk about the dangers of computer games in general.<br><br>\n\nClear position<br><br>\n\nYou should see how I identify a clear position in the introduction (they are bad) and develop that through the whole essay. It is a good idea to be 100% clear about your position and use phrases such as My view is eg<br><br>\n\nMy view is this is a dangerous development for both society and the people concerned.<br><br>\n\nNote also that it is important to maintain that position throughout the essay. See how I reflect it in the opening sentences of the content paragraphs and the conclusion. This is one area where there is no problem in repeating words or ideas  you just want to vary them slightly as in<br><br>\n\nIn conclusion my own view is very clear.<br><br>\n\nIntroduction<br><br>\n\nThis is a short/light introduction. Two sentences can be enough. I clearly identify the topic of the question and establish my own position. An alternative approach would be to use 3 sentences to say:<br><br>\n\n1. This is happening.<br><br>\n\n2. I think its bad.<br><br>\n\n3. Im going to discuss why<br><br>\n\nContent paragraphs<br><br>\n\nNote how each content paragraph is about a different aspect of  the effect of computer games. I organise my ideas carefully. I develop that point in the other sentences with reasons and examples that relate to young adults.<br><br>\n\nConclusion<br><br>\n\nThe conclusion matches the introduction closely. This is a good idea. I identify my position in the introduction and say that it is a problem for both society and the individual. Note how I vary these words and dont just repeat them. Note too how I vary clear and apparent  two words that mean the same thing:<br><br>\n\nare clear<br><br>\n\nare equally apparent<br><br>\n\nThis is helps the examiner see that I am linking ideas together.<br><br>\n\nReasons and examples<br><br>\n\nIn each paragraph I use reasons and examples. Both content paragraphs 1/2 follow a PEE pattern  where I say something, explain it and give an example. You might note how I use evidence to provide examples. If youre looking for a more advanced way to use examples this works well, eg<br><br>\n\nThere is evidence that<br><br>\n\nIt has been shown that",
        "es_id": 24,
        "answer": "There can be little doubt that more and more people are becoming addicted to computer games and this is especially true for young adults. My view is this is a dangerous development for both society and the people concerned.<br><br>\n\nThe dangers to society of computer gaming addiction among young adults are clear. There is strong evidence to show that there is a connection between violent crime and playing games that do not respect human life. It has been shown for instance that while there is little harm in a few hours of recreational gaming a week, people who spend many hours a day at their gaming consoles are much more likely to commit crimes. This is particularly true of young men in their twenties and thirties who are typically the section of society who become most addicted to games.<br><br>\n\nThe problems that too much gaming can cause young adults as individuals are equally apparent. One particular problem is that they are at a stage of life when they need to concentrate on establishing relationships and perhaps starting families. Again there is evidence to show that people who play too many games find it more difficult to build a lasting relationship and if they do, they provide a poor example to their children.<br><br>\n\nAnother set of problems that gaming addiction can cause in this age bracket is at work. This is because too much gaming can cause loss of concentration and that in turn can lead to reduced efficiency in the workplace. This is of course a problem for the company and may also lead to the individual failing to get promotion or even being fired.<br><br>\n\nIn conclusion my own view is very clear.         "es_id": 25,
        "answer": "It is, of course, important for people to earn a sufficiently high salary to support their lifestyle. This does not mean, however, that the salary is the only point to be taken into consideration when choosing a job. Indeed, I would argue that there are a number of other factors that are equally significant.<br><br>\n\nThe first point to consider is why it may be a mistake to place too much emphasis on the salary. One reason why this is so is that you may select a job that is well-paid but ultimately unsatisfying. In this case, you may spend 8 hours a day being unhappy. Something else to be taken into account is that highly-paid jobs tend to be stressful and involve long working hours. For instance, many doctors have a 60 hour working week and they often suffer from burn-out early in their careers and wish they had chosen a less stressful profession.<br><br>\n\nThe other point to be taken into account is how other factors may matter more than the salary when deciding on a job. Indeed, most people would accept that the work environment is key to job satisfaction. If you are working alongside people you like and the atmosphere in the office is positive, you are much more likely to be satisfied in your work. Likewise, it is also critical that you actually enjoy what you do. For example, someone who is artistic is much more likely to be happy working for a low salary teaching art than earning a fortune as a merchant banker.<br><br>\n\nIn conclusion, I would say that the salary should be only one consideration in choosing a job and that other factors such as job satisfaction and work environment are just as important.",

But here is one possible way of structuring the answer to produce a band 9 essay:<br><br>\n\n<b>Introduction:</b> simply rephrase the topic and say what this essay is about. When your essay question asks you about reasons/consequences or causes/solutions, you shouldnt try to describe all that in your introduction. Instead, state that youll describe them later in your essay.<br><br>\n\n<b>Body paragraphs:</b><br><br>\n\nparagraph 1: main reasons of immigration<br>\nparagraph 2: main consequences of immigration<br><br>\n\n<b>Conclusion:</b> sum up the ideas from body paragraphs and briefly give your opinion.",
        "es_id": 26,
        "answer": "Immigration has a significant impact on the contemporary society. Each year, more and more people from all over the world decide to leave their home countries and move to another place. This essay will examine the reasons and the consequences of immigration.<br><br>\n\nIn my view, the main reason of immigration is a strong desire of better life quality and safe future. A lot of people from so-called Third World move to developed countries in search of better employment opportunities, and therefore, higher incomes. Moreover, living in a wealthy country implies living in a country with stable economy, so risks of losing their savings also lessen. For example, labour migration from Mexico to the USA is caused by these facts. Other reasons that force whole families to cross borders are wars and various cultural conflicts in their homeland. Many people migrate, seeking security and safe future for their children. For instance, most of the refugees who arrived in the European Union were escaping from wars.<br><br>\n\nHowever, sometimes immigration causes more problems than it solves, resulting in negative consequences for both immigrants and their countries of destination. First of all, most of the refugees cant find jobs because of the lack of language skills and difficulties in adaptation. Thats why the countries have to run various refugee assistance programs to help those people. But disproportionate burden of maintaining the immigrants leads to tension in the society. Secondly, not all of the refugees receive proper asylum, food and medical care. So they are at risk even after crossing the border. Finally, even highly qualified specialists, who seek better employment, often dont get what they are looking for.<br><br>\n\nIn conclusion, I think that people immigrate to have better life prospects. However, life after immigration may not always meet peoples expectations. So its very important to consider all the possible outcomes and decide whether leaving your homeland is worth it.<br><br>\n\n<b>(315 words)</b>\n",

    {
        "es_category": 4,
        "vocab": "Agree or disagree question asks you to clearly determine whether you agree or disagree with the statement. Unlike questions that ask you to what extent do you agree or disagree, this question asks you to have a super-clear opinion. After youve decided your opinion, generate 2-3 supporting points for it.<br><br>\n\nFor the task above you have two possible options:<br><br>\n\nYou fully agree that big salary is more important than job satisfaction<br>\nYou completely disagree that big salary is more important than job satisfaction<br><br>\n\n Now lets generate supporting points for each of the opinions:<br><br>\n\n<b>Big salary is more important</b><br><br>\n\nHaving a job with a high salary makes people feel satisfied no matter what kind of job they do<br>\nMoney is essential for survival and good living<br><br>\n\n<b>Job satisfaction is more important</b><br><br>\n\nJob satisfaction gives you a sense of fulfillment<br>\nDoing what you like keeps you motivated and therefore leads to a career growth<br>\nMoney cant buy happiness and its more pleasant to pursue what youre interested in<br><br>\n\nAfter youve decided whether you agree or disagree and generated your supporting points, its time to start writing your essay.<br><br>\n\nThere are a lot of ways to structure your essay, but well use a structure that has been approved by many IELTS examiners to be high-scoring and coherent.<br><br>\n\n<b>Band-9 essay structure:</b><br><br>\n\nIntroduction<br>\nBody paragraph 1 - the 1st reason you agree/disagree<br>\nBody paragraph 2 - the 2nd reason you agree/disagree<br>\nConclusion",
        "es_id": 27,
        "answer": "It is often argued that it is more advantageous to choose a job with high wage, even if it doesn't appeal to you at all. I completely disagree with this opinion and think that job satisfaction is much more important than salary.<br><br>\n\nFirst of all, I believe that job satisfaction gives people a sense of fulfillment that no money can guarantee. Even if someone is earning a high salary, but feels tensed and compromises with his conscience, this person wont enjoy his life. While pursuing ones interests will always bring pleasure and feeling of satisfaction. For example, a lot of famous researchers made their career choices not because of appealing wages, but because they were passionate about science. Thats why its more important to choose the kind of work that makes you happy than to look only at a high salary.<br><br>\n\nSecondly, doing what you like keeps you motivated and therefore leads to a career growth. In other words, there is a strong relation between job satisfaction and productivity. People who love their jobs can easily excel in their fields of work and achieve better results than those, who put salary on the first place. For instance, Henry Miller decided to leave his everyday job despite a good wage and ventured to become a writer. And after enduring years of ups and downs he became one of the most famous and well-paid authors of the twentieth century. Thus, advantages of jobs that keep you satisfied outweigh the drawback of a low salary in a long-term perspective.<br><br>\n\nTo conclude, I strongly believe that job satisfaction is more beneficial than high salary because it makes people happy and motivated.<br><br>\n\n<b>(277 words)</b>",

File: app/src/main/assets/ielts_test/tenses/present_tense/Simplepresenttense.html
----------------------------------------
<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html;charset=utf-8" />
<link href="file:///android_asset/style.css" type="text/css" rel="stylesheet">
</head>
<body>


<p ><font color="purple"><i>How do we make the Simple Present Tense?</i></font></p>
<table border="1"  cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" >
<tr>
<th  >subject</th>
<th  >+</th>
<th  >auxillary verb</th>
<th  >+</th>
<th  >main verb</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td  ></td>
<td  ></td>
<td  >do</td>
<td  >-</td>
<td  >base</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>There are three important <b>exceptions</b>:</p>
<p>1. For positive sentences, <b>we do not normally use the auxiliary</b>. </p>
<p>2. For the 3rd person singular (he, she, it), we add s to the main verb or <b>es</b> to the auxiliary. </p>
<p>3. For the verb <b>to be</b>, we do not use an auxiliary, even for questions and negatives.</p>
<p>Look at these examples with the main verb like:</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
<th></th>
<th >subject</th>
<th >auxillary verb</th>
<th></th>
<th >main verb</th>
<th></th>
</tr>
<tr> 
<td rowspan="2" >+</td>
<td >I, you, we, they</td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td >like</td>
<td >coffee.</td>
</tr>
<tr> 
<td >He, she, it</td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td >likes</td>
<td >coffee.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="2" >-</td>
<td >I, you, we, they</td>
<td >do</td>
<td >not</td>
<td >like</td>
<td >coffee.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >He, she, it</td>
<td >does</td>
<td >not</td>
<td >like</td>
<td >coffee.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="2" >?</td>
<td >Do</td>
<td >I, you, we, they</td>
<td></td>
<td >like</td>
<td >coffee?</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >Does</td>
<td >he, she, it</td>
<td></td>
<td >like</td>
<td >coffee?</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>Look at these examples with the main verb be. Notice that there is no auxiliary:</p>
<table border="1"  cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
<th></th>
<th>subject</th>
<th >main verb</th>
<th></th>
<th></th>
</tr>
<tr> 
<td rowspan="3" >+</td>
<td >I</td>
<td >am</td>
<td></td>
<td >French</td>
</tr>
<tr> 
<td >You, we, they</td>
<td >are</td>
<td></td>
<td >French</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >He, she, it</td>
<td >is</td>
<td></td>
<td >French</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="3" >-</td>
<td >I</td>
<td >am</td>
<td >not</td>
<td >old</td>
</tr>
<tr> 
<td >You, we, they</td>
<td >are</td>
<td >not</td>
<td >old</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >He, she, it</td>
<td >is</td>
<td >not</td>
<td >old</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="3" >?</td>
<td >Am</td>
<td >I</td>
<td></td>
<td >late?</td>
</tr>
<tr> 
<td >Are</td>
<td >you, we, they</td>
<td></td>
<td >late?</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td  >Is</td>
<td >he, she, it</td>
<td></td>
<td >late?</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p><font color="purple"><i>How do we use the Simple Present Tense?</i></font></p>
<p>We use the simple present tense when:</p>
<li>the action is general </li>
<li>the action happens all the time, or habitually, in the past, present and future </li>
<li>the action is not only happening now </li>
<li>the statement is always true </li>
<table border="1"  cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"  >
<tr>
<td colspan="3" >John drives a taxi.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td ><b>past</b></td>
<td ><b>present</b></td>
<td ><b>future</b></td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td colspan="3" >It is John's job to drive a taxi. He does it every day. Past, present and future</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>Look at these examples:</p>
<li>I live in New York. </li>
<li>The Moon goes round the Earth. </li>
<li>John drives a taxi. </li>
<li>He does not drive a bus. </li>
<li>We do not work at night. </li>
<li>Do you play football? </li>
<p>Note that with the verb <b>to be</b>, we can also use the simple present tense for situations that are not general. We can use the simple present tense to talk about <b>now</b>. Look at these examples of the verb "to be" in the simple present tensesome of them are <b>general</b>, some of them are <b>now</b>:</p>
<table border="1"  cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" >
<tr >
<tdcolspan="3" >Am I right?
<br >Tara is not at home.</br>
<br>You are happy.</br></td>
</tr>
<tr >
<td ><b>past</b></p>
<td ><b>present</b></p>
<td ><b>future</b></p>
</tr>

<tr >
<td colspan="3" >The situation is now.</td>
</tr>
</table>
</br>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" >
<tr>
<td colspan="3" >I am not fat.
<br>Why are you so beautiful?</br>
<br>Ram is tall.</br></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td ><b>past</b></p>
<td ><b>present</b></p>
<td ><b>future</b></p>
</tr>

<tr>
<td colspan="3" >The situation is general. Past, present and future.</td>
</tr>
</table>
<br><br><br>
</body>
</html>

</head>
<body>
<p><i><b>I have been singing</b></i></p>
<p><i><font color="purple">How do we make the Present Perfect Continuous Tense?</font></i></p>
<p>The structure of the present perfect continuous tense is:</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
<th  >subject</th>
<th >+</th>
<th >auxillary verb</th>
<th >+</th>
<th >auxillary verb</th>
<th>+</th>
<th >main verb</th>
<th></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td >have<br>has</br></td>
<td></td>
<td >been</td>
<td></td>
<td >base+ing</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>Here are some examples of the present perfect continuous tense:</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
<th></th>
<th >subject</th>
<th  >auxillary verb</th>
<th></th>
<th >auxillary verb</th>

<th  >main verb</th>
<th></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >+</td>
<td >I</td>
<td >have</td>
<td></td>
<td >been</td>
<td >waiting</td>
<td >for one hour.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td bgcolor="Wheat">+</td>
<td bgcolor="Wheat">You</td>
<td bgcolor="Wheat">have</td>
<td></td>
<td bgcolor="Wheat">been</td>
<td bgcolor="Wheat">talking</td>
<td bgcolor="Wheat">too much.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td></td>
<td >It</td>
<td >has</td>
<td >not</td>
<td >been</td>
<td >raining.</td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td></td>
<td >We</td>
<td >have</td>
<td >not</td>
<td >been</td>
<td >playing</td>
<td >fotball.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >?</td>
<td >Have</td>
<td >you</td>
<td style="text-align:center"style="text-align:center" bgcolor="Wheat">.</td>
<td >been</td>
<td >seeing</td>
<td >her?</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >?</td>
<td >Have</td>
<td >they</td>
<td></td>
<td >been</td>
<td >doing</td>
<td >their homework?</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p><font color="purple">Contractions</font></p>
<p>When we use the present perfect continuous tense in speaking, we often contract the subject and the first auxiliary. We also sometimes do this in informal writing.</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
<th >I have been</th>
<th >I've been</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >You have been</td>
<td >You've been</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >
He has been
<br>She has been</br>
<br>It has been</br>
<br>John has been</br>
<br>The car has been</br>
</td>
<td >
He's been
<br>She's been</br>
<br>It's been</br>
<br>John's been</br>
<br>The car's been</br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >We have been</td>
<td > we've been</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >They have been</td>
<td >They've been</td>
</tr>
</table>
<br>Here are some examples:</br>
<li>I've been reading. </li>
<li>The car's been giving trouble. </li>
<li>We've been playing tennis for two hours. </li>
<br><i><font color="purple">How do we use the Present Perfect Continuous Tense?</font></i></br>
<p>This tense is called the <b>present</b> perfect continuous tense. There is usually a connection with the<b> present </b>or now. There are basically two uses for the present perfect continuous tense:</p>
<br><br><br>

File: app/src/main/assets/ielts_test/tenses/present_tense/Presentcontinuous.html
----------------------------------------
<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html;charset=utf-8" />
<link href="file:///android_asset/style.css" type="text/css" rel="stylesheet">
</head>

<body>
<p><b><i>I am singing</i></b></p>

<p>We often use the present continuous tense in English. It is very different from the simple present tense, both in structure and in use.</p>
<p><font color="purple">How do we make the Present Continuous Tense?</font></p>
<p>The structure of the present continuous tense is:</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" >
<tr>
  <th >subject</th>
  <th >+</th>
  <th >auxiliary verb</th>
<th >+</th>

<th >main verb</th>
</tr>

<tr>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td >be</td>
<td></td>
<td >base + ing</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>Look at these examples:</p>

<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" >
  <tr>
<th></th>
<th >subject</th>
<th >auxiliary verb</th>
<th></th>
<th >main verb</th>
<th></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >+</td>
<td >I</td>
<td >am</td>
<td></td>
<td >speaking</td>
<td >to you.</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td >+</td>
<td >You</td>
<td >are</td>
<td></td>
<td >reading</td>
<td >this</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td >-</td>
<td >She</td>
<td >is</td>
<td >not</td>
<td >staying</td>
<td >in London.</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td >-</td>
<td >We</td>
<td >are</td>
<td >not</td>
<td >playing</td>
<td >football.</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td >?</td>
<td >Is</td>
<td >he</td>
<td></td>
<td >watching</td>
<td >TV?</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td >?</td>
<td >Are</td>
<td >they</td>
<td></td>
<td >waiting</td>
<td >for John?</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p><font color="purple">How do we use the Present Continuous Tense?</font></p>
<p>We use the present continuous tense to talk about:</p>
<li>action happening now </li>
<li>action in the future </li>
<p><font color="purple"><i>Present continuous tense for action happening now</i></font></p>

<p>a) for action happening <b>exactly now</b></p>

<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"   style="width:90%;">
<tr>
<td  colspan="3">I am eating my lunch.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td ><b>past<b></td>
<td ><b>present</b></td>
<td ><b>future</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td></td>
<td >The action is happening now.</td>
<td></td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>Look at these examples. Right now you are looking at this screen and at the same time...</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" >
<tr>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >...the pages are turning.</td>
<td >...the candle is burning.</td>
<td >...the numbers are spinning.</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>b) for action happening <b>around now</b></p>
<p>The action may not be happening exactly now, but it is happening just before and just after now, and it is not permanent or habitual.</p>
<p>Look at these examples:</p>
<li>Muriel<b> is learning</b> to drive. </li>
<li>I<b> am living </b>with my sister until I find an apartment.</li>
<p><font color="purple"><i>Present continuous tense for the future</i></font></p>
<p>We can also use the present continuous tense to talk about the <b>future</b>if we add a<b> future word</b>!! We must add (or understand from the context) a future word. "Future words" include, for example, <b>tomorrow, next year, in June, at Christmas </b>etc. We only use the present continuous tense to talk about the future when we have planned to do something before we speak. We have already <b>made a decision and a plan</b> before speaking.</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" >
<tr>
<th  colspan="3">I am taking my exam next month.</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td ><b>past<b></td><td ><b>present</b></td><td ><b>future</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td  bgcolor="Wheat">.</td><td >!!!</td><td></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td></td><td >A firm plan or programme exists now.</td><td >The action is in the future.</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>Look at these examples:</p>
<li>We<b>'re eating</b> in a restaurant tonight. We've already booked the table.. </li>
<li>They can play tennis with you tomorrow. They<b>'re</b> not <b>working.</b> </li>
<li>When <b>are</b> you <b>starting</b> your new job? </li>
<p>In these examples, we have<b> a firm plan or programme before speaking</b>. The decision and plan were made<b> before</b> speaking.</p>
<p><font color="purple">How do we spell the Present Continuous Tense?</font></p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"   style="width:90%;">
<tr>
<th style="text-align:center" rowspan="6"   >Basic rule</th>

<th colspan="3" style="text-align:center" >Just add -ing to the base verb:</th></tr>
<tr><td >work</td>
<td >></td>
<td >working</td></tr>
<tr><td >play</td>
<td >></td>
<td >playing</td>
</tr>
<tr><td >assist</td>
<td >></td>
<td >assisting</td></tr>
<tr><td >see</td>
<td >></td>
<td >seeing</td></tr>
<tr><td >be</td>
<td >></td>
<td >being</td></tr>
<tr>
<th style="text-align:center" rowspan="6"  >Exception1</th>
<td colspan="3" style="text-align:center" >If the base verb ends in<b> consonant</b> + <b>stressed vowel</b> + <b>consonant</b>, double the last letter:

<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0"  >
<tr>
<th  >s</th>
<th >t</th>
<th >o</th>
<th >p</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td></td>
<td >consonant</td>
<td >stressedvowel</td>
<td >consonant</td>
</tr>
</table>

(vowels = a, e, i, o, u)</td>
</tr>


<tr>
<td >stop</td>
<td >></td>
<td >stopping</td>
</tr>


<tr>
<td >run</td>
<td >></td>
<td >running</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >begin</td>
<td >></td>
<td >beginning</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="3" style="text-align:center">Note that this exception does <b>not</b> apply when the last syllable of the base verb is not stressed:</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >open</td>
<td > ></td>
<td >opening</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<th style="text-align:center" rowspan="3"   >Exception2</th>

<td colspan="3" style="text-align:center" >If the base verb ends in <b>ie</b>, change the <b>ie</b> to<b> y</b>:
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td >lie</td>
<td >></td>
<td >lying</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >die</td>
<td >></td>
<td >dying</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<th style="text-align:center" rowspan="6"   >Exception3</th>

<td colspan="3" style="text-align:center" >If the base verb ends in<b> vowel</b> + <b>consonant</b> + e, omit the <b>e</b>:</td></tr>
<tr>
<td >come</td>
<td >></td>
<td >coming</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >mistake</td>
<td >></td>
<td >mistaking</td>
</tr>
</table>
<br><br><br>
</body>
</html>

========================================

File: app/src/main/assets/ielts_test/tenses/present_tense/Presentperfecttense.html
----------------------------------------
<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html;charset=utf-8" />
<link href="file:///android_asset/style.css" type="text/css" rel="stylesheet">
</head>
<body>
<b><i>I have sung</i></b><br>
<br>The present perfect tense is a rather important tense in English, but it gives speakers of some languages a difficult time. That is because it uses concepts or ideas that do not exist in those languages. In fact, the <b> structure</b> of the present perfect tense is very simple. The problems come with the<b>use</b> of the tense. In addition, there are some differences in usage between British and American English.</br>
<br><font color="purple">How do we make the Present Perfect Tense?</font></br>
<br>The structure of the present perfect tense is:</br>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
  <th >subject</th>
  <th >+</th>
  <th >auxiliary verb </th>
<th >+</th>
  <th >main verb </th>

</tr>

<tr>
<td ></td>
<td ></td>
<td >have</td>
<td ></td>
<td >past participle</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>Here are some examples of the present perfect tense:</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
  <tr>
<th ></th>
<th >subject</th>
<th >auxiliary verb</th>
<th ></th>

<th >main verb</th>
<th ></th>

</tr>
<tr>
<td >+</td>
<td >I</td>
<td >have</td>
<td ></td>
<td >seen</td>
<td >ET.</td>

</tr>

<tr>
<td >+</td>
<td >You</td>
<td >have</td>
<td ></td>
<td >eaten</td>
<td >mine</td>

</tr>

<tr>
<td ></td>
<td >She</td>
<td >has</td>
<td >not</td>
<td >been</td>
<td >to Rome</td>

</tr>

<tr>
<td ></td>
<td >We</td>
<td >have</td>
<td >not</td>
<td >played</td>
<td >football</td>

</tr>

<tr>
<td >?</td>
<td >Have</td>
<td >you</td>
<td ></td>
<td >finished?</td>
<td ></td>

</tr>

<tr>
<td >?</td>
<td >Have</td>
<td >they</td>
<td ></td>
<td >done</td>

<td >it?</td>
</tr>
</table>
<br><font color="purple">Contractions with the present perfect tense</font></br>
<br>When we use the present perfect tense in speaking, we usually contract the subject and auxiliary verb. We also sometimes do this when we write.</br>
<br><b>He's</b> or <b>he's</b>??? Be careful! The 's contraction is used for the auxiliary verbs have and be. For example, "It's eaten" can mean: </br>
<li>It<b> has</b>eaten. [present perfect tense, active voice] </li>
<li>It <b>is</b> eaten. [present tense, passive voice] </li>
<br>It is usually clear from the context.</br>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
  <tr>
<th >I have</th>
<th >I've</th>

</tr>
<tr>
<td >You have</td>
<td >You've</td>

</tr>

<tr>

<td ><br>He has</br>
<br>She has</br>
<br>It has</br>
<br>John has</br>
<br>The car has</br></td>

<td ><br>He's</br>
<br>She's</br>
<br>It's</br>
<br>John's</br>
<br>The car's</br></td>

</tr>
<tr>
<td >We have</td>
<td >We've</td>

</tr>
<tr>
<td >They have</td>
<td >They've</td>
</tr>
</table>
<br>Here are some examples:</br>
<li>I've finished my work. </li>
<li>John's seen ET. </li>
<li>They've gone home. </li>
<br><font color="purple">How do we use the Present Perfect Tense?</font></br>
<br>This tense is called the <b>present</b> perfect tense. There is always a connection with the past and with the <b>present</b>. There are basically three uses for the present perfect tense:</br>
<OL>
<LI> experience 
<LI> change 
<LI> continuing situation 
</OL>
<br><br><br>
</body>
</html>



========================================

<head>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html;charset=utf-8" />

</head>
<body>
<p><b><i>I will have been singing</i></b></p>
<p><font color="purple"><i>How do we make the Future Perfect Continuous Tense?</i></font></p>
<p>The Structure of the future perfect continous tense is:</p>
< able border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
<th >subject</th>
<th >+</th>
<th >auxillary verb
<br> WILL</br></th>
<th >+</th>
<th >auxillary verb
<br>HAVE</br></th>
<th >+</th>
<th >auxillary verb
<br>BE</br></th>
<th >+</th>
<th >main verb</th>
</tr>

<tr>
<td style="text-align:center"rowspan="2" colspan="2" bgcolor="Wheat"></td>
<td >invariable</td>
<td style="text-align:center"rowspan="2" bgcolor="Wheat"></td>
<td >invariable</td>
<td style="text-align:center"rowspan="2" bgcolor="Wheat"></td>
<td >past participle</td>
<td style="text-align:center"rowspan="2" bgcolor="Wheat"></td>
<td ></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >will</td>
<td >have</td>
<td >been</td>
<td >base+ing</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>For negative sentences in the future perfect continuous tense, we insert <b>not</b> between <b>will</b> and <b>have</b>. For question sentences, we exchange the<b> subject</b> and <b>will</b>. Look at these example sentences with the future perfect continuous tense:</p>
< able border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
<th ></th>
<th >subject</th>
<th >auxillary verb</th>
<th ></th>
<th >auxillary verb</th>
<th >auxillary verb</th>
<th >main verb</th>
<th ></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >+</td>
<td >I</td>
<td >will</td>
<td ></td>
<td >have</td>
<td >been</td>
<td >working</td>
<td >for four hours.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >+</td>
<td >You</td>
<td >will</td>
<td ></td>
<td >have</td>
<td >been</td>
<td >travelling</td>
<td >for two days.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >-</td>
<td >She</td>
<td >will</td>
<td >not</td>
<td >have</td>
<td >been</td>
<td >using</td>
<td >the car.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >-</td>
<td >We</td>
<td >will</td>
<td >not</td>
<td >have</td>
<td >been</td>
<td >waiting</td>
<td >long.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >?</td>
<td >Will</td>
<td >you</td>
<td ></td>
<td >have</td>
<td >been</td>
<td >playing</td>
<td >football?</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >?</td>
<td >Will</td>
<td >they</td>
<td ></td>
<td >have</td>
<td >been</td>
<td >watching</td>
<td >TV?</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>When we use the future perfect continuous tense in speaking, we often contract the subject and auxiliary verb:</p>
<table  border="1" >
<tr>
<th >I will</th>
<th >I'll</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >you will</td>
<td >you'll</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >he will<br>she will</br><br>it will</br></td>
<td >he'll<br>she'll</br><br>it'ill</br></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:center" bgcolor="Wheat">we will</td>
<td >we'll</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >they will</td>
<td >they'll</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>For negative sentences in the future perfect continuous tense, we contract with <b>won't</b>, like this:</p>
< able border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
<th >I will not</th>
<th >I won't</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >you will not</td>
<td >you won't</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >he will not<br>she will not</br><br>it will not</br></td>
<td >he won't<br>she won't</br><br>it won't</br></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >we will not</td>
<td >we won't</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >they will not</td>
<td >they won't</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p><i><font color="purple">How do we use the Future Perfect Continuous Tense?</font></i></p>
<p>We use the future perfect continuous tense to talk about a long action before some point in the future. Look at these examples:</p>
<li>I<b> will have been working</b> here for ten years next week.</li> 
<li>He will be tired when he arrives. He<b> will have been travelling</b> for 24 hours.</li>

File: app/src/main/assets/ielts_test/tenses/future_tense/Futurecontinuoustense.html

<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html;charset=utf-8" />
<link href="file:///android_asset/style.css" type="text/css" rel="stylesheet">
</head>

<body >
<p><b><i>I will be singing</i></b></p>

<p><font color="purple"><i>How do we make the Future Continuous Tense?</i></font></p>
<p>The structure of the future continuous tense is:</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" >
<tr>
  <th  >subject</th>
  <th  >+</th>
  <th  >auxiliary verb WILL</th>
<th >+</th>
  <th  >auxiliary verb BE</th>
  <th >+</th>
<th  colspan="2">main verb</th>
</tr>

<tr>
<td colspan="2" rowspan="2"></td>
<td >invariable</td>
<td  rowspan="2"></td>
<td >invariable</td>
<td rowspan="2"></td>
<td >present participle</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td >will</td>
<td  >be</td>
<td >base + ing</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>For negative sentences in the future continuous tense, we insert <b>not</b> between <b>will</b> and<b> be</b>. For question sentences, we exchange the<b> subject</b> and <b>will</b>. Look at these example sentences with the future continuous tense:</p>

<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
  <tr>
<th ></th>
<th >subject</th>
<th >auxiliary verb</th>
<th ></th>
<th >auxiliary verb</th>
<th >main verb</th>
<th ></th>

</tr>
<tr>
<td  >+</td>
<td  >I</td>
<td  >will</td>
<td  ></td>
<td  >be</td>
<td  >working</td>
<td  >at 10am.</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td  >+</td>
<td  >You</td>
<td  >will</td>
<td  ></td>
<td  >be</td>
<td  >lying</td>
<td  >on a beach tomorrow</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td  >-</td>
<td  >She</td>
<td  >will</td>
<td  >not</td>
<td  >be</td>
<td  >using</td>
<td  >the car.</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td  >-</td>
<td  >We</td>
<td  >will</td>
<td  >not</td>
<td  >be</td>
<td  >having</td>
<td  >dinner at home</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td  >?</td>
<td  >Will</td>
<td  >you</td>
<td  ></td>
<td  >be</td>
<td  >playing</td>
<td  >football?</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td  >?</td>
<td  >Will</td>
<td  >they</td>
<td  ></td>
<td  >be</td>
<td  >watching</td>
<td  >TV?</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>When we use the future continuous tense in speaking, we often contract the subject and will:</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" >
  <tr>
<th  >I will </th>
<th  >I'll </th>

</tr>
<tr>
<td  >you will </td>
<td  >you'll </td>

</tr>

<tr>
<td  ><br>he will </br>
<br>she will </br>
<br>it will </br></td>
<td  ><br>he'll </br>
<br>she'll </br>
<br>it'll </br></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td  >we will</td>
<td  >we'll</td>
<tr>
<td  >they will</td>
<td  >they'll </td>

</tr>
</table>
<p>For spoken negative sentences in the future continuous tense, we contract with<b> won't</b>, like this:</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
  <tr>
<th  >I will not </th>
<th  >I won't </th>

</tr>
<tr>
<td  >you will not </td>
<td  >you won't </td>

</tr>

<tr>
<td  ><br>he will not </br>
<br>she will not</br>
<br>it will not </br></td>
<td  ><br>he won't </br>
<br>she won't </br>
<br>it won't </br></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td  >we will not</td>
<td  >we won't</td>
<tr>
<td  >they will not</td>
<td  >they won't </td>

</tr>
</table>

<p>We sometimes use <b>shall</b>instead of <b>will</b>, especially for I and we.</p>
<p><b><i>How do we use the Future Continuous Tense?</i></b></p>
<p>The future continuous tense expresses action at a <b>particular moment</b> in the future. The action will start before that moment but it will not have finished at that moment. For example, tomorrow I will start work at 2pm and stop work at 6pm:<p>

<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" >
<tr>
<th  colspan="3">At 4pm tomorrow, I will be working.</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td ><b>past<b></td><td ><b>present</b></td><td ><b>future</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td  ></td>
<td  >4 pm</td>
<td  ></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td  ></td>
<td  ></td>
<td  >At 4pm, I will be in the middle of working.</td>
</tr>

</table>

<p>When we use the future continuous tense, our listener usually knows or understands what time we are talking about. Look at these examples:</p>

<li>I <b>will be playing</b> tennis at 10am tomorrow. </li>
<li>They <b>won't be watching</b> TV at 9pm tonight. </li>
<li>What <b>will</b> you <b>be doing</b> at 10pm tonight? </li>
<li>What<b> will</b> you <b>be doing</b> when I arrive? </li>
<li>She<b> will</b> not <b>be sleeping</b> when you telephone her. </li>
<li>We<b> 'll be having</b> dinner when the film starts. </li>
<li>Take your umbrella. It<b> will be raining </b>when you return. </li>
<br><br><br>

File: app/src/main/assets/ielts_test/tenses/future_tense/Simplefuturetense.html
----------------------------------------
<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html;charset=utf-8" />
<link href="file:///android_asset/style.css" type="text/css" rel="stylesheet">
</head>
<body>


<p><b><i>I will sing</i></b></p>
<p>The <b>simple future tense</b> is often called <b>will</b>, because we make the simple future tense with the modal auxiliary<b> will</b>.</p>
<p><font color="purple"><i>How do we make the Simple Future Tense?</i></font></p>
<p>The structure of the simple future tense is:</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
<th >subject</th>
<th >+</th>
<th >auxiliary verb WILL</th>
<th >+</th>
<th >main verb</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td rowspan="2" colspan="2"  ></td>
<td >invariable</td>
<td rowspan="2" ></td>
<td >base</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td ><b>will</b></td>
<td ><b>V1</b></td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>For negative sentences in the simple future tense, we insert <b>not</b> between the auxiliary verb and main verb. For question sentences, we exchange the <b>subject</b> and <b>auxiliary verb</b>. Look at these example sentences with the simple future tense:</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
<th ></th>
<th >subject</th>
<th >auxillary verb</th>
<th ></th>
<th >main verb</th>
<th ></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >+</td>
<td >I</td>
<td >will</td>
<td ></td>
<td >open</td>
<td >the door</td>.
</tr>
<tr>
<td >+</td>
<td >You</td>
<td >will</td>
<td ></td>
<td >finish</td>
<td >before me</td.
</tr>
<tr>
<td ></td>
<td >She</td>
<td >will</td>
<td >not</td>
<td >be</td>
<td >at school tomorrow</td.
</tr>
<tr>
<td ></td>
<td >We</td>
<td >will</td>
<td >not</td>
<td >leave</td>
<td >yet.</td.
</tr>
<tr>
<td >?</td>
<td >Will</td>
<td >you</td>
<td ></td>
<td >arrive</td>
<td >on time?</td.
</tr>
<tr>
<td >?</td>
<td >Will</td>
<td >they</td>
<td ></td>
<td >want</td>
<td >dinner?</td>.
</tr>
</table>
<p>When we use the simple future tense in speaking, we often contract the subject and auxiliary verb:</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
<th >I will</th>
<th >I'll</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >you will</td>
<td >you'll</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >he will
<br>she will</br>
<br>it will</br>
</td>
<td >he'll
<br>she'll</br>
<br>it'll</br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >we will</td>
<td >we'll</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >they will</td>
<td >they'll</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>For negative sentences in the simple future tense, we contract with <b>won't</b>, like this:</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
<th >I will not</th>
<th >I won't</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >you will not</td>
<td >you won't</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >he will not
<br>she will not</br>
<br>it will not</br>
</td>
<td >he won't
<br>she won't</br>
<br>it won't</br>
</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >we will not</td>
<td >we won't</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >they will not</td>
<td >they won't</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p><i><font color="purple">How do we use the Simple Future Tense?</font></i></p>
<p><font color="purple">No Plan</font></p>
<p>We use the simple future tense when there is no plan or decision to do something before we speak. We make the decision spontaneously at the time of speaking. Look at these examples:</p>
  <li>Hold on. <b>I'll </b>get a pen. </li>
  <li>We <b>will see</b>what we can do to help you.  </li>
 <li>Maybe we <b>'ll stay in</b>and<b>watch</b>television tonight. </li>
<p>In these examples, we had no firm plan before speaking. The decision is made<b> at the time of speaking</b>.</p>
<p>We often use the simple future tense with the verb <b>to think</b> before it:
<li>I <b>think</b> I'll go to the gym tomorrow. </li>
<li> I <b>think </b>I will have a holiday next year. </li>
<li> I don't <b>think </b>I'll buy that car. </li>
<p><font color="purple">Prediction</font></p>
<p>We often use the simple future tense to make a prediction about the future. Again, there is no firm plan. We are saying <b>what we think will happen</b>. Here are some examples:</p>
<li>It <b>will rain</b>  tomorrow. </li>
<li>People<b>won't go</b>to Jupiter before the 22nd century.   </li>
<li>Who do you think <b>will get</b>  the job </li>
<p><font color="purple">Be</font></p>
<p>When the main verb is <b>be</b>, we can use the simple future tense even if we have a firm plan or decision before speaking. Examples:</p>
<li> <b>I'll be</b>   in London tomorrow.  </li>
<li> I'm going shopping.<b> won't be</b>  very long.  </li>
<li> <b>Will </b> you<b>be</b>  at work tomorrow?   </li>
<br><br><br>
</body>
</html>

File: app/src/main/assets/ielts_test/tenses/future_tense/Futureperfecttense.html
----------------------------------------
<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html;charset=utf-8" />
<link href="file:///android_asset/style.css" type="text/css" rel="stylesheet">
</head>

<body>
<b><i>I will have sung</i></b><p>
The<b> future perfect tense</b> is quite an easy tense to understand and use. The future perfect tense talks about the<b> past in the future.</b></br>
</p><font color="purple">How do we make the Future Perfect Tense?</font>
<br>The structure of the future perfect tense is:</br>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
  <th >subject</th>
  <th >+</th>
  <th>auxiliary verb WILL</th>
<th>+</th>
  <th >auxiliary verb HAVE</th>
  <th>+</th>
<th >main verb</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td  colspan="2" rowspan="2">.</td>
<td >invariable</td>
<td  rowspan="2">.</td>
<td >invariable</td>
<td  rowspan="2">.</td>
<td >past participle</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >will</td>
<td >have</td>
<td >V3</td>
</tr>
</table>
<br>Look at these example sentences in the future perfect tense:</br>


<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
  <tr>
<th >.</th>
<th >subject</th>
<th >auxiliary verb</th>
<th>.</th>
<th>auxiliary verb</th>
<th >main verb</th>
<th >.</th>

</tr>
<tr>
<td >+</td>
<td >I</td>
<td >will</td>
<td >.</td>
<td >have</td>
<td >finished</td>
<td >by 10am.</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td >+</td>
<td >You</td>
<td >will</td>
<td >.</td>
<td >have</td>
<td >forgotten</td>
<td>me by then</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td >-</td>
<td >She</td>
<td >will</td>
<td>not</td>
<td >have</td>
<td>gone</td>
<td >to school.</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td>-</td>
<td >We</td>
<td >will</td>
<td >not</td>
<td>have</td>
<td >left</td>
<td >.</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td >?</td>
<td >Will</td>
<td >you</td>
<td >.</td>
<td >have</td>
<td >arrived?</td>
<td >.</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td >?</td>
<td >Will</td>
<td >they</td>
<td >.</td>
<td >have</td>
<td >received</td>
<td >it?</td>
</tr>
</table>
<br>In speaking with the future perfect tense, we often contract the<b> subject</b> and<b> will</b>. Sometimes, we contract the <b>subject</b>,<b> will</b> and<b> have</b> all together:</br>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
  <tr>
<th >I will have</th>
<th>I'll have</th>
<th >I'll've</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >you will have</td>
<td >you'll have</td>
<td >you'll've
</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td ><br>he will have</br>
<br>she will have</br>
<br>it will have</br></td>
<td ><br>he'll have</br>
<br>she'll have</br>
<br>it'll have</br></td>
<td ><br>he'll've</br>
<br>she'll've</br>
<br>it'll've</br></td>

<tr>
<td s>we will have</td>
<td >we'll have</td>
<td >we'll've</td>
</tr>
</tr>
<tr >
<td >they will have</td>
<td >they'll have</td>
<td >they'll've</td>
</tr>
</table>
<br> We sometimes use <b>shall </b>instead of <b>will,</b>especially for I and we.</br>
<br><font color="purple">How do we use the Future Perfect Tense?</font></br>
<br>The future perfect tense expresses action in the future <b>before</b> another action in the future. This is the<b> past in the future</b>. For example:<br>

<li>The train will leave the station at 9am. You will arrive at the station at 9.15am. When you arrive, the train <b>will have left</b>. </li></br>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
<th  colspan="3">The train will have left when you arrive.</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td ><b>past<b></td><td><b>present</b></td><td ><b>future</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >.</td><td >.</td><td s>Train leaves in future at 9am.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >9</td>
<td >.</td>
<td>9.15</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >.</td><td >.</td><td >You arrive in future at 9.15am.</td>
</tr>
</table>
<br>Look at some more examples:</br>

<li>You can call me at work at 8am. I <b>will have arrived</b> at the office by 8. </li>
<li>They will be tired when they arrive. They <b>will</b> not <b>have slept</b> for a long time. </li>
<li>"Mary won't be at home when you arrive."</br>"Really? Where <b>will</b> she<b>have gone</b>?"</li>

<br>You can sometimes think of the future perfect tense like the present perfect tense, but instead of your viewpoint being in the present, it is in the future:</br>

<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
	  <tr>
		<td  colspan="3"><b>present perfect tense<b></td>
		<td >.</td>
		<td colspan="3"><b>future perfect tense</b></td>
	  </tr>
	  <tr>
		<td >.</td>
		<td><br>have</br>
			<br>bone</br></td>
		<td >.</td>
	  <td >.</td>
	<td >.</td>
	<td >.</td>
<td ><br>will</br>
<br>have </br>
<br>done </br></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td  colspan="3">.</td>
<td >.</td>
<td  colspan="3">.</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td ><b>past</b></td>
<td ><b>now</b></td>
<td ><b>future</b></td>
<td >.</td>
<td ><b>past</b></td>
<td ><b>now</b></td>
<td ><b>future</b></td>
</tr>
</table>
<br><br><br>
</body>
</html>

<html>
<head>
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html;charset=utf-8" />
<link href="file:///android_asset/style.css" type="text/css" rel="stylesheet">
</head>
<body>
<p><font color="purple">How do we make the Simple Past Tense?</font></p>
To make the simple past tense, we use:
<li><b>past form</b> only</li><br>  &nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp; &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;or
<li>auxiliary <b>did + base form</b> </li>
<p>Here you can see examples of the<b> past form</b> and <b>base form </b>for irregular verbs and regular verbs:</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
<th></th>
<th ><b>V1</b>
<b><br>base</b></br></th>
<th ><b>V2</b>
<b><br>past</b></br></th>
<th >V3
<br>past participle</br></th>
<th></th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >regular verb</td>
<td ><b>work</b>
<b><br>explode</b></br>
<b>like</b></td>
<td ><b>worked</b>
<b><br>exploded</b></br>
<b>liked</b></td>
<td >worked
exploded
liked</td>
<td >The past form for all regular verbs ends in -ed.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >irregular verb</td>
<td ><b>go</b>
<b><br>see</b></br>
<b>sing</b></td>
<td ><b>went</b>
<b><br>saw</b></br>
<b>sang</b></td>
<td >gone
seen
sung</td>
<td >The past form for irregular verbs is variable. You need to learn it by heart.</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td  colspan="3">.</td>
<td >You do not need the past participle form to make the simple past tense. It is shown here for completeness only.</td>
<td></td>
</tr>
</table>
<p style="height: 74px; ">The structure for<b>positive</b> sentences in the simple past tense is:</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
<th >subject</th>
<th >+</th>
<th >main verb</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td >past</td>
</tr>
</table>

<p>The structure for<b> negative</b> sentences in the simple past tense is:</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
<th >subject</th>
<th >+</th>
<th >auxiliary verb</th>
<th >+</th>
<th >not</th>
<th >+</th>
<th >main verb</th>

</tr>
<tr>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td >did</td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td >base</td>
</tr>
</table>

<p>The structure for<b> question</b> sentences in the simple past tense is:</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>

<th >auxiliary verb</th>
<th >+</th>
<th >subject</th>
<th >+</th>

<th >main verb</th>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >did</td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td >base</td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>The auxiliary verb <b>did</b> is not conjugated. It is the same for all persons (I did, you did, he did etc). And the base form and past form do not change. Look at these examples with the main verbs <b>go</b> and<b> work</b>:</p>

<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
<th></th>
<th >subject</th>
<th >auxiliary verb</th>
<th></th>
<th >main verb</th>
<th></th>

</tr>
<tr>
<td >+</td>
<td >I</td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td >went</td>
<td >to school</td>

</tr>

<tr>
<td >+</td>
<td >You</td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td >worked</td>
<td >very hard</td>

</tr>

<tr>
<td></td>
<td >She</td>
<td >did</td>
<td >not</td>
<td >go</td>
<td >with me</td>

<tr>
<td></td>
<td >We</td>
<td >did</td>
<td >not</td>
<td >work</td>
<td >yesterday</td>

</tr>

<tr>
<td >?</td>
<td >Did</td>
<td >you</td>
<td></td>
<td >go</td>
<td >to London?</td>

</tr>

<tr>
<td >?</td>
<td >Did</td>
<td >they</td>
<td></td>
<td >work</td>
<td >at home?</td>

</tr>
</table>
<p><b>Exception!</b> The verb<b> to be</b> is different. We conjugate the verb to be (I was, you were, he/she/it was, we were, they were); and we do<b>not</b> use an auxiliary for negative and question sentences. To make a question, we exchange the subject and verb. Look at these examples:</p>

<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" >
  <tr>
<th></th>
<th ><b>subject</b></th>
<th ><b>main verb</b></th>
<th></th>

<th></th>


</tr>
<tr>
<td >+</td>
<td >I, he/she/it</td>
<td >was</td>
<td></td>
<td >here.</td>


</tr>

<tr>
<td >+</td>
<td >You, we, they</td>
<td >were</td>
<td></td>
<td >in London.</td>
</tr>

<tr>
<td ></td>
<td >I, he/she/it</td>
<td >was</td>
<td >not</td>
<td >there.</td>


</tr>

<tr>
<td></td>
<td >You, we, they</td>
<td >were</td>
<td >not</td>
<td >happy.</td>


</tr>

<tr>
<td >?</td>
<td >Was</td>
<td >I, he/she/it</td>
<td></td>
<td >right?</td>

</tr>

<tr>
<td >?</td>
<td >Were</td>
<td >you, we, they</td>
<td></td>
<td >late?</td>


</tr>
</table>
<p><font color="purple">How do we use the Simple Past Tense?</font></p>
<p>We use the simple past tense to talk about an action or a situationan eventin the past. The event can be <b>short</b> or<b> long</b>.</p>
<p>Here are some <b>short</b> events with the simple past tense:</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
<td  colspan="3"><br>The car exploded at 9.30am yesterday.</br>
<br>She went to the door.</br>
<br>We did not hear the telephone.</br>
<br>Did you see that car?</br></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td ><b>past</b></td>
<td ><b>present</b></td>
<td ><b>future</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
</tr>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >The action is in the past.</td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>Here are some<b> long</b> events with the simple past tense:</p>
<table border="1" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
<tr>
<td  colspan="3"><br>I lived in Bangkok for 10 years.</br>
<br>The Jurassic period lasted about 62 million years.</br>
<br>We did not sing at the concert.</br>
<br>Did you watch TV last night?</br></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td ><b>past</b></td>
<td ><b>present</b></td>
<td ><b>future</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td></td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
</tr>
</tr>
<tr>
<td >The action is in the past.</td>
<td></td>
<td></td>
</tr>
</table>
<p>Notice that it does not matter how long ago the event is: it can be a few minutes or seconds in the past, or millions of years in the past. Also it does not matter how long the event is. It can be a few milliseconds (car explosion) or millions of years (Jurassic period). We use the simple past tense when:</p>
<li>the event is <b>in the past</b> </li>
<li>the event is <b>completely finished</b> </li>
<li>we say (or understand) the<b> time</b> and/or<b> place</b> of the event </li>
<p>In general, if we say the<b> time</b> or<b> place</b> of the event, we must use the simple past tense; we cannot use the present perfect.<p>
<p>Here are some more examples:<p>
<li>I <b>lived</b> in that house when I was young. </li>
<li>He <b>did</b>n't <b>like</b> the movie. </li>
<li>What <b>did</b> you<b> eat</b> for dinner? </li>
<li>John <b>drove</b> to London on Monday. </li>
<li>Mary did not go to work yesterday. </li>
<li><b>Did</b> you <b>play</b> tennis last week? </li>
<li>I <b>was</b> at work yesterday. </li>
<li>We <b>were</b> not late (for the train). </li>
<li><b>Were</b> you angry? </li>
<p>Note that when we tell a story, we usually use the simple past tense. We may use the past continuous tense to "set the scene", but we almost always use the simple past tense for the action. Look at this example of the beginning of a story:
"The wind was howling around the hotel and the rain was pouring down. It <b>was</b> cold. The door<b> opened</b> and James Bond <b>entered</b>. He <b> took off</b> his coat, which was very wet, and<b> ordered </b>a drink at the bar. He<b> sat down</b> in the corner of the lounge and quietly<b> drank</b> his..."</p>
<p>This page shows the use of the simple past tense to talk about past events. But note that there are some other uses for the simple past tense, for example in conditional or <b>if</b> sentences.</p>
<br><br><br>
</body>
</html>
