    {
        "content": "<p>IELTS Speaking Band 7 is the target for many of my students.</p> <p>But why is it so difficult to get a 7.0 score in IELTS Speaking when your other module scores are higher?</p> <p>One reason is that speaking is very much a skill, rather than a set of knowledge, so it takes longer to acquire. The best way to improve is with continual practice, ideally with feedback from a teacher.</p> <p>Lack of understanding of the assessment criteria also causes IELTS students to focus on the wrong things. For example, they may worry about tiny features of pronunciation and trying to sound like a native speaker. These efforts can make a difference, but pronunciation is only 25% of your score in IELTS Speaking.</p> <p>And what percentage of the IELTS Speaking score is based on having an interesting life story and knowing the solutions to all the world&rsquo;s problems? 0%!</p> <p>  </p>\n<p>IELTS Speaking Tip 1: Keep talking</p> <p>According to the assessment criteria, an IELTS Band 7 candidate:</p> <p>Speaks at length without noticeable effort or loss of coherence</p>\n<p>In IELTS Speaking, your score goes up when you say more, even if that results in more errors. That&rsquo;s because IELTS is a test of what you CAN do, not what you can&rsquo;t. So say as much as you can in response to the question, until you run out of ideas or start repeating yourself. It&rsquo;s not a bad thing if the examiner has to interrupt you.</p> <p>IELTS Speaking Tip 2: Use an idiom or two</p> <p>According to the assessment criteria, an IELTS Band 7 candidate:</p> <p>Uses some less common and idiomatic vocabulary and shows some awareness of style and collocation</p>\n<p>The IELTS examiner is listening for evidence that you can go beyond &lsquo;textbook English&rsquo; and start using real, idiomatic English. So impress the examiner by including a few idiomatic phrases like &ldquo;I&rsquo;m a bundle of nerves&rdquo; to mean &ldquo;I&rsquo;m nervous&rdquo;.</p> <p>IELTS Speaking Tip 3: Paraphrase the question</p> <p>According to the assessment criteria, an IELTS Band 7 candidate:</p> <p>Uses paraphrase effectively</p>\n<p>If the examiner asks you a question and you can immediately think of a way to paraphrase it&mdash;i.e. express the same meaning in other words&mdash;go ahead and say something like &ldquo;Oh, you mean (paraphrase question)?&rdquo; This is a very effective strategy to demonstrate one of the core skills that the examiner is listening for. Try to do this two or three times during the test.</p> <p>IELTS Speaking Tip 4: Use linking words to connect your ideas</p> <p>According to the assessment criteria, an IELTS Band 7 candidate:</p> <p>Uses a range of connectives and discourse markers with some flexibility</p>\n<p>What does this mean in normal English? It means that you use a range of expressions like &lsquo;in other words&rsquo;, &lsquo;also&rsquo;, &lsquo;however&rsquo; and &lsquo;on the other hand&rsquo; to connect your ideas. The key word is range. The examiner doesn&rsquo;t want to hear you say &lsquo;on the other hand&rsquo; a hundred times! So record yourself speaking and notice if you use a phrase like &lsquo;on the other hand&rsquo; too much. If so, use a different phrase instead. Now you can start demonstrating a good range of linking words.</p> <p>  </p>\n<p>IELTS Speaking Tip 5: Don&rsquo;t be afraid of mistakes</p> <p>According to the assessment criteria, an IELTS Band 7 candidate:</p> <p>Frequently produces error-free sentences, though some grammatical mistakes persist</p>\n<p>That means it&rsquo;s possible to make some mistakes and still get IELTS 7.0 or 7.5. However, some candidates score poorly because they worry too much about mistakes. As a result, they speak too slowly and their mistakes become MORE obvious! It&rsquo;s more important to demonstrate fluency (See Tip #1) than it is to produce error-free speech. Of course, it&rsquo;s also good to correct yourself if you do notice a mistake.</p>",
        "main_topic": "Common",
        "remark": "",
        "section": "Speaking",
        "source": " ielts-academic",
        "sub_topic": "",
        "title": "How to Achieve 7.0",
        "topic": ""
    },
    {
        "content": "<p>One of the 4 criteria the IELTS Speaking module is assessed on is fluency and coherence. What does this mean?</p> <p>Fluency is the ability to maintain a flow of language without unnatural hesitation.</p> <p>Coherence is the logical organization, development and connection of ideas.</p> <p>Do you express ideas and opinions clearly and coherently (logically ordered and easy to follow), without long pauses or hesitations?</p> <p>Do you use discourse markers appropriately and naturally (i.e. you don&rsquo;t overuse the same few ones) to link your ideas?</p> <p>Do you stay on topic, develop your ideas but not &ldquo;go in circles&rdquo; (repeating yourself) or &ldquo;go off on a tangent&rdquo; (moving off the topic)?</p> <p>Unfortunately, there is no quick fix for this. Fluency comes from a lot of practice speaking, so the best way to improve is to speak/engage in conversation as often as you can! But you can really think about your strategy for coherence and practice. When answering a question remember to:</p> <p>Expand on your answer. Think of logical details that the examiner would want to know about. If someone else were talking to you, you would naturally have questions to find out more. What are those questions? Who? What? Where? When? Why? How? How much? How often? How good? How did you feel? Expand on your answer by adding those details that make it interesting.</p> <p>Where appropriate, explain how you feel about something &ndash; it gives emphasis to your reasons and details</p> <p>Where appropriate, describe a person, thing or place</p> <p>Think of a logical order or sequence. Don&rsquo;t jump around from one part to another. The examiner doesn&rsquo;t know what you&rsquo;re thinking in your head, so you should try to make your answer easy to follow.</p> <p>Use common conversational discourse markers to signal how your sentences and ideas are linked together. Here are some examples:</p> <p>well, &ndash; this has a lot of different uses, but mostly at the beginning of speaking in response to the other speaker</p> <p>ex. &ldquo;Well, I would say my favorite trip was the one I took with my family to the Philippines for the first time.&rdquo;</p> <p>actually &ndash; used to state a fact or reality, or for stating a correction, or sometimes to signal that what you&rsquo;re going to say may be unexpected</p> <p>ex. &ldquo;Actually, I think it was the first time for my parents to go back to their home country in about 20 years.&rdquo;</p> <p>as for &ndash; used in the same sense as &ldquo;regarding&rdquo; or &ldquo;in regard to&rdquo; which can be more formal</p> <p>ex. &ldquo;As for the food, I found the it to be really fresh and light.&rdquo;</p> <p>basically &ndash; when you want to simplify or summarize a complicated or lengthy story/idea</p> <p>ex. &ldquo;Basically, we were there to visit relatives my parents hadn&rsquo;t seen since they were young and for me to get to know my parents&rsquo; home country.&rdquo;</p> <p>I mean &ndash; used to clarify what was just said or say it in different words</p> <p>ex. &ldquo;It wasn&rsquo;t at all what I expected. I mean, I thought I knew a lot about the culture and the food, but it was so different being there.&rdquo;</p> <p>on the other hand &ndash; used to introduce a different view or alternative opinion</p> <p>ex. &ldquo;The big crowds on the streets made it really difficult to walk around. On the other hand, it made it exciting to be surrounded by so many people.&rdquo;</p> <p>anyway &ndash; to move on to another point or close the conversation</p> <p>as I was saying &ndash; to bring the topic back to the original point</p> <p>the thing is &ndash; to raise an important point</p> <p>ex. &rdquo; The thing is, I think the trip was just as memorable for my parents as it was for me. They were so proud to show off their hometown.&rdquo;</p> <p>at the same time &ndash; used to contrast what was previously said</p> <p>ex. &ldquo;It was fun enjoying summer weather during Christmas. At the same time, it didn&rsquo;t really feel like Christmas to me.&rdquo;</p>",
        "main_topic": "Common",
        "remark": "",
        "section": "Speaking",
        "source": " yourieltstutor",
        "sub_topic": "",
        "title": "IELTS Speaking tips  Fluency and Coherence",
        "topic": ""
    },
    {
        "content": "<com.ielts.ieltspreparation>Part 1 - Introduction</com.ielts.ieltspreparation> <p>Q. Good afternoon. My name is Kristina Pollock. Could I have your name, please?</p>\n<p>A. Good afternoon Madam. My name is Joseph Mark and my nickname is Mark.</p> <p>Q. And your candidate number?</p>\n<p>A. My candidate number is...</p> <p>Q. Thank you. Now could you tell me a little about yourself and where do you live?</p>\n<p>A. Well, I'm Joseph Mark and I live at... My father's name is... He is a Government service holder. My mother's name is... She is basically a housewife but sometimes she works at our shop. I'm 26 and I've finished my graduation from... University. My major was Mathematics. I've got 2 brothers and a younger sister. We live like a very happy family and my parents take great care of us. I'm doing a part-time job at a local school as a Mathematics teacher. I'm planning to complete my M.Sc. from any reputed University of the UK. My future plan is to teach in a college. I spend my leisure time surfing the internet and reading books. Sometimes I hang around with my friends on the lake shore. The place I live now is really charming and I love to live there. It's not noisy and busy like other cities and I have got many friends there. I am maintaining a personal blog and there I try to add a post every week. This is basically a technology and Math related blog.</p> <p>Q. What are some of the nicest things about where you live?</p>\n<p>A. The place where I live in is a calm area and is very neat and clean. You will find it naturally beautiful and the lakes, gardens, fountain, river, hill and the songs of birds will take your heart away. Whenever my friends from other cities come to visit my area, they become awestricken! Our area is indeed a beautiful place to live in. The people are very nice and friendly and you would be very pleased with their charming behaviours if you visit there. The area is free of pollution as it is not an industrial area and the fresh air would give a soothing feeling. The traffic on the road is good most of the time and you won't have to worry about the public transportation as they are available around the clock. This area is famous for many historical sites and monuments like (...say some names here...) and many tourists come to visit here every day. The tour guides are very nice and are maintained by Government. There are many restaurants there and you can pick one of your delicious menus from there and I am sure you will never forget the taste! People in our area lead simple yet friendly lives and they make friends easily. The crime rate is pretty low and as a small town, we know other members of our area.</p>\n<p>I am sure if you visit our area once, you will simply love it.</p> <p>Q. Are there any places of special interest I could visit in your home area?</p>\n<p>A. The Gomez River and Roar Hills are two most beautiful places in our area. Thousands of tourists each month come to visit our area and these two places are main attractions for the tourists.</p> <p>Apart from that, some monuments of famous politicians, poets and renowned persons in the Family Square is one of the main attractions and it is worth visiting. The hill hiking, swimming and fishing are three most popular activities among tourists and I would recommend those activities to you. You will never get bored there and if you even slightly do, simply get yourself enrolled in the government managed tour plans for a couple of days. This would give you a whole new chance to explore hills, rivers, forests and you would find challenges and enthralling experiences from there. Lastly, do not forget to taste our local foods and fruits.</p> <p>Take the chance to visit our area and I am sure you would start recommending your friends after that.</p> <p>Q. Could you describe some of them for me?</p>\n<p>A. The Gomez River is a long river that passes through our town. The water is crystal clear and you can see the fishes, corals and other objects inside it. The water is surprisingly warm and when you will look at it, you will be surprised to see all the fishes there. It is like a large aquarium. The reflection of the sky gives it a heavenly look and many people go there for picnic and fishing there. In the evening children and parents play in the fields beside the river and you can find some newly constructed motels and restaurants there. Swimming in this river is a popular activity among local people and tourists in the summer season.</p> <p>The Roar hill is another beautiful site in our area and it got its names from the roaring echo sound it creates. There are several hills there and they are over 300- 500 feet tall. The vista, illusionary sound of birds, the natural beauty and fountains give it a painted picture like looks. In the evening when the sun starts hiding behind the hills, people look at this out-of-the-world scenery simply in amazement.</p> <p>Q. What would be the best way for me to get there?</p>\n<p>A. If you have a private car with you, you can drive along the roads and reach there. From the city centre, both of the destinations would be around 1 and half hour&rsquo;s journey. Alternatively, you can take a public bus or hire a small car and reach there. The rent/ticket fee of the public transportation is fixed and you do not need to pay any extra charge.</p> <p>If you enrol with the tour service provider, they will manage the plan, route and based on your preference, you can either share a zip or can take a private car for rent. The later one is comparatively expensive.</p> <p>Q. What sort of places could I stay at?</p>\n<p>A. You can stay at a tourist motel near the hills or can rent a hotel room in the city centre. If you are visiting your family members, then villa near the hill road would be better alternatives for you. Almost every tourist motel provides meals facility.</p> <p>Q. Should I go at any special time of year?</p>\n<p>A. Most of the tourists come to our area during the summer season and I would recommend you to visit during summer as well. There are lots of activities you can do during this period and you will find the beauty of our city at that time.</p> <p>[ I see, this has all been very interesting.]</p> <p>  </p>\n<com.ielts.ieltspreparation>Part 2 - Cue Card</com.ielts.ieltspreparation> <p>Topic:</p> <p>Describe a problem that affects the environment in the area where you live.</p> <p>You should say:</p> <p>what the problem is</p>\n<p>what causes it</p>\n<p>what people feel about the problem</p>\n<p>and explain what you think could be done to solve it.</p> <p>  </p>\n<p>A. There are so many problems that negatively affect the environment in our area and among these, the density of population, in my opinion, is the most severe one. While in many countries, less than 100 people live in one square kilometre, we have got around thousand of people living in one square kilometre. Because of this high population and population density in city areas, lots of problems are arising.</p> <p>The expenditure to support living is quite high compared to the average earning of the people, a heavy traffic has become a common scenario in the roads and as a consequence, lots of time is killed every day. The lower economic people are not getting the proper education and hospital facility, crime has increased than ever, lots of unplanned and risky constructions have been established, the environment is getting polluted and seems like no one cares.</p> <p>There are many reasons that caused this outburst of this mass population in our city and among those, the most influential reason is the centralization of industry in this city. Most of the factory, offices and organisations are located in this city and people from all area of the country are coming here to find a living. The unemployment in rural areas is another reason why people are trying to stay here. The political reason not to take strict decisions on making equal opportunity in the country is another reason. The businesses and job opportunity attract people to come and live here in this city.</p> <p>People can feel the heat of this uncontrolled population and the problems are creating for that but they have little control over it. We all suffer from the problems and talk about it but I have not seen any big movement to solve this problem. On the other hand, the political leaders who can take initiatives to lessen the problem are sometimes corrupted to take appropriate and honest steps.</p> <p>There are lots of theories to solve this problem and seems like we all know about it. First of all, decentralisation should be done and industries and factories that can be moved to other areas should be moved promptly. Proper education and job sectors should be ensured so that people can earn their living at their cities rather than coming here. Local government can be formed to support and improve each area of the country. Each local government should be able to invest and decide about the development projects in their area.</p> <p>People naturally want to live in a better place where they can find the necessary infrastructure, daily needs and can earn a living. If that can be ensured throughout the country, this problem can be reduced.</p> <p>  </p>\n<com.ielts.ieltspreparation>Part 3 - Details Discussion</com.ielts.ieltspreparation> <p>Q. Tell me, what do you think are the greatest problems facing your country at present?</p>\n<p>A. Economic development issue, political instability, unemployment and healthcare are the major issues most of the people in my country face. In my opinion, these are the most burning issues and the greatest problems we have in our country.</p> <p>Q. And what has been done so far to solve these problems?</p>\n<p>A. The government has taken many initiatives for the economic progress of our country. According to the statistics, we are indeed progressing. But I am not convinced with the reported statistics. I want to see the result, I want to feel it. The political instability seems like consuming most of our good will and energy. While major political parties should have worked together to help improve our economic conditions, sometimes their actions give me real doubt whether they are the type of leaders we need for our country!</p> <p>On the positive sides, government has emphasized on ICT sector, has made the export process easier for business people, established many training institutes to enhance the skill of the rural people and those are all hopeful signs. Someday definitely we will see the progress. Education, skill, foreign investment, job security etc. are also important areas where the government has invested a lot of money. The aim of this investment is to create a skilled and educated generation who would lead the economy and the country.</p> <p>The health care section is still an expensive area for the mass people and the government&rsquo;s initiatives for the establishment of new hospitals, enrolling more doctors and nurses are in reality very little compared to the actual need.</p> <p>Q. How successful would you say these measures have been?</p>\n<p>A. These measures are successful to some extent but if I present it in figures, it would only a few percentages than the actual progress we expect. For instance: more than three thousand hospitals are required throughout the country whereas only 45 hospitals have been established in the last one year.</p> <p>Q. Do you think things are likely to get better or worse in the future?</p>\n<p>A. We hope that the problem we have in our country would be resolved in next few years. The government and other organisations are working hard to address these issues and we are noticing some progress. So we can definitely be positive and wait for the glorious days when we won&rsquo;t have those issues. This was an optimistic idea and I possess this positive idea about my country. But the greatest obstacle is the hunger for power and our political parties often create haphazard situations for the power. This is the single reason that can degrade the situation in the future.</p> <p>Q. Is what you are going to study likely to be of any use to solve these problems?</p>\n<p>A. I am going to finish my graduation majoring Computer Science and I am very positive that it would directly or indirectly help eradicate unemployment, economic progress issues to some extent that I have talked about. After finishing my education, I would establish a small software company and hopefully one day it would grow to be a large company where thousands of employees would work. The ICT sector also helps earn foreign remittance for a country and I would also contribute to enhance the foreign remittance for my country.</p>",

        "content": "<h5>Part 1 - Introduction</h5> <p>Q. Good Morning. Could you tell me your name and candidate number, please?</p>\n<p>A. Good Morning. I am Rahul Sharma and my candidate number is&hellip;...</p> <p>Q. And what would you like me to call you?</p>\n<p>A. Please call me Rahul. That&rsquo;s my nickname.</p> <p>Q. Tell me a bit about your family.</p>\n<p>A. Well, I live in a joint family and there are almost 20 family members in this family. My grandpa, grandma, my parents, sisters, my uncles and their children are living in a joint family and that makes it a large family. My grandpa was a teacher and he is now around 70 years old. My father owns a small business and two of my uncle work there. My mother is a house wife and she takes care of me, my sisters and cousins. I have two sisters who are younger than me are in school. My father mostly takes care of the financial part of our family and he is the main earning member of our family. The house we live in quite big and it has more than 15 rooms in total.</p> <p>That&rsquo;s the summary of my family members. If there is anything particular you would like to know about my family, I would be happy to answer.</p> <p>Q. What do your brothers and sisters do?</p>\n<p>A. I have not got any brother of my own. I have two sisters and both of them are students. The older one, Radhika, reads in class ten while the younger one, Dina, reads in class seven. Besides study sometimes they help my mother on her housework and often help my cousins to prepare their homework. My sisters are very close to me and I like them so much. They are both very adorable.</p> <p>Q. So, where are you from?</p>\n<p>A. I am from ...&hellip; (tell the City/ Village/ Area name) of &hellip;... (District/ County/ Area/State name). I was born in this city but for my university education I, later on, moved to ..&hellip;. (Area name). Currently, I am living at &hellip;&hellip; (Your present area) and I came here from my current living place.</p> <p>Q. What are the advantages and disadvantages of living here?</p>\n<p>A. The place where I am currently living is a busy and residential area.</p> <p>Among advantages I would say:</p> <p>It is a secured area as there are guards and police cars often roam in the streets. There are very few incidences to bother about.</p>\n<p>People are nice and amiable.</p>\n<p>The internet, cyber caf&eacute;, library and other facilities are available.</p>\n<p>Transportation facility is another advantage of this area. You do not need to wait for a long in the queue to get a public car.</p>\n<p>Amusement park, gardens, playgrounds, shopping complex and other community facilities are nearby.</p>\n<p>Finally, there is no industry or commercial building there to pollute the air or sound.</p>\n<p>Overall, I enjoy living there and compared to my previous living place, this is many times better.</p> <p>Now among the disadvantages, I would mention that:</p> <p>The rent of the houses and apartments are comparatively higher and it is rising every year.</p>\n<p>The entrance gate of my area closes at 11:00 pm and that&rsquo;s why I have to worry about returning home before 11:00 pm even after I have important tasks outside.</p>\n<p>The roads are busy during the school and office time.</p>\n<p>The last problem I would like to mention is the scarcity of doctors in this area. There is no hospital or medical centre here so people have to go to the city centre to avail this facility if required.</p>\n<p>Q. I'm new here. Could you recommend a good restaurant?</p>\n<p>A. That would depend on your taste of foods and budget. If you want to enjoy the natural views and taste the local foods, I would recommend you to go to (Mark Polo Restaurant). It is nearby- would not take more than 20 minutes in a car.</p> <p>Now if you want to taste other menus like Chinese, Italian, Indian, Thai, or European foods, your best deal would be the Dela Mono restaurant. They are bit expensive but their foods are delicious.</p> <p>Finally, if you want to enjoy your foods and have some refreshment like music, you should better go to WestInn and as far as I know it is quite expensive. To taste cheap fast foods you can visit the small restaurants nearby the New Market area. In fact, I often go there and I enjoy their foods.</p> <p>Q. Why do you like it?</p>\n<p>A. I like quick foods and they are delicious. They offer ready foods at a low budget and that&rsquo;s why I like it very much. Apart from that, New Market area is only 10 minutes distance from my university and having foods from those restaurants is convenient for me.</p> <p>Q. What types of foods does it serve?</p>\n<p>A. It serves only fast foods and quick meals including the burger, sandwich, pizza, fried chicken, fried rice with vegetables, all type of soft drinks and lassi. If you want to have lunch or dinner, you can order the set menu that includes: fried rice, vegetable, chicken, curry and other local items. Lassi and pizza are my two favourite foods of this restaurants and I often have these two items.</p> <p>Q. What do you suggest I order?</p>\n<p>A. I would suggest you to order a small California Pizza, one glass of Lassi and a mixed vegetable item. I am quite fond of this menu and enjoy eating it a lot. I am quite sure if you are not a pizza hater, you would also like it.</p> <p>Q. Is it expensive?</p>\n<p>A. Not at all. The whole menu would cost you only a few dollars. If you compare the price of this restaurant to other restaurants, you would find it quite cheap in fact.</p> <p>Q. How do I get there?</p>\n<p>A. The newmarket area is a well-known place so you don&rsquo;t have to worry much. From here you can take a public bus to reach the new market area. After reaching there you need to take a turn to the north and you will see the large banner ads of this restaurants. If you take your private car, you need to reach the City fountain first and then you should turn left. After 5 minutes you will see a large auditorium and then you should turn to your right. Go straight for a couple of more minutes and you are bound to notice the New Market. In case you are not sure about the route at any moment, you should ask any passerby about the location and anyone would be able to tell you the direction.</p> <p>Q. After you have taken the lELTS, what are you planning to study?</p>\n<p>A. I have finished my graduation in Computer Science and I have planned to finish my post-graduation in the same major. After getting my IELTS I would get myself admitted in any renowned university of the United Kingdom.</p> <p>Q. Why are you interested in this?</p>\n<p>A. I have a passion for computer programming and web development. Before deciding to take my undergraduate program in Computer Science, I talk with my teachers, parents and some relatives and they all suggested me to take part in this study. Since I have already completed my B.Sc. degree in Computer Science, I think it would be wise to continue my post-graduation courses in the same subject. Apart from that, the career prospect in Information and Communication sector and more specifically in software engineering is very high in my country. So I am interested in it from my passion, past educational background and because of the career prospect.</p> <p>Q. Why do you want to study overseas?</p>\n<p>A. I always wanted to study in an oversea university as it would ensure a better educational environment and quality education compared to the universities of my country. Apart from that, the opportunity to learn about the diverse cultures and people in a foreign university is something I don&rsquo;t want to miss. Finally, a foreign degree, especially a degree from a reputed USA or UK university is helpful for better career prospect in our country. Considering all of the above-mentioned reasons, I have decided to continue my study at an overseas university.</p> <h5>Part 2 - Cue Card</h5> <p>Topic:</p> <p>Describe a course you took in your college or university.</p> <p>You should say:</p> <p>what it was</p>\n<p>when you took it</p>\n<p>what you learned from this course</p>\n<p>And explain why you took this course.</p> <p>A. &lsquo;Book Keeping &amp; Banking&rsquo; was one of the most interesting courses I took in my university level and I thoroughly enjoyed this course. In fact, I learned many new concepts and theory from this course that it helped me a lot throughout the remaining semesters. This was a mandatory course in the 3rd semester in my Bachelor of Business Administration studies and the courses on this subject lasted for four months. I was so interested in this course that later on, I took three other courses in different semesters related to banking.</p> <p>I learned the accounting concept of banking, how a bank is operated, how the banking transactions and accounting are maintained, how the central banks control the money supply of the market and many more concepts from this course. A practical session was included in this course and I learned some basic transaction processes of bankers from this lab sessions.</p> <p>In my third semester, this was a mandatory course and I had no alternatives other than taking this course. I came from Science background until my undergraduate course and that&rsquo;s why I had no prior accounting course experience. I was bit dubious about this course in my university level as I did not know what it includes. But after I completed this course, I found myself very much interested in Banking procedure and automated banking.</p> <h5>Part 3 - Details Discussion.</h5> <p>[OK, good. I would like to go back to you now.]</p> <p>Q. How do you think studying overseas will be different to studying in your own country?</p>\n<p>A. Studying in a foreign country is far different than studying in the home country. First of all, a student would have to leave his family, relatives, friends and stay in a different country to continue his/ her study in a foreign university. In home country s/he has the option to either attend classes from home or to stay in the university residence halls. In the second case, s/he can meet family and relatives frequently and can make new friends very quickly. While studying in a foreign university, students often suffer from homesickness and have to get enrolled in part-time jobs to support his/ her expenses. While studying overseas universities students can learn about different custom, culture and tradition. Overseas universities are often better in quality than home universities and thus overseas universities offer quality education and this has a better prospect in the future career. Among other differences, the language, communication and exam systems might be different. Finally, an overseas university offers latest and up to date curriculum while home universities, especially in less developed countries, might lack the proper study environment and proper syllabus.</p> <p>Q. So what problems do you think you will have studying abroad?</p>\n<p>A. I will miss my family members and I think for the first few weeks this would be terrible. All my life I lived with my family members and being in a foreign country would mean that I can contact them over the phone and have video calls, but can&rsquo;t spend time with them in person.</p> <p>The language barrier would be another problem. My English is better than average but still understanding and communicating with people of a different country who have a different accent is sometimes an unavoidable problem. Hopefully, this won&rsquo;t last for a long as I am a quick learner and I will try my best to learn the manner, custom and accent of this country very quickly.</p> <p>Another problem that might arrive is loneliness. This is going to be a new country and I won&rsquo;t have any friends and relatives. So the first few days would be lonely I guess. Travelling and not knowing the route and bus number would be another problem. The different kinds of foods in this country might be a problem as I am habituated to eat common types of foods available in my country. It might happen that I won&rsquo;t find foods of my preference near my living place.</p> <p>Finally finding a senior student, classmate or a teacher who would spend some time to explain some of the lessons that I might find difficult would be another problem I guess. In my country, I always had resources and helping hands for my studies. I guess that would not be available initially in a new country where I would go for study.</p> <p>I think these are the main issues I will face in first few weeks after I arrive in a different country to study.</p> <p>Q. Do you think you will have many difficulties adapting to a new culture?</p>\n<p>A. I guess it would not be much difficult for me to adapt to a new culture as I am already exposed to diverse customs and cultures in my home country. But of course, it is a bit tough to adapt a new culture very, especially when the culture and tradition are quite different from my home country. But I have the confidence that I won&rsquo;t face many difficulties there, especially related to the new culture, as I already did my research on common customs and traditions of this new country. So nothing would be completely new and shocking for me, I hope.</p> <p>Q. Do you think that there will be any major changes in your field of study over the next few years?</p>\n<p>A. Yes, the subject Computer Science by its nature changes over time. Since this is a pure technology-based subject unlike other subjects like History, Mathematics, Arts etc. changes are very obvious. Programming languages and computer hardware are ever changing from the very beginning and many changed would occur in my field of study.</p> <p>The courses change very frequently and many new algorithms are introduced to make the computing and software development more efficient. For instance, the data security, search mechanism, encryptions are very core subjects of Computer Science and they are changing very fast. It is not unlikely that new computing concept would emerge and that would be included in my field of study.</p> <p>Q. How do you think an overseas degree will improve your professional skills?</p>\n<p>A. I am planning to have an overseas degree mainly because of the finest quality and facilities this university can offer in my area of study. The overseas degree would actually ensure a better study environment and learning opportunity for me. Thus I would be able to learn better and have better skills to pursue a better career.</p> <p>In my country, a foreign degree is given a priority in case of a job interview. Many local and international organisations even mention that a foreign degree from a reputed university would be a plus for the candidate. So I am sure having a foreign degree would open more opportunity for me in my professional life.</p> <p>The foreign universities, especially universities of first world countries, are renowned for their professionalism, study environment and facilities to learn better skills. I am sure I would be able to take advantages of these facilities and would be able to learn more. The top notch universities of a first world country are often renowned for their research and I will put every effort to get involved in such research facilities to enhance my skills.</p> <p>Q. What do you intend to do once you have finished your studies?</p>\n<p>A. I will get admitted in my Master's degree in few months and after I finish my studies, I would get back to my country. Once I get back to my country, I will start applying for a suitable job. In fact, the job would be the place where I would be able to learn even more and use the knowledge I have learned in the past few years and will learn in next two years.</p> <p>So in a nutshell, starting a job related to my study to enhance my skill would be the first thing I will do after I finish my graduation. Apart from that, I have a plan to work on a personal eCommerce project that I have been planning for years. The potential of eCommerce in my home country is immense and I would try to tap in this sector to establish a large eCommerce business.</p> <p>These are the plans I have now for my immediate future but time often drives us to new tracks and different motivations. So if something bigger and better comes across my pathway, I will plan accordingly then.</p> <p>Q. What do you see yourself doing professionally in 10 years' time? And how do you see your personal life changing?</p>\n<p>A. Umm, predicting what I will be doing after 10 years is bit tricky! But if everything goes according to my plan and the Almighty drives me to the right track, I will own my own Ecommerce business after 10 years. I will be able to quit my day job at that time and would be able to fully concentrate on my own business. E-commerce would not be the only thing where I would be working then. At that time I will own some of the prominent and large software nationally and internationally. I have a plan to establish a night school in my hometown and hopefully in ten years that would be renowned one and a role model for the people of my locality.</p> <p>After 10 years I will probably be a married person with 1-2 kids of my own. That would be a big change I guess. There would be many responsibilities and new ways of life. I will devote more on doing humanitarian things than concentrating more on personal gains. Probably my choices of dresses, foods, music, movies and books would change and I would become more matured. Finally, I will have fewer friends than I have now but they would be very close. My relationship with my co-workers and employees would be more prominent than my relationship with my university or college friends. I think those are very significant changed that are most likely to take place in my personal life after 10 years or so.</p>",

        "content": "<h5>PART 1 - Introduction:</h5>\n<p>[The examiner asks the candidate about him/her, his/her home, work or studies and other familiar topics.]</p> <p>Family:</p>\n<p>Q. Do you have a large family or a small family?</p>\n<p>A. I come from a small family. I live with my parents and two siblings. As I recall we used to live with our grandparents, uncles and aunts many years ago. But now we have a nuclear family.</p> <p>Q. Can you tell me something about them?</p>\n<p>A. Yeah sure. My father is a doctor and he has been practising medicine for more than 15 years. He is a devoted doctor and possesses a great and exemplary personality. People think that he has a very controlled personality but we know that he is very kind. I am proud to have such a great father. He is my idol in my life.</p> <p>My mother is an angel and she is the most kindhearted woman I have ever seen in my life. She is a teacher in a school and she teaches literature. She is my best friend and I adore her very much.</p> <p>My brother is 3 years senior to me and he is working in a telecommunication company as a System Analyst. He is around 28 years old and a very good friend and mentor to me.</p> <p>My younger sister is only 12 years old and she is busy with her home works, study and computer. She is very sweet and helps my mother often to finish her household chores. I love her very much and she talks a lot to me. In our house, I am her best friend and I often help her completing her home works.</p> <p>Q. How much time do you manage to spend with members of your family?</p>\n<p>A. I live with my family and I spent most of my time at home with my family members. When I am out of home for my classes or go to hang out with friends are the times I stay away from my family. Apart from that, I mostly spend time with them.</p> <p>I have a very close relationship with my younger sister and my brother. We often go out together to watch movies or to do shopping. We sometimes play computer games together. On an average, I spend 5-7 hours with my family members in a typical day.</p> <p>Q. What sorts of things do you like to do together?</p>\n<p>A. I like to discuss my plans with my father. I often take advice on important things from him. He discusses his experience, tells me history and often he teaches me morality and importance of being honest in life. He recommends me books and then we discuss these books in our free time.</p> <p>I do everything with my brother John. We hang out together, watch movies, read books, sometimes we fight, we often complaints to our parents about what I or he should not have done, we swim, catch fish, play football and many other countless things. Though he is very friendly, he often scolds me whenever he thinks I did something wrong. He even acts like a mentor sometimes. Nowadays, he got busy in his office and that&rsquo;s why we spend our time together on his days off.</p> <p>I play computer games and chess with my sister and she often seeks my advice regarding things she can&rsquo;t decide alone. We watch cartoons and documentary on History Channel together.</p> <p>I love to talk to my mother and she is very fond of feeding us. She often shares her experience at school with us and we often watch TV serials and sports together. She loves to hear some classic music and I have become a fan of her favourite singers. So I often listen to music with her. There are many more activities that actually I do with my family members and those are the frequent ones.</p> <p>Q. Did/ Do you get on well with your family? Why?</p>\n<p>A. Yes, obviously I go well with my family. They are the most precious things I have in my life. They care for me a lot, they help me on my difficult times and my whole existence is surrounded by them. Whoever I am and whoever I become in future would be because of my family members&rsquo; love, care and affections.</p> <p>I have a strong bonding and friendly relationship with my family. They share their thought and everyday experience with me. They always try to support me no matter what and all those mutual understanding makes us a small, happy family.</p> <h5>PART 2 - Cue Card</h5> <p>Topic:</p> <p>Describe a teacher who has influenced you in your education.</p> <p>You should say:</p> <p>&bull; where you met him/her.</p>\n<p>&bull; what subject he/she taught.</p>\n<p>&bull; what was special about him/her.</p> <p>and explain why this person influenced you so much.</p> <p>[ You will have to talk about the topic for 1 to 2 minutes. You have one minute to think about what you are going to say. You can make some notes to help you if you wish. ]</p> <p>A.I consider myself lucky to get several very good teachers throughout my academic years. Among them, I'd like to talk about Mr Smith who was an extraordinary teacher, a really good mentor and who has a great influence in my education.</p> <p>I met Mr Smith when I was in class 4 and he was our math teacher. Initially, we thought that he would be a moody teacher and we would have to be very polite in front of him. This impression came mostly because of his serious face and tidy dress-up. But soon we found that he is a very friendly person and teaches us very well. He never made things complicated and tried over and over again to explain something to us. He had a unique way of teaching. Seems like he would start an interesting story and later we would find that he would relate the math to the story. Thus everything we learned from him was interesting and that's why we remember most of the theory and techniques of math he taught us.</p> <p>I'd say he has a great influence in my education because he made a very strong foundation on Mathematics. Later on, I studied Science and Mathematics was the most important subject. I have always been good at math and that' mainly because of Mr Smith who had a major role in making the subject interesting to me. Before I learned math from Mr Smith, my impression on math was not good and I considered mathematics to be a very difficult and uninteresting subject. But his teaching and influences changed my way of thinking about math and later on math became my one the most favourite subject.</p> <h5>PART 3 - Follow-up Questions</h5> <p>Discussion topics:</p> <p>Developments in education...</p> <p>Q. How has education changed in your country in the last 10 years?</p>\n<p>A. I live in a developing country where the education sector went through numerous changes including the government&rsquo;s more fund allocation in education, more women enrollment in higher studies, changes in academic syllabus etc.</p> <p>During the last 10 years, the most significant change that has happened in the education sector in my country is the people&rsquo;s mentality regarding the necessity of education. Only 20-30 years back many parents showed little interest in sending their kids to school. But that has radically changed in my country and nowadays almost every parent sends their children to school. This is a giant leap in my opinion in terms of the advancement of our education. The government allocated a share portion of its budget to ensure the school's infrastructure, study materials and salary of the teachers and that has been proven effective to build a solid ground to make an education nation. Only in the last 5 years, our literacy rate has almost doubled and I give a major credit to the government for ensuring free education in primary level, special scholarship and monetary rewards to women students.</p> <p>I am not 100% sure about the exact statistics but my best guess would be that more than 200-300 colleges and universities have been established in the last few years. We had only 4-5 engineering university back in 2000 but we have more than 30 such educational institutions now. More importance has been given to vocational education and thus a large number of underprivileged populations have come under the vocational education system.</p> <p>In a nutshell, that was a massive change and I have witnessed some of those changes in my own eyes including how public exams&rsquo; quality have been improved, how the schools are emphasising on English and Mathematics as academic subjects and so on and on.</p> <p>  </p>\n<p>Q. What changes do you foresee in the next 50 years?</p>\n<p>A. If you ask me about the type of changes that might occur in the education sector in my country in next 50 years, I would need to rely on my own past experience and predictions mostly. My best guess is that the education would be more practical than theoretical in future. Women&rsquo;s participation and performance in education would excel to a great extent. More women would be in research and higher education than their male counterpart.</p> <p>The education would be expensive and private education institutes would be more demanding than the public and state-owned ones. More foreign students would come to study here and the number of higher education institutes would increase by many-fold than the current number.</p> <p>The digitalization and computer-based education system would replace many traditional education systems and the online education would be a very popular form during that time.</p> <p>Curriculum and subject offered in the college and education level would see a dramatic increase and technology would be the most important and demanding subject in this era.</p> <p>Not sure if I will be alive or not to see the changes but I hope many positive changes within the next 50 years in my country including 100% literacy rate, more engineering and research-based education system, some of our universities are raking in the world&rsquo;s best university list and we are renowned as a country of a very excellent place for education.</p> <p>  </p>\n<p>A national education system...</p> <p>Q. How do the expectations of today&rsquo;s school leavers compare with those of the previous generation?</p>\n<p>A. Well, the school quitters nowadays are expected to study further and get involved in a part-time job to gain practical experience. The job market is pretty competitive compared to the previous time. Getting a good job requires talent, some practical experience, good grades in school and many other criteria. The competitions in public service or Government jobs are even higher. In the past decades there were very few school graduates in my country and hence securing a job both in public and private sector was not that tough.</p> <p>The requirement is education is higher than the past. Twelve class degree is not enough to get a decent job. Recruiters are looking for candidates with prior job experiences and at least Bachelor degree. Thus the school leavers nowadays have no other option but to continue their studies. Getting a part-time job besides the study is a dream for many.</p> <p>I heard from my grandfather that there were only few bachelor degree holders in his whole village while there must be more than 100 bachelor degree holders in a single community these days.</p> <p>Those who leave school without completing the course have no other option but to either look after their family business or manage a job where physical labour is the only skill that s/he has.</p> <p>The population in my country has almost doubled in the last decade and that is pretty obvious that the completion the school leavers nowadays face is tremendous. Among the school leavers, many decide their major in college or university while other prefers vocational education. This facility was very narrow in my grandfather&rsquo;s generation as I know. So I would say there is a whole lot of difference between current and past generations in terms of their opportunity, action and plan after leaving school.</p> <p>Q. What role do you think extracurricular activities play in education?</p>\n<p>A. Extracurricular activities sharpen the minds of students and enhance their creativity. Activities that require physical movements keep their body fit and thus the importance of extracurricular activities are immense. It is often experienced that kids who have interests in sports and games outperform the others in many fields. Extracurricular activities like singing, debating, painting can be very handy in terms of career enhancement. Students who have extracurricular activities possess better leadership and social activities. Finally from my experience, I can say that such students have better knowledge about the world than students who are solely focused on academic lessons.</p> <p>  </p>\n<p>Different styles/ methods of teaching and learning...</p> <p>Q. What method of learning works best for you?</p>\n<p>A. I prefer to work in a pair for the complex topics and subjects. The group discussion, in particular, works best for me. When I study in a group I can discuss my views and learn opinions of others. Thus the discussion is always helpful and I can better perform in an exam and remember the details for a long.</p> <p>Q. How beneficial do you think it is to group students according to their level of ability?</p>\n<p>A. It&rsquo;s always beneficial for students to make a group for study and discussion. If the group comprises students of similar calibre and talent levels, they are proven to be more helpful. Similar abilities of students in a group can be advantageous from mainly two points of views. They are more frank to participate in any discussion and they have a good understanding among themselves. Secondly, they understand each other better and can advise in an effective way.</p>",

    {
        "content": "<p>This post will help you give better answers in part 2 of the IELTS speaking test.</p> <p>In IELTS speaking part 2 you will be given a topic or cue card similar to this:</p> <p>Describe a plant grown in your country. You should say</p>\n<p>&ndash; what the plant is</p>\n<p>&ndash; where it is grown</p>\n<p>&ndash; why you like or dislike it</p>\n<p>and explain why it is important to your country.</p>\n<p>You will have 1 minute to make notes and then will be asked to speak for between 1-2 minutes.</p> <p>Speaking for 2 minutes on an unfamiliar topic scares most IELTS students and that&rsquo;s why IELTS speaking part 2 is one of the most feared parts of the exam. The problem seems to be running out of things to say or not knowing what to say because you are unfamiliar with the cue card suggestions.</p> <p>To overcome this problem, I have developed a strategy to help students and it has proved very successful.</p> <p>A common error is thinking you have to talk about exactly what is written on the card. You don&rsquo;t! Having spoken to several IELTS examiners and students who achieved very high marks in their speaking test, I can assure you that you don&rsquo;t have to cover everything on the card. The band descriptors also don&rsquo;t mention anything about answering all the suggested parts of task 2.</p> <p>Following the suggested sentences on the card is fine and many candidates do very well following them but others run out of ideas. More importantly, if you have a structure to follow for every question you can practice and prepare more effectively.</p> <p>My strategy is to talk about what you feel comfortable talking about. In other words, talk about the things you think will get you the highest marks. If you like the suggestions on the card, then talk about them. But if you don&rsquo;t, or you want some extra things to talk about, then follow the strategy below.</p> <p>When you get the cue card you will be given one minute to write down some ideas. You are going to use this time wisely by using the following structure. On the piece of paper provided write down five headings with a little space between each one.</p> <p>Introduction</p>\n<p>Past</p>\n<p>Description</p>\n<p>Opinion</p>\n<p>Future</p> <p>Now you will start to write keywords beside each of these headings. Let&rsquo;s look at each in a little more detail.</p> <p>Introduction</p> <p>Start off by saying &lsquo;I&rsquo;d like to talk about (X).&rsquo; Then say &lsquo;I chose this topic because&hellip;&rsquo; and you will be able to say why you choose this topic. If you can&rsquo;t think of a reason just make one up, although it&rsquo;s always better to talk about real experiences.</p> <p>Past</p> <p>Now pause and use a linking word like &lsquo;anyway&rsquo; or &lsquo;anyhow&rsquo; to transition into talking about the past. This will allow you to demonstrate that you are confident using a range of past structures. For example-</p> <p>Used to + infinitive to talk about past habits or states that are now finished.</p>\n<p>Would + infinitive to describe past habits.</p>\n<p>Past simple to talk about things you did in the past that you no longer do or are no longer true.</p>\n<p>Past continuous to talk about the background of a story or how you felt at a particular time.</p>\n<p>Past perfect to say something happened before something else in the past.</p> <p>Description</p> <p>Now pause and say &lsquo;So let me tell you about (X) in a little more detail.&rsquo; This is your opportunity to impress the examiner with specific vocabulary. Get to know the common topics and have some specific adjectives ready. If you use an adjective to describe something, make sure you expand on it or explain it with examples. Again, if you can&rsquo;t think of specific examples, it is fine to make these up. Make sure your examples match the adjective and you will be fine.</p> <p>Opinion</p> <p>Now you can pause and say &lsquo;If you ask me/In my view/I would say + (opinion on topic). This give you a chance to express how you feel about the topic. It could be your personal opinion or it could be a comparative or superlative. Using a wide range of phrases to express your opinion will help you get a higher mark. If you want to give a stronger opinion you could say:</p> <p>I strongly believe that&hellip;</p>\n<p>As far as I&rsquo;m concerned&hellip;</p>\n<p>I&rsquo;m strongly against&hellip;</p>\n<p>I&rsquo;m strongly in favour of&hellip;.</p>\n<p>I&rsquo;m skeptical of the idea that&hellip;</p>\n<p>I must admit, I think&hellip;.</p> <p>Future</p> <p>Finally you can display your ability to use future tenses. Start off by saying &lsquo;With regards to the future&hellip;.&rsquo; A range of tenses will help you gain extra marks. For example you could use:</p> <p>Present continuous to talk about fixed arrangements.</p>\n<p>Be going + to + infinitive to talk about future plans.</p>\n<p>Will or won&rsquo;t + infinitive is used with predictions based on opinions or experiences. It can also be used to talk about hopes and assumptions.</p>\n<p>The future perfect- will have + past participle- is used to say something will have happened or will have been completed by a certain point in the future.</p> <p>That&rsquo;s it! Five simple headings that will allow you to speak for at least two minutes without any difficultly.</p>",

        "content": "<p>Strategies to answer the questions</p>\n<p>Quickly read through the paragraph headings so you can see what they say.</p>\n<p>Then look at the first paragraph.</p>\n<p>Often only the topic sentence needs to be read carefully because the main idea and answer are there - you may be able to just skim the rest.</p>\n<p>Sometimes, however, the answer is not in the topic sentence and the whole paragraph needs to be read more carefully.</p>\n<p>If a match is not immediately obvious, move on to the next one.</p>\n<p>If you are unsure between two answers at first, put them both in. You may be able to eliminate one answer later if it fits another paragraph better.</p>\n<p>If at the end you are still stuck between two answers for a question, pick which fits best.</p>\n<p>Things to beware of</p>\n<p>There are always more choices of paragraph headings on the list than paragraphs, so be careful when matching them.</p>\n<p>Watch out for synonyms - often words in the paragraphs and paragraph headings will not be the same; they will be synonyms.</p>\n<p>Having a noun from a heading that is in the paragraph does not guarantee they match - you still need to read it carefully to check.</p>",

        "content": "<h5>Strategies to answer the questions</h5>\n<ol>\n<li>Look through the questions first</li>\n<li>Underline key words from the question</li>\n<li>Then scan the text for those key words that you have underlined</li>\n<li>The answer should be found close to that word</li>\n<li>The answers will be found in the text in the same order as the questions</li>\n<li>Things to beware of</li>\n<li>There will be synonyms used in the reading - the words in the IELTS multiple choice questions may not be the same as in the text</li>\n</ol>",

    {
        "content": "<h5>Tips</h5> <p>If the fact you are given is clearly in the reading it is True</p>\n<p>If the reading says the opposite of the fact you've been given it is False</p>\n<p>If it is not true or false, it is Not Given</p> <h5>Strategies to answer the questions</h5>\n<ol>\n<li>The questions follow the order of the text.</li>\n<li>Read the question carefully to make sure you fully understand what it is saying.</li>\n<li>Scan the text to find where the answer is using key words from the question</li>\n<li>When you find where the answer is, read the text carefully to identify if you think it is T, F or NG.</li>\n<li>The questions will probably use synonyms rather than the words in the text.</li>\n<li>Look out for controlling words such as &ldquo;only&rdquo;, &ldquo;all&rsquo;, &ldquo;never&rdquo; etc. For example, if the fact in the question says 'some' and the fact in the text says 'all', then it is F.</li>\n<li>Do not spend a long time looking for the answer to one question; it is probably NG, if you cannot find it.</li>\n<li>Make sure you use the correct code; 'Yes', 'No', 'No Information' is sometimes used (these question are slightly different and you look for opinions rather than facts).</li>\n</ol> <h5>Example</h5>\n<p>Look at this statment, taken from the first sentence in the reading below:</p>\n<p><span style=\"color: #ff6600;\">\"Chiles originate in South America and have been eaten for at least 9,500 years.\"</span></p>\n<ol>\n<li>Here are some example IELTS True False Not Given statements with answers:</li>\n<li>Chiles come from South America - True</li>\n<li>People began eating Chiles in the last few centuries - False</li>\n<li>South Americans were the first people to start eating Chiles - Not Given</li>\n</ol>\n<p><span style=\"color: #0000ff;\"><strong>Result &amp; Explanation:</strong></span></p>\n<ol>\n<li>Number one is clearly true. Notice the use of the synonym 'come from' used instead of 'originates'. It is common to use different words.</li>\n<li>Two is clearly false as it was 9,500 years ago, not a few 100 years ago.</li>\n<li>Three is not in the text. Be careful about making assumptions then thinking it is true. It is quite probable that South Americans began eating Chiles first as they originated there; however, you can't be sure of that and the text does not tell you that.</li>\n</ol>",

        "content": "<h5>Identifying the question type</h5>\n<p>Before you start any reading passage, you should firstly take a look at the question stems to get an idea of what you may need to look out for.</p>\n<p><span style=\"color: #0000ff;\">1. So now look at the IELTS reading multiple choice questions below this reading.</span></p>\n<ol>\n<li>If you look at the question stems, you will see that names are often mentioned e.g.James Alan Fox, John J. DiIulio, Michael Tonry. So this immediately tells you it is a good idea to underline 'names' as you read the text.</li>\n<li>You will then be able to quickly scan the text later to find where the answers are.</li>\n<li>Looking at the question stems first also gives you an idea of what the reading is about.</li>\n</ol>\n<p><span style=\"color: #0000ff;\">2. Underline / highlight key words</span></p>\n<ol>\n<li>As you read the text, you should get into the habit of highlighting words that you think may be important and will help you find answers later.</li>\n<li>These are often nouns like names, dates, numbers or any other key words that stand out as a key topic of that paragraph.</li>\n<li>Looking at the IELTS reading multiple choice questions quickly first may help with this.</li>\n</ol>\n<h5>IELTS Reading Multiple Choice Questions</h5>\n<p>This type of question follows the order of the text. So when you have found one answer, you know that the next one will be below, and probably not too far away.</p>\n<p>When you start looking at the questions, you should underline key words in the question stem to help you find the answers in the text.</p>\n<p>Look at the IELTS reading multiple choice questions again - as you will see, key words have been highlighted. You can use these to help you scan the text to find the answers more quickly.</p>\n<p><span style=\"color: #0000ff;\">Reading in detail</span></p>\n<p>When you read the text for the first time, you should focus on the topic sentences, and skim the rest of the paragraph.</p>\n<p>But once you start answering the IELTS reading multiple choice questions and you have found where the answer is, you will need to read the text carefully in order to identify the correct choice.</p>\n<p>Tip: Do not think that just because you have found some words in the multiple choices (a, b or c) that match the words in the text that this must be the right answer.</p>\n<p>It's usually not that simple so you must read the section where you think the answer is carefully.</p>\n",

        "content": "<p>In summary completion question types, you will be given a summary of information from the text and there will be some gaps in that summary.</p>\n<p>You will either  be given a list of words to fill the gaps with or asked to find the answers in the reading text.</p>\n<p>Your job is to insert some of the words from the list into the gaps, or if asked, to fill the gaps with words from the text.</p>\n<p>There will be more words in the list than required to fill the gaps.</p>\n<p>All of the information contained in the summary will also be contained in the reading text, but they will use  synonyms and paraphrasing, so don&rsquo;t expect to see the same words.</p>\n<p>Summary completion questions test your ability:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>to understand the general meaning of the summary</li>\n<li>to scan for the correct information in the text</li>\n<li>to be able to identify synonyms and paraphrases</li>\n</ul>\n<p><strong>Summary Completion Common Problems</strong></p>\n<p>This question does not expect you to have a detailed understanding of the text. Some students lose lots of time reading the whole text and trying to understand everything. You don&rsquo;t need to do this, focus more on the summary in the question.</p>\n<p>Some students read the summary and then look for the exact same words in the reading text. You are unlikely to find these because the examiners use  synonyms and paraphrasing.</p>\n<p>A common mistake is to ignore grammar rules when completing the summary. If the sentence does not make sense grammatically, then you have the wrong answer.</p>\n<p>The examiners also try to trick you by putting a word from the text as one of the options. Some students recognise this and think this is the correct answer. It is probably wrong because the answer will normally be a synonym rather than a matching word.</p>\n<p><strong>Summary Completion Tips</strong></p>\n<ol>\n<li>Try to predict the answers before you look at the options or the text. This will help you spot the correct answer.</li>\n<li>Should the gap be filled with a verb, noun, adjective or adverb? If your answer makes the sentence grammatically wrong, then you have the wrong answer.</li>\n<li>Look for synonyms and paraphrases in the text rather than words that directly match.</li>\n<li>Don&rsquo;t spend too much time looking for the answer to one question. If you can&rsquo;t find it, mark what you think it might be and move on. Focusing on the easier answers is a better use of your time.</li>\n<li>The answers normally come in the same order as the questions.</li>\n<li>If you get a list of words, think about the ones that can&rsquo;t be the correct answer because of meaning or grammar. You can then eliminate these words.</li>\n</ol>\n<p><strong>Summary Completion Strategy  </strong></p>\n<p>This is my suggested strategy. There are many different strategies and you should use the one you feel comfortable with. You can also adapt this strategy to what suits you.</p>\n<ol>\n<li>Read the question carefully. Note how many words you can write (normally one, two or three) and if you should get the words from the reading text or a list.</li>\n<li>Skim  the summary and try to understand the overall meaning.</li>\n<li>Try to predict the answers before you look at the reading text. Also, think about the word type (noun, verb, adjective) that should be included.</li>\n<li>If you have a list of words, try to guess which 2 or 3 the answer  might be. Pay attention to words that collocate well with the words in the sentence.</li>\n<li>Identify which part of the reading text  the summary relates to. Scanning for synonyms from the summary will help you do this.</li>\n<li>Look at that part of the section more carefully and choose the correct answer. Remember to be careful with synonyms.</li>\n<li>Check to see if your word makes the sentence  grammatically correct.</li>\n</ol>",

        "section": "Reading",

        "sub_topic": "",
        "title": "Summary Completion",

        "content": "<p>There are three kinds of diagrams you might get: a technical drawing of a machine or invention, something from the natural world or a design or plan.</p>\n<p><strong>Common Problems</strong></p>\n<p>The main problem with these questions is students focus too much on the diagram and try  to understand everything about it.  Unfamiliar diagrams can cause panic and lose you time. This is not a test of your technical knowledge but a test of your reading skills. You should try to understand generally what is happening in the diagram,  but the  relationship between the text and the diagram is more important.</p>\n<p>Another big problem is failing to locate the paragraphs that contain the answers quickly and losing time reading the whole text.</p>\n<p>Students also lose marks in this section by writing the wrong number of words or spelling words incorrectly.</p>\n<p><strong>Tips  </strong></p>\n<ol>\n<li>Check how many words you are supposed to write, it will tell you in the question. In the example above you can only write &lsquo;one or two words&rsquo;, any more than this and you will lose  marks. Remember that  numbers count as one word and hyphenated words like &lsquo;state-of-the-art&rsquo; count as one word.</li>\n<li>  Identify the type of word (noun, verb, adjective) you need. This will help you find the correct answer.</li>\n<li>The answers do not always come in the same order that the paragraphs are in.</li>\n<li>Do the easiest questions first. You are more likely to get these correct. If you cannot find the answer to a difficult question, move on and come back later.</li>\n<li>Try to predict the answer before you read the text. This will help you find the correct answer.</li>\n</ol>\n<p><strong>Strategy</strong></p>\n<ol>\n<li>Check how many words you can write.</li>\n<li>Study  the diagram and try to understand generally what is happening. Don&rsquo;t spend too much time doing this.</li>\n<li>Highlight keywords or labels.</li>\n<li>Identify the types of words required and try to predict the answer.</li>\n<li>Scan the text and identify where the information is located.</li>\n<li>Read in more detail to find the answer.</li>\n<li>Check spelling.</li>\n</ol>",

        "content": "",
        "main_topic": "Reading Skills",
        "remark": "",
        "section": "Reading",
        "source": "",
        "sub_topic": "",
        "title": "",
        "topic": ""
    },
    {
        "content": "<p><strong>Skimming and scanning</strong>  are two very effective (yet different) strategies for  <strong>speed-reading</strong>.</p>\n<p>What is speed-reading? You may be used to read every word slowly and carefully to understand every sentence of the text. But on IELTS Reading test, you are limited in time and it&rsquo;s impossible to read attentively all the information. But how to read more, in less time? One way is to use  <em><u>speed-reading</u>  - quickly read the text according to your purpose, getting only the information you need</em>.</p> <h5>Skimming</h5>\n<p><strong>Skimming</strong>  means  <em>quickly reading the text to get only its main idea</em>. To skim effectively, you need to  <u>read only a part of the material</u>.</p>\n<p>You have already encountered skimming: when reading a long chapter of a book, or doing a research on a long article. In such case, you would probably read the first sentences of each paragraph, dropping down to the end of the paragraph.</p>\n<h5>How to skim?</h5>\n<ol>\n<li>Read the first paragraph attentively to get an idea of what will be discussed in the text.</li>\n<li>Read the first (and sometimes the second) sentence of each paragraph - they give the main idea of the paragraph.</li>\n<li>After you have read the first sentences, your eyes should drop down to the end of the paragraph, looking for important pieces of information, such as dates and names.</li>\n<li>Read the last paragraph attentively as it may contain the summary.</li>\n</ol>",
        "main_topic": "Reading Skills",
        "remark": "",
        "section": "Reading",
        "source": " ieltsup",
        "sub_topic": "",
        "title": "Skimming",
        "topic": ""
    },
    {
        "content": "<h5>Scanning</h5>\n<p><strong>Scanning</strong>  means  <em>searching for specific phrases in the text to answer some questions</em>.</p>\n<h5>Underline!</h5>\n<p>The questions on IELTS Reading test often include  <strong>dates</strong>,  <strong>names</strong>,  <strong>numbers</strong>,  <strong>new terms</strong>  or other  <strong>key words</strong>. So it&rsquo;s a very good idea to  <u>underline those key words</u>  while reading, so you could find the answers in the text more easily.</p> <h5>How to scan?</h5>\n<ol>\n<li>Underline the important information while reading the text (dates, numbers, names etc.)</li>\n<li>When you read the question, identify the key word and scan the text for it. This way you&rsquo;ll find the answer more quickly.</li>\n</ol>",

        "remark": "",
        "section": "Reading",
        "source": " ieltsup",
        "sub_topic": "",
        "title": "Scanning",
        "topic": ""

    {
        "content": "<h5>Skimming and Scanning Practice</h5>\n<p>Now it's time for practice. Like on a real IELTS Reading test, you have to read the text and answer the questions below.</p>\n<p>First of all, let's practise  <strong>skimming</strong>. When reading a text for the first time, you should skim over it to  <strong>grasp the main idea</strong>. In this example,  <em>read the  <span style=\"background-color: #ffff99;\">highlighted</span> text  and quickly look over the rest of the text</em>  (you have about 1-2 minutes):</p>\n \n<div class=\"exam-text\">\n<div class=\"exam-text\">\n<p style=\"font-weight: bold;\" align=\"center\">Are electric cars really eco-friendly?</p>\n<p><span style=\"background-color: #fffacd;\">Electric-car drivers are saving the planet, right? Their vehicles produce none of the pollutants that dinosaur-burning, fossil-fuel-powered machines do. That is the standard view, and governments around the world provide incentives to encourage the uptake of this new technology.</span></p>\n<p><span style=\"background-color: #fffacd;\">That is why a Tesla owner got a rude shock when he went to import his vehicle into Singapore - the first person to do so.</span> The Tesla Model S is a 100% electric vehicle. It does not have an exhaust to emit from. So what happened?</p>\n<p><span style=\"background-color: #fffacd;\">Instead of an expected rebate of around S$15,000 (US$10,800) he received a fine of the same amount for being a gross polluter.</span> The company commented the incident, \"The Model S that our customer imported into Singapore left our factory only two years ago with energy consumption rated at 181 Wh/km. This qualifies as the cleanest possible category of car in Singapore and entitles the owner to an incentive rather than a fine.\"</p>\n<p><span style=\"background-color: #fffacd;\">The Singapore authorities calculated the &lsquo;carbon cost&rsquo; of generating the electricity that will be used to charge the car.</span> This is the elephant in the trunk of electric vehicles. Where and how the power is produced is not often considered, but perhaps it should be. Let&rsquo;s move the elephant up to the passenger seat and address it directly.</p>\n<p><span style=\"background-color: #fffacd;\">The authorities in Singapore apparently found the Tesla in question consumes 444 watt-hours of electricity per km (Wh/km) in tests.</span> Without wanting to get too maths-heavy, the number of <span style=\"background-color: #fffacd;\">444Wh/km does seem high</span>. And as we still need power stations to produce such amount electric energy, the environmental impact is not so small as it seemed to be.</p>\n<p><span style=\"background-color: #fffacd;\">But what about the bigger picture - should we be factoring in the emissions of power stations when working out how green an electric car is? The logical answer is yes. Emissions shifted elsewhere are still emissions, and CO2 impacts the global atmosphere wherever it is released.</span></p>\n</div>\n<p>Now let&rsquo;s look at the questions:</p>\n<p>1. What is the aim of this text?</p>\n<ol type=\"A\">\n<li>To discourage people from visiting Singapore</li>\n<li>To prove that electric cars are less eco-friendly than fossil-fuel-powered machines</li>\n<li>To show that we need to count the emissions of power stations to see how green an electric car is.</li>\n</ol>\n<p>This question can be answered immediately after you  <strong>skimmed over</strong>  the text. Here, you&rsquo;re required to understand only the main idea of the passage.</p>\n<p>Obviously, the  <strong>correct answer is C</strong>. It&rsquo;s also stated in the last paragraph:</p>\n<p class=\"text-extract\">But what about the bigger picture - should we be  <u>factoring in the emissions of power stations when working out how green an electric car is</u>? The logical answer is  <u>yes</u>.</p>\n \n<p>2. When the owner of the electric car went to Singapore, he received</p>\n<ol type=\"A\">\n<li>a rebate of around US$10,800</li>\n<li>a fine of around US$10,800</li>\n<li>a fine of around US$15,000</li>\n</ol>\n<p>And this question, unlike the previous one, requires specific detail: amount of money. To answer it, you should  <strong>scan the text for words $10,800 and $15,000</strong>. Don&rsquo;t read the text again! Just search these two key words. Once you have found the right sentence, read it attentively to get the answer.</p>\n<p>The sentence that contains these key words is in the third paragraph:</p>\n<p class=\"text-extract\">Instead of an expected rebate of around  <u>S$15,000</u>  (<u>US$10,800</u>) he received a fine of the same amount for being a gross polluter.</p> <p>Now it&rsquo;s clear to us that the  <strong>correct answer is B</strong>.</p>\n \n<p>3. To prove that electric car was a gross polluter, the authorities in Singapore calculated the ...................... of generating the electricity to charge the car.</p>\n \n<p>After you skimmed over the article, you should know that the  <u>Singapore authorities</u>  and  <u>charging car</u>  were mentioned somewhere in the middle of the text. Moreover, you have another clue:  <em>the answer should be after the answer to the question 3</em>. You can find the right answer by these key words:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>authorities in Singapore</li>\n<li>electricity to charge the car</li>\n</ul> <p>If you  <strong>scan</strong>  the text for these key words, and you will find the answer in the fourth paragraph:</p>\n<p class=\"text-extract\">  The Singapore authorities calculated the &lsquo;carbon cost&rsquo; of generating the electricity that will be used to charge the car.</p> <p>The correct answer is  <strong>carbon cost</strong>.</p>\n</div>",
