        "content": "<p>All of the information in this section applies to both the Academic and General Training IELTS Reading exams. Let&rsquo;s start with some important keys to success:</p> <p><strong>Pacing</strong></p>\n<p>Pacing is critical in order to do well on the IELTS Reading paper. This is especially true for the Academic IELTS, but it also applies to the General Training Reading exam. Sixty minutes is not a lot of time get through all of the passages and answer 40 questions. Since each question is worth the same amount of points (1), it makes most sense to divide the 3 sections equally&mdash;spending 20 minutes per section.</p> <p>Instead of reading each passage carefully, it works much better for most people to &ldquo;skim&rdquo; the Reading passages. This is something we will discuss in detail in the &ldquo;Strategy&rdquo; section of this post below. I advise my students to spend 3 to 5 minutes quickly skimming the passage before looking at the questions. That leaves 15 to 17 minutes to study the questions and find answers in the text.</p> <p>Note: Unlike the Listening exam, you do not have an extra 10 minutes to transfer answers from your Test Booklet to your Answer Sheet. On the Reading paper, you need to record all of your final answers on the Answer Sheet within 60 minutes.</p> <p><strong>Scoring</strong></p>\n<p>Scoring is fairly simple on the Reading section. Each question is worth 1 point, so you can achieve a &ldquo;raw&rdquo; score of up to 40 points. From there, IELTS converts your &ldquo;raw&rdquo; score into your Band score. You can find a basic band score conversion table on the official IELTS website. However, keep in mind that each version of the IELTS is slightly different. The tables can give you a general idea about how &ldquo;raw&rdquo; Reading scores are converted to band scores.</p> <p>It is also important to keep in mind that the hardest questions and the easiest questions count equally towards your final Reading score. Therefore, if you&rsquo;re struggling to finish all of the questions within 60 minutes, make sure you&rsquo;re not losing out on easier points because you get stuck on hard questions. Sometimes, you simply won&rsquo;t understand a question or a segment within a passage fully. Other times, no matter how hard you try, you won&rsquo;t find an answer in the text. If this happens, just make your best guess and move on so you don&rsquo;t miss out on easier points later in the test! You can always return to a difficult question later if you have spare time at the end.</p> <p><strong>Vocabulary</strong></p>\n<p>The more vocabulary you know, the easier the IELTS Reading exam will be for you. Vocabulary is very, very important if you&rsquo;re aiming for a high Band score. As you prepare for the exam, make sure to study new words regularly. Your goal should be to learn 15 to 20 new words each day.</p> <p>Also, try to read in English regularly (15 to 20 minutes per day at least!). It&rsquo;s an excellent idea to keep a vocabulary journal as you read. Record new and unfamiliar words, and then define each one with a synonym or short definition. Keep it simple. You should return to your list a few times each week to review, focusing attention on terms you have difficulty remembering. Additionally, Magoosh offers a Vocabulary Flashcard app and a Vocabulary PDF word list for the IELTS. (Bonus: They&rsquo;re both free!) No matter how you prefer to review vocabulary, study a little bit every day!</p> <p><strong>Focus on the Directions</strong></p>\n<p>Attention to detail is very important on the IELTS Reading paper. Unfortunately, too many test-takers lose points unnecessarily because they don&rsquo;t pay close attention to the directions. The directions for each task will tell you how to mark answers on your Answer Sheet. For example, some questions require numerals (i, ii, iii, iv, v, etc), while others require letters (A, B, C, etc). Short Answer questions are even more complicated. The directions may say something like, &ldquo;Choose NO MORE THAN THREE WORDS from the passage.&rdquo;</p> <p>Each set of questions will have its own instructions telling you how to mark your answers. As you practice, get into the habit of looking at these instructions every time. You don&rsquo;t want to miss points because you didn&rsquo;t notice a key detail in the directions.</p>",
        "main_topic": "Reading Skills",
        "remark": "",
        "section": "Reading",
        "source": " magoosh",
        "sub_topic": "",
        "title": "IELTS Reading Tips: Keys to Success",
        "topic": ""
    },
    {
        "content": "<p>The IELTS Reading exam is probably different than the English reading tests you&rsquo;ve taken in school. Most of the time, reading exams involve carefully reading a passage from beginning to end, and then answering comprehension questions about it. In theory, this is also what you should do on the IELTS Reading paper.</p> <p>In practice, this approach doesn&rsquo;t work very well for most people. The reason is simple&mdash;there simply isn&rsquo;t enough time on the IELTS Reading paper to read each passage slowly and carefully AND answer all of the questions. This is especially true on the Academic IELTS, where you only have 60 minutes to read 3 long and complex passages. On the General Training IELTS, it may be possible to read each passage carefully if you are a proficient reader. Nevertheless, I still recommend a different approach. Try these strategies as you practice:</p> <p><strong>Strategy 1:</strong> Skim each passage for 3 to 5 minutes before looking at the questions.</p>\n<p>Learning to skim a passage effectively can save you a lot of time. To skim, simply look over each paragraph quickly, but in a strategic way. You should read the first line or two of each paragraph normally, but then you should go over the rest much faster. As you skim, you&rsquo;re trying to notice words that stand out because they seem important. This helps you to get the &ldquo;gist,&rdquo; or the basic sense of each paragraph.</p> <p>The ultimate goal of skimming is to notice things in the text that will help you answer questions. You may find people&rsquo;s names, or important dates. You may also figure out how a passage is organized.</p> <p>For example, imagine you are reading a historical text. Often, historical passages are organized chronologically, from the beginning of a time period to the end. Skimming effectively will help you to notice this organizational pattern, and this knowledge will most likely help you to find answers to questions more quickly. Any time you get a question that includes a date or time reference, you&rsquo;ll know where to look because you&rsquo;ve skimmed the passage effectively.</p> <p>Here is a summary of the key skimming techniques you should master:</p> <p>Notice the title of the passage. It often gives you a general idea about the main idea of the text.</p>\n<p>Read the first sentence or two of each paragraph. Often, this is where the main idea of each paragraph is located.</p>\n<p>Underline words that stand out to you as important. This will help you get a general idea of what is being talked about.</p>\n<p>Pick out words that have something in common (i.e., airports, passengers, lounge, fly).</p>\n<p>Ignore words that you do not know. Focusing on words that are unfamiliar to you will slow you down.</p>\n<p>At all times, try not to get caught up in the detail when you skim!</p> <p><strong>Strategies 2 and 3:</strong> As you skim, underline keywords in the text and write short notes as reminders in the text.</p>\n<p>Strategies 2 and 3 work together with the skimming strategy above. Basically, the goal of &ldquo;underlining&rdquo; and taking &ldquo;notes&rdquo; as you skim is that this helps you remember what you learned when you go to answer questions. It&rsquo;s very simple. Here&rsquo;s what you should do:</p> <p>As you skim, quickly underline each word that seems important in your Question Booklet (which contains your Reading passage). In other words, don&rsquo;t just skim with your eyes. Use your pencil to underline things that stand out as you skim the passage.</p> <p>Secondly, as you skim, quickly write very short notes (2-5 words) next to each paragraph with your best guess about the main idea of that paragraph. You don&rsquo;t have to be comprehensive or even 100% right about your &ldquo;guess&rdquo; in order for it to be useful. To be sure, if you had time to read the paragraph carefully, you could almost certainly come up with very good and accurate summary notes. But you might be surprised how close you can come to the main idea of each paragraph just from skimming.</p> <p><strong>Strategy 4:</strong> Study the questions, noting keywords, and SCAN the text strategically for answers</p>\n<p>After you&rsquo;ve thoroughly skimmed the text, you&rsquo;re ready to turn to the questions. Each question type is slightly different, so you&rsquo;ll have to vary your approach in some ways for each new set of questions. However, the strategy discussed in this section applies to them all. The basic concept is simple: First, read the questions carefully and look for keywords. Then, you scan the passage for answers.</p> <p>When you look for keywords in the questions, you should underline the most important ones. This may sound like a lot of extra work, but it really shouldn&rsquo;t require a lot of time. As you read, simply use your pencil to mark up the questions.</p> <p>These keywords provide the concepts for which you&rsquo;ll need to search in the passage. As you&rsquo;re probably aware, IELTS questions almost never use the same language as the actual reading passage (except for incorrect answer choices!). Instead, the questions will be paraphrases of information found in the article. This is one way the IELTS tests your vocabulary.</p> <p>Paraphrases will be synonyms or different forms of words found in the text. A paraphrase could also be an entire sentence that conveys the same meaning as a sentence in the passage, while using different words and sentence structures. When you underline keywords in the questions, you&rsquo;re identifying the IDEAS you need to search for in the passage.</p> <p>Use a strategic approach when you scan the reading passage for answers. It&rsquo;s best to begin with questions that have keywords you think you can find easily in the text. When you answer questions that are &ldquo;easy&rdquo; to locate, you will learn a little more about what is contained in the Reading passage because you had to read some segments closely to confirm your answers. This process continues with each question you answer. It is possible (and fairly common!) to find an answer to a different question than the one you&rsquo;re searching for at that moment.</p> <p>What makes one question easier to scan for in the text than another? Perhaps a question stands out to you because you remember seeing the topic in the text when you skimmed, underlined, and took notes at the very beginning. But there are some other things that can make an answer easier to find by scanning. For example, numbers and proper nouns like names or locations often stand out visually in a text. A date like 1950, and the names Jane Smith and New York City would be very easy to locate among other words. Once you find the words you&rsquo;re looking for, read the surrounding sentences carefully to find the answer to your question.</p>",

        "content": "<p>This lesson has  <strong>IELTS listening multiple choice tips</strong>  and strategies to improve your score in the test.  </p>\n<p>It shows you how to approach this type of question and highlights some aspects that you should be aware of.</p>\n<p>In this type of question you are usually given three choices of answers. It is commonly found in parts two, three and four of the listening test.</p>\n<p>The questions will be harder the further on you get in the sections of the test.</p>\n<p>There are certain things in this kind of question that can easily trip you up and lead to mistakes. Learning about these will improve your ability to listen and identify the correct answer.</p>\n<p>There are several reasons why this type of question can be difficult and we'll now look at some IELTS listening multiple choice tips to help you understand this.</p>\n<h5><strong>What are the difficulties with IELTS Listening Multiple Choice Questions?</strong></h5>\n<p><strong><em>Hearing all the words</em></strong></p>\n<blockquote>\n<p>In this type of question, it is very likely that you will hear ALL the words that you are given in each choice. Two will obviously not be referring to the answer, so you need to listen very carefully to make sure you get the correct one.</p>\n</blockquote>\n<p><strong><em>Similar Choices</em></strong></p>\n<blockquote>\n<p>Another problem is that you may be given very similar choices. For example, all the choices may refer to &lsquo;<em>years</em>&rsquo;, so it is easy to choose the wrong one. Also, the information you hear about each choice may be quite similar.</p>\n</blockquote>\n<p><strong><em>Paraphrases and synonyms</em></strong></p>\n<blockquote>\n<p>Also, sentences and words that you hear in the listening will often be changed in the actual listening script. The test would be quite easy if you could heard exactly what you see in the question, but it will be changed in some way.</p>\n</blockquote>\n<p><strong><em>A different order</em></strong></p>\n<blockquote>\n<p>The person you hear speaking may not necessarily give you the information or choices in the same order as the question you see on the paper.   </p>\n</blockquote>\n<h5><strong>A Real Example of a Question</strong></h5>\n<p>In this next part of the IELTS listening multiple choice tips, we look at an example to explain the points above a bit more.</p>\n<p>This is taken from a real IELTS test. It is from section 2 of the test, so it will be slightly easier than a multiple choice that you would get in sections 3 or 4, but the same principles apply.</p>\n<p>Below the question is the section of the listening script that refers to the question.</p>\n<div>\n<p><strong>\"1.</strong>  PS Camping has been organising holidays for</p>\n<p><strong>         A.</strong>  15 years  <br /><strong>         B.</strong>  20 years  <br /><strong>         C.</strong>  25 years  </p>\n<p style=\"text-align: center;\">____________</p>\n<p><em>Thank you for coming to my talk this evening. It&rsquo;s nice to see so many people in the audience. For those of you who don&rsquo;t know very much about PS Camping, let me start by giving you some background information about the company.<br /></em></p>\n<p><em>The company started twenty five years ago. It actually started as a retail chain selling camping equipment, and then twenty years ago, it bought a small number of campsites in the UK, and began offering camping holidays. The company grew rapidly and has been providing holidays in continental Europe for the last fifteen years.\"</em></p>\n</div>\n<p>So you should be able to spot some of the difficult things:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>You hear  <strong>all the words &ndash;  </strong>25 years, 20 years and 15 years.</li>\n<li>There are  <strong>similarities in the choices -  </strong>they are all years with a mix of the numbers &lsquo;<em>twenty</em>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<em>five</em>&rsquo; in there and they all mention about the company or holidays.</li>\n<li>The question stem has been  <strong>paraphrased</strong>  - nowhere does it say &ldquo;<em>organising holidays</em>&rdquo;. Instead you can see phrases like &ldquo;<em>began offering holidays</em>&rdquo; and &ldquo;<em>providing holidays</em>&rdquo;. This can be particularly confusing because you have to understand which one fits with the question.</li>\n<li>The possible answers are in a  <strong>different order  </strong>to the audio &ndash; you hear &lsquo;<em>25</em>&rsquo; first and &lsquo;<em>15</em>&rsquo; last.</li>\n</ul>\n<h5><strong>How do you answer multiple choice questions?</strong></h5>\n<p>The first thing you need to do is  <strong>look through the questions</strong>. You have 30 seconds to do this before you hear the audio.</p>\n<p>Underline<strong>  key words</strong>  in the question stems and look at the choices so you know what to listen out for.</p>\n<p>So in this first one, you may underline &ldquo;<em>Organised Holidays</em>&rdquo;. You should focus on the question stem but also look at the choices and note that you are listening out for &lsquo;<em>years</em>&rsquo;.</p>\n<p>In this case, this sentence should tell you that you have got to the section of the listening where the answer will be:</p>\n<p>\"<em><strong>The company started twenty five years ago</strong>.  </em><em>It actually started as a retail chain selling camping equipment, and then twenty years ago, it bought a small number of campsites in the UK, and began offering camping holidays. The company grew rapidly and has been providing holidays in continental Europe for the last fifteen years.</em>\"</p>\n<p>So when you hear this, make sure you are  <strong>looking carefully at the question</strong>  and the choices and  <strong>listening extremely carefully</strong>.</p>\n<p>You need to listen carefully for what is said about each year so that you can identify the right answer:</p>\n<blockquote>\n<p><strong>1.  </strong>PS Camping has been organising holidays for:</p>\n<blockquote>\n<p><strong>A.</strong>  15 years<br />[<strong><em>has been providing holidays</em></strong><em>  in continental Europe for the last fifteen years]</em></p>\n<p><strong>B.</strong>  20 years<br />[<em>twenty years ago, it bought a small number of campsites in the UK, and  <strong>began offering camping holidays</strong></em>]</p>\n<p><strong>C.</strong>  25 years<br />[<em>The  <strong>company started</strong>  twenty five years ago]</em></p>\n</blockquote>\n</blockquote>\n<p>You can see how the question tries to trick you!</p>\n<p>It  <strong>distracts you</strong>  from the correct answer by giving other statements that are quite similar to the correct answer.<br /><span id=\"ezoic-pub-ad-placeholder-122\" class=\"ezoic-adpicker-ad\"></span></p>\n<p><span id=\"ezoic-pub-ad-placeholder-115\" class=\"ezoic-adpicker-ad\"></span>The answer is  <strong>B</strong>, but you could easily end up thinking it is  <strong>A</strong>  or  <strong>C</strong>  if you are not listening carefully enough.</p>\n<p>The company  <strong>started</strong>  25 years ago, but that is  <strong>NOT</strong>  when they started offering holidays for camping.</p>\n<p>It later clarifies that they did not start  <strong>offering / organising holidays</strong>  until 5 years later (20 years ago) when they bought a campsite.</p>\n<p>It is not  <strong>A</strong>  because this is just when they starting  <strong>providing holidays</strong>  in Europe, which came later. That is not what the question asks. The question ask generally.</p>",

        "content": "<p>In lesson one we looked at a form of  <strong>IELTS listening distractors</strong>.  </p>\n<p>This was when you do multiple choice type questions and you hear all of the possible choices but only one is correct.</p>\n<p>In this lesson we look at another form of distractor which is very common in part one of the IELTS listening test.  </p>\n<p>This is when you hear a  <strong>speaker correct him/herself</strong>, or the other speaker will correct them.   </p>\n<p>Basically, the speaker will give you a piece of information and you will  <strong>think</strong>  that is the right answer.</p>\n<p>But the speaker will then  <strong>correct what they have said</strong>, and the new corrected piece of information will in fact be the right answer.</p>\n<h5>Examples of Correction Distractors</h5>\n<p>These two examples of distractors are taken from a real IELTS listening test. The distractor is in  <em><span class=\"red\">red / italics  </span></em>and the correct answer is in  <u><span class=\"blue\">blue / underlined</span></u>.<br /></p>\n<p><strong><em>Example 1</em></strong></p>\n<p>In this situation, a woman is booking a journey into town for when she arrives at Toronto Aiport. You have to note down the distance of the town, Milton, from the airport.</p>\n<p>Take a look at the information you have to find in the question. Below that is a copy of the listening script that you would hear.</p>\n<p>\"</p>\n<p><strong>Question</strong>: Distance                             &hellip;.. miles</p>\n<p>************</p>\n<p><strong>MAN:</strong>  Hello, this is Land Transport Information at Toronto Airport. How may I help you?</p>\n<p><strong>WOMAN:</strong>  Oh, good morning. I&rsquo;m flying to Toronto Airport next week, and I need to get to a town called Milton. Could you tell me how I can get there?</p>\n<p><strong>MAN:</strong>  Milton, did you say? Let me see.  <em>I think that&rsquo;s about 150 miles</em>  south-west of here.  <u>In fact it&rsquo;s 147 miles</u>  to be exact, so it will take you at least &ndash; say, three to four hours by road.</p>\n<p>\"</p>\n<p>As you can see, you will likely at first think that the answer is 150 miles, but it is actually 147 miles.</p> <p>  </p>\n<p>  </p>",

        "content": "<p><strong>IELTS listening map labelling</strong>  is common in Section Two of the test, though you may get a map in any of the sections.</p>\n<p>In section two of the IELTS listening test you hear  <strong>one person speaking</strong>. It is quite common for the map to be related to some kind of tour.</p>\n<p>The aim in labelling a map is to connect the information that you hear in the listening to the gaps in the map.</p>\n<p>In some maps you are given a  <strong>list of words</strong>  and you have to choose the correct word to fit in the map.</p>\n<p>Other times, you will just be given some gaps and you need to listen and choose the right word from the listening.</p>\n<p>This lesson is an example of the second type - no list of words are given so you have to identify them yourself.</p>\n<h5>Tips for IELTS Listening Map Labelling</h5>\n<ol>\n<li><span class=\"red\">Read the instructions carefully</span>  - this is so you know what you need to do and the maximum number of words and / or numbers you can use &ndash; in this case it is no more than two words.</li>\n<li><span class=\"red\">Know the vocabulary of location</span>  - you need to know words commonly used to describe where things are located (see below).</li>\n<li><span class=\"red\">Identify where the numbers start and finish</span>  &ndash; as you can see from the example, the first one (15) starts at the bottom, not the top. The numbers (15, 16, 17) will follow the order of the listening.</li>\n<li><span class=\"red\">Understand the context  </span>- listen carefully at the beginning as the speaker will give you the context. (where you are for example) which will help you follow the talk. Also, look over the map. This will help you identify exactly what you are labelling - note the things that are already labelled to get a feel for where things are.</li>\n<li><span class=\"red\">Predict the answers</span>  - as with all the listening test, it helps to predict what the answer may be. Look at the gaps and see if you can guess what you are labelling - a room, building, sports facility, street etc?</li>\n<li><span class=\"red\">Pay particular attention to things close by</span>  - for example, number 15 is by the &lsquo;<em>station</em>&rsquo; so it is quite likely (though not definite) that this will be mentioned just before number 15</li>\n<li><span class=\"red\">Pay attention to any other clues in the map</span>  - for example, you are given a  <em>compass icon</em>  in the corner telling you where &lsquo;<em>North</em>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<em>South</em>&rsquo;, &lsquo;<em>East</em>&rsquo; and &lsquo;<em>West</em>&rsquo; are. This means it is likely that these phrases will be used to direct you. So listen out for them. You are also given your location - in the tower.</li>\n<li><span class=\"red\">Look at two questions at once</span>  - this is something you should always do in the listening test. If you hear the answer to question 16, you will know you missed 15. Forget about this and move on. If you are only looking at 15 you could miss both and get lost.</li>\n</ol>\n<h5>Common Language of Location</h5>\n<p>There can be various phrases to explain where things are, but below are listed some of the most common you'll need for IELTS listening map labelling or diagram labelling.</p>\n<p>Make sure you understand them all.</p>\n<ul>\n<li><em>At the top / at the bottom</em></li>\n<li><em>On the left / on the right</em></li>\n<li><em>Left hand side / right hand side</em></li>\n<li><em>South / North / East / West</em></li>\n<li><em>Southeast / Southwest / Northeast / Northwest</em></li>\n<li><em>To the north / to the south / to the east / to the west</em></li>\n<li><em>Opposite   / in front of / behind</em></li>\n<li><em>In the middle / in the centre</em></li>\n<li><em>Above / below</em></li>\n<li><em>Inside / outside</em></li>\n<li><em>Just beyond / a little beyond / just past</em></li>\n<li><em>Next to / alongside / adjoining (= next to or joined with)</em></li>\n</ul>",

        "title": "IELTS Listening Map Labelling",

    {
        "content": "<p><strong>Signposting language</strong>  is the words and phrases that people use in order to guide the listener coherently through what is being said.  </p>\n<p>It is used to make clear what has just happened, and what is going to happen next.</p>\n<p>So in other words, it acts as a  <strong>guide</strong>  so the listener can follow what you are saying.</p>\n<h5>Why is this important for IELTS?</h5>\n<p>In section 4 of the listening you have to listen to a talk in an  <strong>academic setting</strong>, such as a university.</p>\n<p>It is usually a lecture by a professor, a presentation by a student, or a talk by a university staff member. So it is possible that signposting will be used within this.</p>\n<p>This lesson is designed to help you with  <strong>Section 4 IELTS listenings</strong>  that are a  <strong>lecture</strong>, though the language for a presentation or talk may be the same or similar.</p>\n<p>If you know the type of language that is used to guide you, it will help you to  <strong>follow the lecture</strong>.</p>\n<p>This is particuarly important if your listening skills are weaker than they should be because you will easily get lost if you don't know where you are.</p>\n<p>Also, the lecture may be split into two parts.</p>\n<p>t may be the case that these two sections follow the sections that the speaker divides their talk into i.e. two parts. Knowing then the lecture structure and the language the speaker uses to tell you they are moving onto the second section will help you to follow where you are.</p>\n<p>The signposting language we'll look at in this lesson is the words and phrases that  <strong>introduce the topics</strong>  and  <strong>subsections</strong>  of the lecture.</p> <h5>Examples of Lecture Signposting Language</h5>\n<p>This table sets out some of the key language that guides you on the overall  <strong>topic and content</strong>  of the lecture, and when  <strong>different sections</strong>  of the lecture are being discussed.</p>\n<p>The table includes the signposting language to signal the end of the talk. However you are every unlikly to hear this used in IELTS because as section 4 of the listening is only around 4-5 minutes, you only usually hear the first part of the lecture or presentation.</p>\n<p>Remember there are lots of different ways to say these things, so what you hear could be phrased slightly differently.</p>\n<center>\n<h5>Signposting Examples</h5>\n</center><center>\n<div>\n<table border=\"1\" width=\"500\">\n<tbody>\n<tr>\n<th scope=\"col\" width=\"128\">Purpose</th>\n<th scope=\"col\" width=\"314\">Signpost Language</th>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><strong>Introducing the topic of the lecture</strong></td>\n<td>\n<ul>\n<li>Today we are going to talk about&hellip;</li>\n<li>The topic of today&rsquo;s lecture is&hellip;</li>\n<li>This morning we are going to take a look at&hellip;</li>\n<li>Today I&rsquo;ll be talking about / discussing...</li>\n<li>What I&rsquo;m going to be talking about today is&hellip;</li>\n<li>The purpose of today&rsquo;s lecture is&hellip;</li>\n<li>The subject/topic of my talk is ...</li>\n</ul>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><strong>Explaining the lecture structure (sections / subtopics)</strong></td>\n<td>\n<ul>\n<li>In today&rsquo;s lecture I&rsquo;m going to cover three points.</li>\n<li>I&rsquo;m going to divide this talk into three parts.</li>\n<li>First we&rsquo;ll look at&hellip;.. Then we&rsquo;ll go on to &hellip; And finally I&rsquo;ll&hellip;</li>\n</ul>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><strong>Introducing the first section / subtopic   or first of a list of points</strong></td>\n<td>\n<ul>\n<li>Let&rsquo;s start by talking about...</li>\n<li>To begin,&hellip;</li>\n<li>Firstly,&hellip;</li>\n<li>I&rsquo;ll start with,&hellip;</li>\n<li>The first advantage / reason / cause etc. is...</li>\n</ul>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><strong>Finishing a section</strong></td>\n<td>\n<ul>\n<li>We've looked at...</li>\n<li>I&rsquo;ve talked about&hellip;.</li>\n</ul>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td><strong>Starting a new section</strong></td>\n<td>\n<ul>\n<li>Let&rsquo;s move on to&hellip;</li>\n<li>Now, let&rsquo;s turn to&hellip;</li>\n<li>And I&rsquo;d now like to talk about&hellip;</li>\n<li>The next / second &hellip;</li>\n<li>I'd like now to discuss...</li>\n<li>The next issue/topic/area I&rsquo;d like to focus on &hellip;</li>\n</ul>\n</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td>\n<p><strong>To signal the end of the talk / Summing up</strong></p>\n</td>\n<td>\n<ul>\n<li>To sum up, &hellip;</li>\n<li>So it is clear from what we have discussed today that&hellip;</li>\n<li>I'd like now to recap...</li>\n<li>Let's summarise briefly what we've looked at...  </li>\n<li>In conclusion, &hellip;</li>\n<li>To summarise, &hellip;</li>\n<li>In summary, &hellip;</li>\n<li>Overall, &hellip;</li>\n<li>The three main points are &hellip;  </li>\n</ul>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</tbody>\n</table>\n</div>\n</center>",

        "title": "IELTS Signposting Language for Section 4",

    {
        "content": "<p><strong>Pre-listening activities</strong>  are essential to improve your IELTS listening skills and to improve your score in the test.</p>\n<p>This lesson is about  <strong>predicting the answers</strong>  in the IELTS listening test. This skill is an important one to learn as it helps you to get the correct answer.</p>\n<p>In this lesson we will look at it in relation to a '<strong>Note Completion</strong>' task, which you will often see in Section 1, the easiest part of the test.</p>\n<p>Prediction though can be used for any type of question where you have to fill in a gap, so it can apply to other parts of the test.</p>\n<h5>Pre-Listening Activities Practice</h5>\n<p>Before each listening section, you have some time to look at the questions.</p>\n<p>You should use this time to look through the questions and get an idea of what you are going to be listening for and when it is a gap filling exercise you should try to predict the types of thing you need to be listening for.</p>\n<p>This will help with your listening ability.</p>\n<p>Take a look at the notes on  <em>Library Membership</em>, and try to predict the information that you may need.</p>\n<p>Which questions may need:</p>\n<blockquote>\n<p><em>a) a number?</em></p>\n<p><em>b) a name (of a person)?</em></p>\n<p><em>c) a place?</em></p>\n<p><em>d) a date or day/month/year?</em></p>\n<p><em>e) another word?</em></p>\n</blockquote>\n<p>In order to prepare you for the listening, write a  <strong>letter</strong>  <em>(</em><em>  a, b, c, d, or e)</em>  in the box to indicate what type of information you think you will hear:</p>\n<center>\n<h5>Library Membership</h5>\n</center> <p>Minimum joining age: 18 years</p>\n<p>For registration must take:</p>\n<ul>\n<li>Two<strong>  (1)</strong>  <input size=\"5\" type=\"text\" />  and</li>\n<li>Two forms of ID e.g. driving licence  <strong>(2)</strong>  <input size=\"5\" type=\"text\" /></li>\n</ul>\n<p>Cost to join per year (without current student card:<strong>  (3)</strong>  <input size=\"5\" type=\"text\" /></p>\n<p>Number of items allowed: (member of public)  <strong>(4)</strong>  <input size=\"5\" type=\"text\" /></p>\n<p>Loan Times: four weeks</p>\n<p>Fines start at:<strong>  (5)</strong>  &pound;  <input size=\"5\" type=\"text\" /></p> <center>________________</center> <p>Computers can be booked up to  <strong>(6)  </strong><input size=\"5\" type=\"text\" />  hours in advance</p>\n<p>Library holds most national papers,  <strong>(7)</strong>  <input size=\"5\" type=\"text\" />  , and magazines</p>\n<p>Need  <strong>(8)</strong>  <input size=\"5\" type=\"text\" />  to use photocopier</p>\n<p><strong>Creative Writing Class</strong></p>\n<p>Tutor is John  <strong>(9)  </strong><input size=\"5\" type=\"text\" /></p>\n<p>Held on  <strong>(10)</strong>  <input size=\"5\" type=\"text\" />  evenings</p>\n<h5>Other Words</h5>\n<p>It is not just though about guessing whether it is a  <em>number, name</em>  etc. You should also try to predict what some of the  <em>'other words</em>' will be.</p>\n<p>You may find you can guess some correctly without even listening (though of course you must listen to check you are right!).</p>\n<p>For example, in question  <strong>(1)</strong>  you need  <strong>two of something</strong>  along with the  <em>ID for registration</em>.</p>\n<p>What do you often need to take '<em>two of</em>' to register for something? You should be able to guess.</p>\n<p>Or for question  <strong>(2)</strong>  it will be another form of ID. What kind of things can you use for ID apart from a driving licence?</p>\n<p>Again, you should be able to guess some possibilties without even listening.</p>\n<h5><strong>Beware of Distractors!</strong></h5>\n<p>Unfortunately it is never going to be made too simple for you as the aim is to separate those with weaker skills from those with stronger skills.</p>\n<p>For most questions, you are likely to hear  <strong>two or more possibilities</strong>  for the answer.</p>\n<p>For example, in question  <strong>(3)</strong>  you are looking for the  <em>cost</em>  <strong>without</strong>  a current student card. That means you are very likely to hear the  <em>cost</em><strong>  with</strong>  one as well. So you need to listen carefully to get the right one.</p>\n<p>Again, in question  <strong>(4)  </strong>you are asked about the  <em>number of items allowed</em>  for a  <strong>member of the public</strong>. So there is probably a different number for a  <strong>student</strong>. You need to get the right number.</p>\n<p><span id=\"ezoic-pub-ad-placeholder-115\" class=\"ezoic-adpicker-ad\"></span>This will be true of probably many of the questions - you will hear  <strong>more than one choice</strong>  but only one will be correct.</p>\n<p>If you knew a number was coming up and there was just one number given, it would be too easy!</p>\n<p>Now take a listen and try to answer the questions. Remember:</p>\n<ul>\n<li><em>read the instructions carefully for the word/number limits for each question</em></li>\n<li><em>write the words exactly as you hear them (don't change them)</em></li>\n<li><em>make sure your spelling is correct</em></li>\n</ul>\n<center></center>",

        "section": "Listening",
        "source": " IELTS Buddy",
        "sub_topic": "",
        "title": "IELTS Pre-Listening Activities - Predicting the Answer",
        "topic": ""

    {
        "content": "<p>These IELTS listening sentence completion strategies will help you to improve your score for the exam.</p>\n<p>In this type of question, you are given a sentence taken from the listening, and you have to decide which word fits in the gap.</p>\n<p>Remember though that the sentence will not be exactly the same as what you hear on the audio - it will be paraphrased (using different words to what you hear).</p>\n<p>The listening excerpt from this page is from a real test. It is from  <strong>Part 4</strong>  of the test - the most difficult - so expect to find this exercise hard.</p>\n<p>Don't be disheartened if you do not do well - students often score poorly on part 4, but that does not mean you can't get a good score from doing well in the other sections.  </p>\n<p>Part 4 is based on a  <strong>lecture</strong>, and for this recording you are going to hear the second part of a lecture on the luxury end of the hospitality and tourism market.  </p>\n<h5>IELTS Listening Sentence Completion Strategies</h5>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>Look  </strong>through the sentences before you start to get an idea of what you will be hearing.</li>\n<li><strong>Pay</strong>  particular attention to the words that come before and after the gap to help you notice when the word is spoken.</li>\n<li><strong>Try</strong>  to guess what may go in the gap - is it a place, name, number, or something else?</li>\n<li><strong>Remember</strong>  that the words you see in the sentence may be synonyms of the words from the audio, so you may be listening out for words with similar meanings.</li>\n<li><strong>Write</strong>  the exact words, phrases or numbers that you hear in the gap on your question paper.</li>\n<li><strong>Always</strong>  check the word limit - your answer will be marked wrong if you exceed the number of words allowed.</li>\n</ul>\n<center></center>",

    {
        "content": "<ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Predict the topic</span></strong>  &ndash; it helps you to listen if you know what kind of conversation is taking place so you can picture it in your head. So look through each section in the time you are given and make sure you have an idea of who is speaking to who and what the context is.</li>\n</ul> <ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Predict the questions</span></strong>  &ndash; you should also try and have an idea of what kind of information you are listening out for. For example, in section one you often have to listen for names, numbers and addresses. Have a look at the questions in the time you are given and work out what needs to go in the space. A name? Number? An address? You are more likely to catch it then when the answer arises.</li>\n</ul>",
        "main_topic": "IELTS Listening Tips",
        "remark": "",
        "section": "Listening",
        "source": " IELTS Buddy",
        "sub_topic": "",
        "title": "Predicting Skills",
        "topic": ""
    },
    {
        "content": "<ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Use a minute to look through each section</span></strong>  &ndash; you are given 30 seconds at the end of each section to check your answers. You are then told to turn over and look at the next section for 30 seconds. Although some IELTS listening tips will tell you to check what you have written, there is little you can check for the previous section as you can&rsquo;t hear the listening again. So instead, turn straight to the next section. You will then have one minute (instead of 30 seconds) to look through the next section. This is time better spent.</li>\n</ul> <ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Careful with question order</span></strong>  &ndash; often you have a table to complete, and sometimes a diagram or chart. The questions will not necessarily go from left to right, so check the progression carefully otherwise you will get lost and confused.</li>\n</ul> <ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Look at two questions at once</span></strong>  &ndash; there are two reasons for doing this. Firstly, some questions may have the answers close together in one sentence so you could miss one if you only look at one question at a time. Also, it is possible that you will miss an answer &ndash; if you are just looking at one, you may not know that you missed it. If you are also looking at the next, you&rsquo;ll see that it has moved on.</li>\n</ul>",
        "main_topic": "IELTS Listening Tips",
        "remark": "",
        "section": "Listening",
        "source": " IELTS Buddy",
        "sub_topic": "",
        "title": "Understanding the format and questions",
        "topic": ""
    },
    {
        "content": "<ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Move on if you miss an answer</span></strong>  &ndash; if you do realise you have missed an answer, quickly forget about it and concentrate on the next ones. There is nothing you can do, and you can also guess when you transfer your answers to the answer sheet at the end. The same applies if you realise you missed two or three answers. Don&rsquo;t panic and just move on as there is nothing you can do. A few questions missed may not necessarily affect your band score.</li>\n</ul> <ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Watch others if you&rsquo;re completely lost</span></strong>  &ndash; if you completely lose where you are, then watch when the other candidates turn over their exam papers. You&rsquo;ll know then that you are back in the right place.</li>\n</ul>",

        "content": "<ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Look out for paraphrasing</span></strong>  &ndash; remember that what you hear will most likely not be exactly the same as is written on the exam paper as that would be too easy. The question and the question stems use such things as synonyms so you must listen carefully for these.</li>\n</ul> <ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Ignore words you don&rsquo;t know</span></strong>  &ndash; don&rsquo;t worry or panic if you hear a word that you do not know. It may not be necessary to know it anyway, or you can take a guess.</li>\n</ul> <ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Underline key words</span></strong>  &ndash; when you look through the questions first, particularly in the more difficult parts 3 and 4, underline key words (such as names, places and dates) in the question stems to help you hear the answer. Remember though, as explained above, synonyms are often used.</li>\n</ul>",

    {
        "content": "<ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Take care with spelling and grammar</span></strong>  &ndash; your answer will be marked wrong if it is spelt incorrectly or the grammar does not fit. So when you transfer your answers at the end, double check these. The sentence on the exam paper may help you with the grammar &ndash; does it fit grammatically? Should it be a verb, noun, adjective?</li>\n</ul> <ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Use British or American spelling</span></strong>  &ndash; this is what is says on the official IELTS website: &rdquo;<em>IELTS recognises both British and American English in terms of spelling, grammar and choice of words</em>&rdquo;. So you can use either in your answers.</li>\n</ul> <ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Don&rsquo;t worry about what you write on the exam sheet</span></strong>  &ndash; in practice tests, it is common to see students rubbing or crossing things out on the exam paper. Remember that nobody sees or marks what you write here. Don&rsquo;t waste time getting the spelling correct or anything else. If you do this you&rsquo;ll get lost &ndash; you need to be listening. So just write down what you hear then move on. When you transfer the answers at the end to the answer sheet, you can make sure you have the correct spelling.</li>\n</ul> <ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Read the instructions</span></strong>  &ndash; an IELTS listening tip that is an important tip for any part of the test is to always read the instructions carefully. They will tell you how many words to use. If it asks for no more than two words and you use three, it will be wrong. And you must only put in the words asked for. For example, if there is a gap of &ldquo;<em>at &hellip;&hellip; pm</em>&rdquo; and you write &ldquo;<em>at 5pm</em>&rdquo; on the answer sheet, it will be wrong. You should only write what is missing i.e. &ldquo;<em>5</em>&rdquo;.</li>\n</ul> <ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Use upper or lower case letters</span></strong>  &ndash; a question often asked is whether you can use upper case letters. This is what it says on the official British Council Website: &ldquo;<em>You may write your answers in lower case or capital letters</em>&rdquo;. So you can write all your answers in capital letters if you like. This statement from the British Council suggests, therefore, that you will not be penalised if you write &lsquo;<em>paris</em>&rsquo; for example, instead of &lsquo;<em>Paris</em>&rsquo; because it says you can use lower case letters. However, it is recommended that you try and use capitalisation correctly to be on the safe side. If you are not sure if the first letter needs capitalisation, then capitalise the whole word.</li>\n</ul> <ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Get used to the British accent</span></strong>  &ndash; a good IELTS listening tip is to be prepared to hear all accents as you may hear Australian, American, Canadian, New Zealand and a mix of European countries. However, although there are a mix of accents in the test, the majority tend to be British (unlike TOEFL which tends to be American). So make sure you are used to the British accent.</li>\n</ul> <ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Practice the pronunciation of letter and numbers</span></strong>  &ndash; often words are spelt out in the test by a speaker and numbers are read out, so make sure you can recognise how different letters sound in different accents, not just words.</li>\n</ul> <ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Careful with what you write down</span></strong>  &ndash; speakers in the test will often give an answer but then correct themselves. So the first answer that looks right may actually be wrong.</li>\n</ul> <ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Don&rsquo;t leave answers blank</span></strong>  &ndash; you will not get penalised for writing the wrong answer (as opposed to nothing if you are not sure what it is) so guess if that is possible.</li>\n</ul> <ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Transfer your answers to the answer sheet carefully</span></strong>  &ndash; if you put correct answers in the wrong place on the answer sheet it will be wrong, so make sure you put the answer in the correct place. It is easy to do this if you leave an answer blank on the exam sheet. You may then fill that one in with the wrong answer when you transfer them across. So put in a guess for any you do not know and leave no blanks.</li>\n</ul> <ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Check your answers</span></strong>  - make sure you recheck your spelling and grammar too when you transfer your answers at the end.</li>\n</ul> <ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Listen very carefully</span></strong>  - listen very very carefully throughout the test. Zone in and focus. Don&rsquo;t be distracted by anything around you, and don&rsquo;t panic if you think you having missed any answers or that you are getting them wrong. All this will do is distract you from listening.</li>\n</ul>",

        "content": "<ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Practice listening</span></strong>  &ndash; of all the IELTS listening tips, this is one of the most important. Make sure you practice listening as much as you can! You can practice with sample IELTS listening tests but you should also expose yourself to as much English as you can. Target it at the level you are currently at. There is no point in listening to BBC World if you don&rsquo;t understand any of it. Find resources on the internet that suit your level and gradually increase difficulty. And don&rsquo;t worry if they are not exams or specifically for IELTS, any kind of listening helps. Try to make listening fun and listen to things you like. You can move on to more difficult things as you improve.</li>\n</ul> <ul>\n<li><span class=\"red\"><strong>Listen to lectures</strong>  </span>&ndash; remember that the last part is a lecture, so practice listening to lectures and taking notes. Lectures often follow certain patterns, such as an introduction to tell you the topic and main points, and they have sign-posts to tell you if they are comparing e.g. \"<em>although</em>\", or moving onto a new main points e.g. &ldquo;<em>Now I&rsquo;ll discuss&hellip;.</em>&rdquo;. So listening to lectures will help you with this section. You can find lectures online if you do a search. TED lectures may be useful as they provide a transcription so you can check your notes.</li>\n</ul> <ul>\n<li><strong><span class=\"red\">Learn to listen and write together</span></strong> &ndash; practicing your listening skills is important, but remember in the test you have to write and listen. So you should practice this too. One way to do this is with practice tests but you can also try listening to audios and taking notes at the same time. This will improve your ability to do both skills at the same time.</li>\n</ul>",

        "content": "<p>This first section of the IELTS Speaking exam lasts about 4-5 minutes and gives the examiner the chance to find out a little about you through some simple &lsquo;getting-to-know-you&rsquo; questions. These will be questions that you&rsquo;ll have something to talk about such as your family, where you come from and what your interests are. This is also YOUR chance to get off to a good start!</p> <p>Example Questions:</p> <p>Q: Tell me a little about where you come from?</p>\n<p>Q: Do you enjoy studying English?</p>\n<p>Q: Why are you taking the IELTS exam?</p>\n<p>Q: Have you got any interests or hobbies?</p> <p>Part 1: Top Tips!</p> <p>Impress the examiner with your ability to give full answers to his or her questions.</p> <p>a) Avoid short, &lsquo;yes&rsquo;, &lsquo;no&rsquo; answers.</p> <p>Q: Tell me a little about where you come from?</p>\n<p>A: I&rsquo;m from Coimbra. It&rsquo;s a city in the central part of Portugal. It&rsquo;s a very historical city and we have one of the oldest universities in Europe.</p>\n<p>Use examples to back up statements.</p> <p>Q: Do you enjoy studying English?</p>\n<p>A: Oh yes! I went to England last year and loved being able to communicate with local people. And knowing a second language means you have access to a whole new culture &hellip; new authors, English films.</p> <p>b) Give the examiner a picture of you.</p> <p>Q: Why are you taking the IELTS exam?</p>\n<p>A: I&rsquo;m taking an IELTS course in India in order to go to university in the UK. I&rsquo;ve been accepted on a Business course in London but need to get the right IELTS score so I&rsquo;ve been doing lots of IELTS Speaking practice.</p> <p>Q: Have you got any interests or hobbies?</p>\n<p>A: Not really. I like watching football and read books quite often, but I don&rsquo;t have any hobbies really. Hopefully one day I&rsquo;ll discover a hidden interest!</p>",

        "content": "<p>This lesson is a quiz using IELTS speaking questions and answers to provide you with some general tips on successfully answering questions for part one of the IELTS speaking test.</p> <p>In part one of the test, you are asked general questions about yourself - follow this link to view example part one questions if you do not know what to expect.</p> <p>You'll be asked about 12 questions in part one of the test, and these will be taken from three different sets of topics which the examiner will choose.</p> <p>For example you could be asked about:</p> <p>Your home town</p>\n<p>Your favourite holiday destination</p>\n<p>What kinds of books you like to read</p>\n<p>So you'll have about four questions on each of these.</p> <p>Now, take this 'IELTS Speaking Questions and Answers Quiz' to see if you know what is the best way to respond in this part of the test.</p> <p>Decide which answer you think is the best, then click on the letter to see if you are right.</p> <p>You should have learnt from these IELTS speaking questions and answers to:</p> <p>Stay on topic</p> <p>Listen carefully to the question and make sure you are answering it. Don't talk about something completely different just so you can talk for longer.</p>\n<p>Extend your answers</p> <p>Give reasons for your answer. This can be a useful way to extend your responses. Always explain WHY you have given the answer that you have.</p>\n<p>Don't speak excessively</p> <p>Extend your answers but don't go on too much. This will only mean the examiner will have to keep interrupting you to move onto the next questions.</p>\n<p>Be honest but positive</p> <p>Try to remain upbeat and positive even if you are saying you don't do things or don't enjoy things you are being asked about. You can always put a positive slant on your answers.</p>",

        "content": "<p>This is an idea about how to improve speaking about likes and dislikes in IELTS. The very simple idea is that one way to improve is to practise speaking about what you like and dislike about some similar things &ndash; in this case leisure activities. I show you ways to do this by</p>\n<ul>\n<li><strong>speaking about how much you like something</strong></li>\n<li><strong>giving reasons for your preferences</strong></li>\n<li><strong>making comparisons between your preferences</strong></li>\n<li><strong>talking about consequences</strong></li>\n</ul>\n<p>Doing this should help your fluency in all 3 parts of the speaking test.</p> <p><strong>A possible model</strong></p>\n<p>The goal here is to work on your fluency and speaking skills and not necessarily produce an &ldquo;IELTS&rdquo; answer to an IELTS question. Rather I suggest you use this as a model to show you the different ways you can expand your answer</p> <p>My favourite film by far is The Shawshank Redemption. [say what it is and how much]</p> <p>I suppose it&rsquo;s because it&rsquo;s such a feel-good movie and you can&rsquo;t help but feel uplifted at the end. The plot is fantastic and has a great twist in it at the end but what really makes the film for me is the cast, both the leading actors Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman give truly great performances and you really believe in their characters. [give a reason with some detail]</p> <p>I also quite like Fugitive with Harrison Ford &ndash; which is quite similar in some ways &ndash; but it doesn&rsquo;t give me the same feeling just because I don&rsquo;t believe in the characters in the same way. [make a comparison]</p> <p>In fact I enjoy Shawshank so much that I watch it again and again &ndash; I guess I must have seen it about 10 times so far and I never get bored by it. [talk about consequences]</p> <p>  </p>\n<p><strong>Make a list</strong></p>\n<p>Here are some categories of typical leisure activities you may be asked about in IELTS speaking. Choose something you like and dislike in each category. If you think of something you dislike that can often help you with saying why you like something else &ndash; and vice versa. You can not only compare the two things but you can often see more clearly what aspect of that thing/activity is important to you.</p> <p>a film</p> <p>a book</p> <p>a song/piece of music</p> <p>a picture</p> <p>a tv programme</p> <p>a game/sport</p> <p>an indoors activity</p> <p>an outdoors activity</p> <p>Decide how much</p> <p>Not all likes and dislikes are equal. One way you can practise speaking is deciding how much you like/dislike something. Go through your list and decide which of these phrases is most appropriate &ndash; you can of course choose your own too.</p> <p>Note the use of the adverbs such as quite, pretty and really and see how they add meaning to what you say</p> <p>I quite like</p> <p>I&rsquo;m rather fond of</p> <p>I&rsquo;m pretty keen on</p> <p>quite my favourite</p> <p>I really enjoy</p> <p>I absolutely adore</p> <p>I don&rsquo;t particularly like</p> <p>I&rsquo;m not especially fond of</p> <p>I actively dislike</p> <p>My least favourite</p> <p>I positively don&rsquo;t enjoy</p> <p>I detest</p> <p>  </p>\n<p><strong>Say why &ndash; be specific</strong></p>\n<p>You also need to extend your answer and one obvious way to do this is give a reason. Here the two words are reason and because</p> <p>The reason I like [] is</p> <p>I dislike [] is because</p> <p>It can also help to be more specific and to avoid only using words such as interesting and boring when you are giving your reasons. It&rsquo;s often better to focus on one or two particular parts of what you&rsquo;re talking about. This allows you to say more normally. It can also help to focus on how much you like or dislike something as you speak.</p> <p>To get you started, here are one or two quick ideas about more precise aspects of each subject you can talk about.</p> <p>Film &ndash; plot &ndash; characters &ndash; cast &ndash; genre (action/romcom etc)</p> <p>Book &ndash; author- plot &ndash; characters &ndash; genre (detective/classic/romance etc)</p> <p>Music &ndash; rhythm &ndash; lyrics &ndash; genre (dance/house/classical etc)</p> <p>Picture &ndash; setting &ndash; subject &ndash; format</p> <p>TV programme &ndash; actors &ndash; characters &ndash; plot &ndash; episode &ndash; genre (chat show/soap/sitcom etc)</p> <p>Indoors activity (e.g. game) &ndash; when/where you do it &ndash; other people &ndash; purpose</p> <p>Outdoors activity &ndash; when/where you do it &ndash; other people &ndash; purpose</p> <p>  </p>\n<p><strong>Compare it</strong></p>\n<p>Another way to say more is simply compare something you like with something you dislike or like less. One key word here can be prefer</p> <p>I much prefer [] to [] because</p> <p>Try to add to your description of things you enjoy by comparing/contrasting them with things you like less.</p>",

    {
        "content": "<p>If you&rsquo;re looking for some speaking practice for part 1 IELTS, here&rsquo;s a simple idea that may help you improve your skills. You just practise speaking about the same questions in slightly different ways.</p> <p>How does it help? It can be easy to get stuck with trying to find the perfect answer to a question and trying to repeat that when you get to the test. That can put more pressure on you &ndash; especially when you get a slightly unexpected question. This method is different. You go into the test with</p> <p>ideas of different things you can say</p>\n<p>different ways of extending your answer &ndash; the key skill in part 1</p>\n<p>It can help you find answers to unexpected questions and questions you haven&rsquo;t prepared for.</p> <p>  </p>\n<p>Key idea &ndash; try some different ways of saying more</p> <p>What I suggest is that you try answering the same question in 4 different ways. Here are 4 possibilities.</p> <p>adding detail</p>\n<p>talking about different times</p>\n<p>giving a reason</p>\n<p>This list isn&rsquo;t supposed to be complete! There are lots of ways of answering questions. Rather it&rsquo;s supposed to show you that if you think in different ways you can find more to say. Do this exercise enough and you&rsquo;ll soon find you have lots of things to say to even simple questions.</p> <p>Look at these sample answers to the question &ldquo;What do you study?&rsquo;.</p> <p>Detail</p> <p>I&rsquo;m majoring in English but I&rsquo;m also doing French as my minor and taking one or two optional courses in Spanish. We spend most of our time on literature but there are also some modules in language too.</p> <p>Different times</p> <p>I&rsquo;m currently doing a degree at Nottingham Uni &ndash; it&rsquo;s in English . But I&rsquo;ve only been doing that for a couple of months now. Before that I was at Shanghai Central University where I also studied English &ndash; the difference is that there most of the course focussed on the language and not literature.</p> <p>A reason</p> <p>I&rsquo;m actually studying English. I chose to do that as I&rsquo;ve always enjoyed literature and it&rsquo;s also a chance to take my language to another level. I&rsquo;ve always wanted to learn to speak a language really fluently and in the end it should help me find a well-paid job.</p> <p>Quick notes</p> <p>Don&rsquo;t worry about trying to say something completely different each time. That&rsquo;s not really the goal. In practice many of your answers will sound quite similar and contain similar information. Rather what should happen is that each time you change your answer you find another way of talking about the same thing.</p> <p>Do this exercise enough and the process of extending your answers should become what we call &ldquo;second nature&rdquo; &ndash; something you do automatically.</p> <p>See some more examples</p> <p>Adding detail</p> <p>Look at these possible questions about university life and see how I add detail each time. More detail leads to more specific language. That&rsquo;s good for vocabulary.</p> <p>Start with a simple general answer first</p>\n<p>Make your answer personal and think about your personal experience</p>\n<p>As you&rsquo;re speaking, just try and be more precise when you say something general</p>\n<p>What do you study?</p> <p>I&rsquo;m majoring in English but I&rsquo;m also doing French as my minor and taking one or two optional courses in Spanish. We spend most of our time on literature but there are also some modules in language too.</p> <p>Why did you choose to study that?</p> <p>I chose law because I&rsquo;ve always wanted to be a barrister. It&rsquo;s been my ambition since I was in 8th grade when I we had a day in court and I was fascinated by the whole process and I just knew I wanted help defend the innocent.</p> <p>What do you like about your course?</p> <p>I most enjoy it when we get to work in the labs.</p> <p>Talking about different times</p> <p>These are the same questions &ndash; I just answer them differently because this time I&rsquo;m thinking about different times. This can give you more to say but also can help your grammar by showing that you can use different tenses.</p> <p>Answer the question in the tense it is asked in first</p>\n<p>Think about other times too. What about last year/ Next year?</p>\n<p>What do you study?</p> <p>I&rsquo;m currently doing a masters at Nottingham Uni &ndash; it&rsquo;s in Biomechanical Engineering. But I&rsquo;ve only been doing that for a couple of months now. Before that I was at Shanghai Central University where I did my first degree in engineering.</p> <p>Why did you choose to study that?</p> <p>I chose computer science because that was the subject I was best at in school and I had the right grades to get to university. I had wanted to become a doctor when I was little because my dad is a neurosurgeon but then</p> <p>What do you like about your course?</p> <p>Writing essays and doing research! When I was at school I used to hate having to write essays but it&rsquo;s really different now when I have to write a paper at uni. I get to do my own research and I don&rsquo;t just have to repeat all the notes I made class like in school.</p> <p>Giving a reason</p> <p>Here are the same questions again. This time I concentrate on extending my answer in a different way &ndash; giving a reason. Note you can do this even when you don&rsquo;t hear the question &ldquo;why?&rdquo;. To extend your answer further, see if you can explain your reason. Don&rsquo;t just say &ldquo;because&rdquo;.</p> <p>Answer the question</p>\n<p>Give a reason with because</p>\n<p>Explain the reason</p>\n<p>What do you study?</p> <p>I&rsquo;m actually studying to be a dentist. I chose to do dentistry because it&rsquo;s a good career and pays well and the hours aren&rsquo;t quite as demanding as being a doctor &ndash; which was my other option. My career and financial security matter quite a lot to me.</p> <p>Why did you choose to study that?</p> <p>I decided to study economics because I my goal is to run my own business one day. It&rsquo;s an ambitious goal I know but I really want to be independent and not have to work for a giant corporation. And knowing about finance is the best way to get there I think.</p> <p>What do you like about your course?</p> <p>I suppose it&rsquo;s the experiments in the labs. That&rsquo;s because I don&rsquo;t really enjoy the reading and essay writing at all and I chose to do science because I&rsquo;m interested in seeing how things work &ndash; or don&rsquo;t work &ndash; in practice.</p> <p>Try some more practice questions about university life</p> <p>Have a go at giving your own answers to the question above and then try these questions. Remember the idea is not to get one perfect answer but to experiment and see what different answers you can give.</p> <p>What do you like about your course?</p> <p>Is there anything you dislike about your course?</p> <p>What is the most interesting thing about what you study?</p> <p>Do you study in a group or alone?</p> <p>What are your career plans?</p>",

    {
        "content": "<p>In Part 2 of the IELTS Speaking exam you have to speak for between 1 and 2 minutes on a set topic based on information on a card the examiner will give you. You&rsquo;ll be a given a minute to prepare what you want to say &ndash; just enough time to jot down some ideas to help give your talk structure and interest.</p> <p>Example Topics:</p> <p>Example 1: Describe a teacher you have fond memories of.</p> <p>You should say:</p> <p>when this was</p>\n<p>where you were studying when you met</p>\n<p>which subject they taught you</p>\n<p>and what it was about the person that makes them so memorable.</p> <p>Example 2: Describe an item of technology you use that you couldn&rsquo;t do without.</p> <p>You should say:</p> <p>what this technology is</p>\n<p>when you first started using it</p>\n<p>how you use it</p>\n<p>and why it&rsquo;s so essential for you.</p> <p>Part 2: Top Tips!</p> <p>a) Make the most of your preparation time and make notes.</p>\n<p>b) Structure your talk with an introduction, main body and conclusion. Signpost your talk at the end with words or expressions like:</p> <p>&ldquo;So &hellip;&rdquo;</p> <p>&ldquo;As you can see &hellip;&rdquo;</p> <p>&rdquo;To sum up &hellip;&rdquo;</p> <p>c) Add personal details such as short anecdotes to help make your talk interesting.</p>\n<p>d) Don&rsquo;t speak too fast. Pause between sentences and try to relax.</p> <p>Part 2: Troubleshooting</p> <p>Many people preparing for the IELTS long turn worry how they can finish what they want to say in the time available. The best way to get the timing right is to practise making short talks on various topics on your own. (Or in front of a friend if you&rsquo;re feeling brave!) Try building in a short introduction and conclusion to give your talk structure. You&rsquo;ll almost certainly overrun or finish too quickly at first but the more you practise the sooner you&rsquo;ll get a feel for the time available.</p> <p>And remember, we often feel nervous when presenting and this can often lead to us speaking too quickly. Try not to rush. Regular pauses between sentences will help you control the pace of your talk and the examiner will find it easier to follow what you&rsquo;re saying.</p> <p>You can find out more about structuring short talks and using pauses for effect in IELTS Speaking Advanced.</p>",
        "main_topic": "Speaking Part 2",

        "title": "Part 2: The Long Turn",
        "topic": ""

    {
        "content": "<p>In the IELTS speaking part 2, you will be given a topic by the examiner, and you have to speak for two minutes.</p> <p>The topic will be one that the examiner chooses and you cannot change it.</p> <p>They are always things that you should have some experience of and be able to talk about.</p> <p>However, some students find it difficult to do because you only have one minute to prepare what you are going to say.</p> <p>You may also be nervous having to speak for 2 minutes in front of someone.</p> <p>You don't want to run out of things to say so in this lesson there are some tips to help you extend your long-turn.</p> <p>Let's imagine that you are given this IELTS speaking part 2 question:</p> <p>Describe someone who has had an important influence on your life.</p> <p>  </p> <p>You should say:</p> <p>Who the person is</p>\n<p>How long you have known him/her</p>\n<p>What qualities this person has</p> <p>Explain why they have had such an influence on you</p> <p>  </p>\n<p>Firstly, you must talk about the topic on the card.</p> <p>However, if you only talk about the specific questions on the card, you may find that you finish too soon.</p> <p>As long as you keep to the topic, it is ok to talk about other things.</p> <p>Here are two things you can do in the minute you have before you speak to help you find more to say for the IELTS speaking part 2.</p> <p>1. Use other &lsquo;question&rsquo; prompts</p> <p>These are question prompts:</p> <p>Who</p>\n<p>What</p>\n<p>When</p>\n<p>Where</p>\n<p>How</p>\n<p>Why</p>\n<p>When you prepare, write down the other question prompts that are not on the list, and think of things you can say about those as well.</p> <p>For example:</p> <p>When - When did you meet?</p>\n<p>Where &ndash; Where did you meet?</p> <p>2. Think of a Story</p> <p>You can also tell a story about the person, place, event or thing you are discussing.</p> <p>So in your one minute, think of and note down a quick and preferably interesting story to tell about the topic.</p> <p>You can tell the story anywhere in your IELTS speaking part 2, as long as it fits in.</p> <p>  </p>\n<p>Example IELTS Speaking Part 2 :</p> <p>The person I&rsquo;m going to talk about today is my teacher from high school. (who) Her name was Miss Chadwick and she taught quite a few subjects at the school. She had been working there for quite a few years when I met her I think. (where) We met for the first time in my English class. (more about &lsquo;who&rsquo;) I remember this well because she was quite young compared to most of the other teachers in the school so I was surprised that she was a teacher! In fact she looked more like she could be one of the older students!</p> <p>(How long) So I met her when I was 15, and that was 10 years ago. I don&rsquo;t actually know her anymore as we lost contact soon after I left the school, but I still remember her very well for several reasons. (What qualities) Firstly, she was very kind. She always treated all the students very well in the class, and I can&rsquo;t remember her ever shouting at anyone. Also, she had a really good sense of humour. She would make jokes in the class which most of the other teachers never did. The other teachers were very serious all the time. And she made the classes a lot of fun and very interesting, something that I think is very important otherwise you start to get bored. Oh, and also she explained things very well and very clearly. Often teachers are not able to do this in a way that students can understand, especially when it's complicated subjects.</p> <p>So those are the qualities that she had. (why such an influence) The reason she had such an important influence on me is because I was quite a shy person at school and not very confident, but she helped me to change this. (tell a story) Each year, there was a school play that would be held in front of all the parents, and that year, when I was 15, Miss Chadwick was organizing and directing the play. I really didn't want to be in it because I was so shy, but Miss Chadwick insisted that I take one of the roles, and it was one of the main roles which meant that I would have to do a lot of speaking! I was so nervous. Anyway, I went ahead and did it, and on the night I did really well and really enjoyed it. And that really boosted my confidence and this has helped me to this day.</p> <p>So my teacher Miss Chadwick is the person who has influenced my life and I will never forget her.</p>",
